PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the comments made by the British Foreign Secretary, Mr Douglas Hurd, in Cairo that Saddam Hussein may have to be forced from Kuwait at the point of a gun, I ask: What is the current assessment of the Australian Government as to the effectiveness of the current sanctions? Does Australia believe that greater pressure should be applied and, if so, what? How many Australians are currently being held against their will in Kuwait and Iraq?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the last question, the situation is that the numbers of Australians actually restrained from leaving-in effect held in Iraq and Kuwait against their will-are 15 and 17 respectively. The number of Australians actually in detention in Iraq is just one, and in Kuwait just one-the two who have been mentioned in public comment on a number of previous occasions. There is a larger number of other Australian passport holders-about the same number again in Iraq and Kuwait respectively-but they are largely people of Iraqi or Kuwaiti origin who, to our knowledge, have no inclination to leave and, for that reason, are not being held against their will.

ANSWER.PARA: The general situation in the Gulf at the moment is not, in my assessment, such as to make us believe that military action will be necessary, although it remains the case-as the Australian Government has said from the outset-that the military strike option must be kept open as an option in the event that sanctions and related peaceful means of resolving the crisis do not work. I understand the British Foreign Secretary to be saying no more than that-that should peaceful means prove not to work, then of course the military option will be contemplated. I understand American spokesmen to have said nothing different from that; nor, as I say, have Australian spokesmen-myself, the Prime Minister or anybody else. We all wish that the strike option can be avoided because the downside consequences of that are very significant, but if it comes to that-and nobody at this stage wants to indicate the timing within such a decision may have to be made-that course of action will just have to be confronted. What is clear is that Saddam Hussein cannot be allowed to win, cannot be allowed to win by default.

Nonetheless, having said all that, I do strongly believe that the various Allied forces are all, at the moment, committed to securing a result by peaceful outcomes if that is humanly possible. In my judgment, nobody is pressing for a military strike option in advance of its becoming clear that peaceful means will not succeed.

So far as sanctions are concerned, my assessment of the situation, following again another very substantial round of discussions in New York and Washington in recent days, is that there is a belief that sanctions can and will bite. The emphasis should not be placed solely on foodstuffs, but on industrial consumables, spare parts, and things generally to keep the transport and industrial infrastructure going. Things as different as water purification chemicals, not just for potable water but also for industrial processes to avoid the mineralisation of pipes and things of that kind, batteries, ball-bearings, and a whole variety of other things of this kind are already in very short supply and there is a reasonable expectation that shortages of this kind will before very much longer start having a dramatic effect. It is very difficult to be precise about when that effect will show up or when it will be perceived as inevitable, which is also something we are trying to create in terms of perception. But for the moment there are strong grounds for believing that the sanctions course, around which the world is holding together in a very united way, will be successful.

It may need to be accompanied by some appropriate negotiations on matters which are legitimately negotiable. It is very clear that a number of matters are not legitimately negotiable because they would undermine the basic objectives which this exercise is all about. But things such as the future security environment of the Middle East area are manifestly things which can be the subject of discussion. It may be that those sorts of things can come into the process at some appropriate time.

It would be quite inappropriate to be foolishly optimistic about the environment in the Gulf. It is much too dangerous, much too critically poised, and the stakes are much too high for any easy assumptions of any kind about the future course of these events. But I do, as I say, remain personally quite optimistic that the course on which the world is embarked can bear appropriate fruit-peace without appeasement-and without there needing to be recourse to military action. But that option must, I repeat, be maintained as very much part of the allied armoury in the event that that more confident prediction does not in fact eventuate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to reports that Israel has refused to cooperate with a decision by the United Nations Secretary-General to send a mission to the region to report on the deaths of over 20 Palestinian demonstrators in East Jerusalem on 8 October, despite the fact that the mission has been endorsed by the United Nations Security Council over the weekend. What is the Government's reaction to the Israeli decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government welcomes the terms of United Nations Security Council resolution No. 672, which the Security Council adopted unanimously on 13 October in response to the deaths, as Senator McKiernan has said, of more than 20 Palestinian demonstrators in East Jerusalem on 8 October.

ANSWER.PARA: The resolution does several things. It expresses alarm at the violence which occurred, pointing out that it involved not only death and injury to Palestinians, but injury to innocent worshippers as well-a clear reference to the Jewish worshippers at the Wailing Wall. It condemns especially the acts of violence committed by the Israeli security forces. It calls upon Israel to abide scrupulously by its obligations and responsibilities under the Fourth Geneva Convention, which is applicable to all the territories occupied by Israel since 1967. It welcomes the decision by the Secretary-General of the United Nations to send a mission to the region to report on the violence, and it requests the Secretary-General to report his findings to the Security Council by the end of this month.

The Australian Government, in a statement by the Acting Foreign Minister, Dr Blewett, has deplored the deaths which resulted from the violence in the past week, and I do so again. My Department has in recent days called in the Israeli Ambassador to impress upon him our deep and serious concern in this respect. Whatever the provocation-and there undoubtedly was provocation from the Palestinian demonstrators-the response of the Israeli authorities was wholly, and tragically, disproportionate.

We support the Secretary-General's mission as a means of defusing the current highly-charged situation in the occupied territories, which could easily produce more needless deaths. We are, therefore, extremely disappointed that Israel has refused to cooperate with the Secretary-General's mission. The Israeli decision is simply not helpful to progress in the resolution of the Palestinian problem, either in the short or the long term. We urge the Israeli Government to reconsider its position.

I can say, a little more generally, that the Security Council's unanimous decision in relation to the Secretary-General's mission does reflect the Council's enhanced authority in dealing with key global and regional issues such as the situation in the Middle East. This decision, and indeed the Security Council's several resolutions during the past 10 weeks in relation to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, do give us reason to hope that we are beginning a new phase in international cooperation; in fact a new world order, if that spirit of cooperation can be sustained. I have to say in this respect that Israel's negative response to the SecretaryGeneral's mission does stand in contrast with these new international norms of cooperation.

Israel, and friends of Israel, know that the Palestinian problem cannot forever be wished away. Demographic and strategic imperatives demand that it be addressed, and addressed sooner rather than later. It is very much in Israel's own interest that it be addressed in a climate of reconciliation rather than hatred, of international cooperation rather than confrontation. The kind of unapologetic, defensive and negative reflex reaction that we have seen from Israel over the last few days will simply not do anything to help establish that kind of climate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In supporting the Government's decision to accept a 20 per cent carbon dioxide reduction during the next 15 years, I recognise that for such a significant decision to be taken, considerable detailed investigation was necessary. Accordingly, can the Minister advise: first, what is the priority status for dealing with the various sources of emission; and, secondly, what revised funding will be provided for all the extra research that will be necessary if the changes are to be accomplished in accordance with the timetable to which we are now committed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last 12 to 18 months the Australian and New Zealand Environment Council has been looking at this question, as have the energy Ministers. During that time, a consultancy for the environment Ministers commissioned from Jenny Green provided some valuable information on the way we might go in this debate. The energy Ministers also have done some work on this question.

ANSWER.PARA: I imagine that the exact decisions about which areas will be targeted first will come about only after discussion with the States. Obviously, the States will have a crucial role to play in this. Those discussions are yet to take place. Both environment Ministers and energy Ministers would have a hand in them. I would not have thought it appropriate to try to pre-empt those discussions. Nonetheless, there are a number of ways, particularly in the use of energy in households, that we can attack the problem fairly cheaply and fairly quickly while making significant contributions to the reductions which these targets call for. I imagine that they are high on the priority list of environment and energy Ministers. I shall endeavour to keep the Senate informed on those discussions as they take place over the course of the next six to 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister completely failed to answer the second half of my question about what revised funding will be provided for all the extra research that will be necessary. He also raised the matter of the consultancy. Are we to be privy to the suggestions made by the consultancy? Also, have the States-he referred to them being included in this-agreed to participate and to fund in some way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the best of my memory that consultancy to which I referred was made public nearly a year ago, but I will check on that. On the assumption that there is no objection, and I cannot imagine there would be, we will have a copy sent around to the honourable senator as soon as we can. In terms of funding, the honourable senator will also be aware of the very significant funding which the Prime Minister announced last year for greenhouse research, which will place Australia in the forefront of greenhouse research right around the world. I do not believe that is the end of the funding on greenhouse questions and on research.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think it is appropriate now for us to be setting levels. But rather, as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and whatever consultants or State energy commissions come up with during the course of the next few years, we will certainly have to look to extra funding. It is a matter of assessing those requests as they come in. We have set up a greenhouse committee of very prominent, eminent scientists and I think they will be better at assessing these claims than we are. So I am sure that that is where they will go.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of claims that the rock music industry in Australia has achieved export earnings for Australia to the value of some $90m this year? Can the Minister advise what the comparison is to export earnings from opera, ballet or the more conservative forms of the arts in Australia? If the rock music industry earnings, which have increased some 100 per cent in the past two years, are exporting to such an increased market, what plans are there for expanding Government assistance to rock music organisations, such as Export Music Australia or Ausmusic, to take advantage of the huge overseas demand for Australian rock music?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht's tie seems to have encouraged as much interest as the ballet, for example, or perhaps the opera. I confirm to the Senate that the music industry is aggressively marketing its products overseas. Senator Schacht pointed out that export earnings by the Australian rock music industry will amount to $90m this year. I can just give you some examples of success by Australian bands, such as INXS, which is currently at the top of the American charts and is also exporting Australian rock to the world.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht asked about the more traditional performing arts companies, such as the opera and the ballet. I am not able to answer that part of the question in full, except to say that the Australian Ballet deservedly has a very fine reputation overseas for the quality and imaginativeness of its performances, and it has just recently had a very successful tour of the United States. I am unable to make any equally charitable remarks about Australian opera.

TALK.START.PARA: —Philistine.

—But that may be based on ignorance, as some interjector friend at the back of me just said. However, the facts are that the popular music industry has much greater potential for continued growth in its export earnings. For example, last week there was a presentation of a master copy of a television program featuring Australian recording artists to be shown on Soviet television. Soviet radio is already playing 24 hours of Australian popular music each month to an audience of an estimated 280 million people. The Australian singer, Gyan, is already a very popular figure in the Soviet Union. Soviet television will be showing a number of programs by Australian recording artists.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht asked about funding. These initiatives have been jointly funded by Austrade and Export Music Australia, which was started with some Government assistance but which is now a private sector organisation. Both Austrade and Export Music Australia recognise that there will be no quick return on their investment in the Soviet market, but they are working to generate a demand for Australian music which will put our industry in a good position when the Soviet Union is in a position to trade in hard currency.

Export opportunities are not just there for the asking. As in every industry they have be looked for, and companies have to be willing to invest both time and money in new markets. The popular music industry has shown a commendable initiative in doing that, not just in the market to which I have referred, but also in Europe, and of course it has had some considerable success in North America.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: ALLEGED HUMAN RIGHTS ABUSES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen reports from Amnesty International of human rights abuses being committed by both the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) and the Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA), including torture, police threats, assaults, extrajudicial executions and deaths in custody? Has the Minister also seen recent media reports that the blockade of Bougainville has not been lifted, resulting in a drastic reduction in the supply of food and medicines there? If so, has the Minister raised these concerns with the Papua New Guinea Government, or does he intend to do so? If these concerns have been raised, what was its response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just seen the report this morning. It was tabled before the joint committee during my absence overseas. I have not had time to study it in any detail yet, but certainly I will do so. I understand that the abuses referred in the report are in the main those which characterise that very unhappy period early this year when the PNGDF was still stationed on Bougainville, although I understand there are also reports of continuing abuses committed by the BRA. Naturally, we deplore those continuing abuses, although it is not the case that the PNG Government can be in any way regarded as responsible for them. We simply hope that the resolution of the overall problem on Bougainville will resolve that situation.

ANSWER.PARA: As to raising specific human rights concerns of the kind that are addressed in the Amnesty report with the PNG Government, the situation is as follows: both the Prime Minister and I have raised the issue with the PNG Government on a number of occasions at the highest levels, emphasising the need for investigations and appropriate disciplinary action against those who may be responsible. Most recently in September, the Prime Minister discussed our concerns with Prime Minister Namaliu and senior Ministers during his visit to Papua New Guinea.

The PNG Government has acknowledged that abuses have occurred on Bougainville. It has undertaken investigations, but there are difficulties, it has to be acknowledged, in pursuing some of those allegations because of the continuation of the dispute over Bougainville and the unavailability of witnesses to be interviewed. Nonetheless, 67 cases have been listed before the National Court in Rabaul and they are being handled by the Public Solicitor's Office, with the first preliminary hearing set for a couple of days ago-12 October. I am not sure what the outcome of that hearing was. During the endeavour talks, the PNG Government proposed the involvement of the International Commission of Jurists to assist investigations into human rights abuses by both sides, but I understand the BRA did not agree to that.

It remains an important objective of Australian assistance to the PNG security forces to provide training to ensure discipline and an environment in which respect for human rights is upheld. All I can say in response to the question generally is that it is an issue which we are very conscious of and will pursue with vigour and consistency so far as the PNG Government is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I preface my question by referring to the continuing public debate on micro-economic reform in Australia. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the current position of the Government's reform program on the Australian waterfront?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may get a few guffaws from the other side, but it is a very important matter as far as the micro- economic reform of the Australian economy is concerned. I was very pleased this morning to officiate at an extremely important occasion in Port Botany in Sydney when National Terminals (Australia) Ltd announced the major upgrade of its container facility at Port Botany. This upgrade will involve a total expenditure of $60m at the container terminal, $40m of which will have been spent before the end of next year. It is a very significant addition to waterfront reform in Australia as it will make the container terminal in Senator Loosley's home port of Sydney the largest container terminal in Australia. But more importantly, the renovated terminal will have the capacity to reduce the turnaround times of shipping in that port by 40 per cent.
—Careful choice, the word `capacity'.

—In response to Senator Parer's interjection, the Opposition's sole contribution to the debate on waterfront reform, apart from constant knocking, has been an absolute tirade of misinformation from the shadow Minister, Mr Sharp, who does not seem to be able to get anything right in the statements he puts out on this important issue. What Mr Sharp and those with him have consistently said-and they have a mindset on it-is that there can be no significant improvement in waterfront reform in Australia without a stoush. That is what they want-a fight; prolonged industrial action so that they can demonstrate that the Government's agenda of negotiated settlements on the waterfront will be a failure.
—That is a tired old argument.

—In response to Senator Hill's interjection, we constantly hear from them about following the example of Great Britain and New Zealand by declaring war on the unions, and that this is the only way to fix it up. One could fairly ask the question: Why will National Terminals be spending $60m on a major upgrade of a terminal facility? The reason is that as a direct result of the Government's waterfront reform program National Terminals is in a position to demonstrate a significant degree of confidence in the future of waterfront reform. At the time that I announced a $60m upgrade for the facility in Sydney, I was also in the happy position to announce that agreement has been reached between National Terminals and the waterfront unions on enterprise agreements for the ports of Sydney and Melbourne.

ANSWER.PARA: There are only minor drafting alterations to be made to the agreement and the sending of that agreement to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority for its assessment is now imminent. All major issues have been agreed and only minor drafting changes now need to be made. The parties to this agreement have estimated the productivity gains to be made from these agreements to be in the vicinity of 30 per cent in the port of Melbourne and some 60 per cent in terms of productivity improvements in the port of Sydney.

It has been six months of very intense and difficult negotiation considering that it is the first time for some 50 years that any attempt has been made by any government in this country to reform the waterfront. The Inter-State Commission, after a detailed examination of the waterfront industry, pointed out what I thought was a fairly accurate observation; that is, that the industry was not about to reform itself. As I said to the participants in this morning's procedures at Port Botany, it is not correct simply to assume that the Government is the prime player or the only player in this area. There is a certain mindset about that that is the case. All that any government can do is to provide the right environment for the participants in this major Australian industry to take the opportunities provided.

As Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, I am delighted that National Terminals has taken this opportunity, that agreements for the ports of Sydney and Melbourne have been concluded between that company and the unions, and that as a direct result of those agreements being achieved-although with difficulty, peaceably-National Terminals is prepared to put its money where its mouth is and, in addition to the agreements being negotiated, has announced a $60m upgrade for its terminal facility, which will result in significant improvements in the productivity of the port of Sydney.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 9 October 1990 headed `Scientists may lose funds over ``superpigs'''. Will the Minister confirm that the report of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee states that the scientists at Adelaide University mentioned in the article breached the guidelines established by GMAC for genetic research? What action will the Minister be taking in response to this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report to which Senator Crowley refers. I have also seen the allegation that the scientists have breached the guidelines established for genetic research. By way of background-in March this year the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee was advised by the Adelaide University biohazards committee that there had been a breach of GMAC's safety guidelines for research involving genetic modification. This emanated from a project involving the Adelaide University research team and a South Australian company. Shortly after this-and I am sure this has led to the media interest-the Australian Conservation Foundation issued a press release claiming that there had been an unauthorised release of transgenic pigs.

ANSWER.PARA: The project that is the subject of this particular problem is one that was meant to produce pigs with superior quality meat and rapid growth for sale weight. It had been partly funded by grants by the Industrial Research and Development Board-which is the responsibility of Senator Button-and compliance with GMAC guidelines was a condition of the grants.

I had these reports brought to my notice, and at my instigation the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee inquired into the incident and has provided me with a report, as is indicated in the Sydney Morning Herald article. GMAC found that a total of 67 genetically modified pigs had been transported from experimental facilities to abattoirs between May 1988 and March 1989 and that the guidelines were breached when the principal investigators failed to inform the biohazards committee of the intention to transport these pigs.

I am informed that, in the event, all other appropriate procedures were followed. All the pigs transported were slaughtered. There were no escapes and there was no interbreeding with non-transgenic animals. I am sure that Senator Button will be pleased to know that the meat was also cleared and assessed by the food science and technology committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, using information supplied by the company. The meat was also considered to be fit for human consumption, with approval being gained from the South Australian Health Commission and the Department of Agriculture. GMAC accepted that those involved acted in good faith in the belief that the necessary government approvals and clearances had been obtained. The breach, therefore, was found to be due to a failure of communication between the biohazards committee, the researchers and the company.

In view of GMAC's findings, I have considered the report and have decided not to seek withdrawal of Commonwealth funding for this particular project. I also assure Senator Crowley and others who are interested in this area that all steps have been taken to ensure that the parties involved fully understand their responsibilities to undertake procedures under the guidelines and all have given written undertakings to abide by the guidelines in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: — I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Resources: Now that the forest and the forest industry strategy for Tasmania has been signed by the Farmers and Graziers Association, the Forest Industry Association of Tasmania (FIAT), the Country Sawmillers Association, the Minister in charge of forests, the Timber Workers Union, the Printing and Kindred Industries Union, the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, and has been endorsed by the Tasmanian Cabinet, what role, if any, does the Federal Government anticipate playing in its implementation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot be absolutely precise on what role the Commonwealth would play in its implementation, given that the strategy to which Senator Watson refers is, of course, a strategy concluded at State level in Tasmania-and concluded, moreover, between the State parties in the form of all of those groups the honourable senator referred to in his question. I can say, however, that last year the Commonwealth agreed to assist Tasmania in terms of forestry because of the World Heritage listing in the western side of Tasmania and because of the decision of the Commonwealth to support an area of World Heritage listing arising from the report of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. We decided last year to assist Tasmania with financial support for afforestation programs; programs aimed at encouraging a better yield of sawlog from forest; programs aimed at providing for better technology and thus better recovery of millable material from logs which might ordinarily not go to the mill; and a whole program of support for access into areas of the forest.

ANSWER.PARA: As I say, I am not advised at this point as to whether all of those things are picked up in the forest and forest industry strategy that the honourable senator has referred to. I am happy to check that. I can say, however, that the financial support by the Commonwealth is quite significant. It is highly valued by all parties, including the industry and the unions in Tasmania, and underpins the future development of forestry in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the $4m that has been allocated in this year's Budget towards the multifunction polis (MFP) in Adelaide. Could the Minister please explain how much of that $4m allocation will be going towards community consultation and what form the consultation will take? Does the Minister believe that the project will be a drain on the economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —No more than anything else. Let me say that of the total of $4m allocated in the Budget for the next phase of the MFP project, $1.5m was for community consultation and an information program. The community consultation process is managed by a three-member panel led by Mr Bob Lansdown, the former Chairman of the National Capital Development and Planning Authority, and other members are Dr Deidre Jordan, the Chancellor of Flinders University, and Dr David Wilmuth, Associate Director of Victoria University of Technology. The consultation process will involve a range of activities in Adelaide and in other major cities throughout Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The panel has invited submissions, and during October there will be a series of free public seminars in mainland capitals and key regional centres so that the members of the community can both obtain information and put their views to the panel. During November the panel will hold discussions with people who have made submissions on the project. These submissions will form an important input to a progress report to the Commonwealth and South Australian governments in December 1990. During the final stages of the feasibility project the panel will make a comprehensive report to the Government on its findings, which will be a major input into the Government's final decision on the project.

Senator Maguire asked whether the project will be a drain on the economy. The Government has always said that the project will go ahead only if it is of net benefit to the Australian economy. It is too early to assess the precise costs of establishment in Adelaide, and that is one of the important aspects of the current studies under the guidance of the MFP Management Committee chaired by Mr Ross Adler, the Managing Director of Santos Ltd.

I wonder whether you could ask the Minister to table his document so we could move on.

—Could I just say that Senator Foreman does in fact have a genuine interest in this matter. He has been pursuing this question for something like a fortnight now, and he is entitled to a comprehensive answer. There is in fact only one paragraph of this to go, and I will deliver it.

—Well, that is very big of the honourable senator. This coordinator will develop an Aboriginal employment strategy for the company. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask whether the Minister is aware that Australia Post is distributing to householders a brochure advertising its new Selectmail service which claims as follows:

Or can the Minister give some other explanation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Chapman's question is no, it does not represent anything of the sort. Australia Post does, in fact, operate as a list broker in the same way as a number of other organisations operate as list brokers in what has become the extremely competitive area of direct mail. Indeed, Australia Post operates a very sophisticated direct mail service that it can provide to customers on request, and, I must say, it does a very professional job. I do not have the detail of the particular correspondence that the honourable senator has referred to, but I will get that detail and I will get an answer for Senator Chapman, hopefully, before the end of the day.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware that areas in Western Australia subject to exploration or mining claims for mineral sands include most of the coastal strip from Perth south to Dunsborough, and from Augusta east almost to Esperance, and that this includes parts of the D'Entrecasteaux and Fitzgerald River National Parks as well as State forests, nature reserves and freehold land? In view of the fact that the flora of the south coast is highly significant-much of it growing only in restricted areas and most of it highly susceptible to dieback, which already poses a conservation risk, and is likely to be spread further by mining operations-will the Minister give his assurance that he will use the Government's export control powers to ensure that no national parks, nature reserve, areas with wilderness values or areas listed on the Register of the National Estate will be mined? Will he also give an assurance that the Government will use its powers under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act to ensure that any additional mineral sands operations in Western Australia will be subject to the most stringent environmental safeguards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the opening parts of this question seem to equate exploration with mining and/or the pegging of claims with mining. It should be said for the record that in most cases where exploration occurs-or, indeed, where claims are filed-very little mining follows, and certainly it is not automatic. It depends on what the nature of the discoveries might be. However, the exploration and granting of mining leases is not a matter within the purview of the Commonwealth Government; it is, indeed, a matter for the State Government.

ANSWER.PARA: If as a result of exploration any claims were developed which lead to proposals for mining developments concerning mineral sands, and the output of that mining development were to be exported, then the export control powers of the Commonwealth would come into play and we, as the Commonwealth Government, would have a role. Therefore, before a mineral sands export project could be granted export approval and be allowed to proceed, it would be subject to environmental assessment in terms of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and, where relevant and if necessary, the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

It should also be said that the mineral sands industry is now subject to the most stringent environmental and rehabilitation conditions at both State and Commonwealth levels. Indeed, in many instances the industry has demonstrated both a willingness and an ability to successfully rehabilitate mined areas.

I think that answers the question, but I should say that the mineral sands industry, most of which is located in Western Australia, makes a significant contribution to the economy, with exports valued at around $700m in 1988-89, with this forecast to rise to around $1.2 billion by 1992, including through investment in value-added production.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a case where a person's employer deducted the contributions made to a superannuation scheme from the employee's redundancy payment at the time of his retrenchment. Is the Minister aware of this type of activity in the Australian community and are moves planned to change the legislation to protect workers' superannuation packages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of this problem because Senator Maguire gave me notice of his question. I have been provided with the following answer: the occupational superannuation standards legislation administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission requires a fund wishing to benefit from tax concessions for the relevant year of income to be maintained for the purpose of providing benefits for members or dependants in the event of members' retirement, resignation or death. This type and range of superannuation benefits provided by an employer is a matter for the employer to determine. However, when a superannuation arrangement is established the occupational superannuation standards legislation requires that certain components of benefits be fully vested in the member and, therefore, no deductions can be made from them. In particular, the legislation requires that a benefit arising from member contributions and employer award contributions must be fully vested in the member.

ANSWER.PARA: While the legislation currently does not require vesting of non-award employer-financed benefits, the Government announced in 1989 that it intends introducing into the legislation, with effect from 1995, a requirement for full vesting of the employer-financed benefit after 10 years' membership. The level of voluntary vesting of the employer-financed element in a particular case, and the extent to which that may be varied at the discretion of the trustee, will depend on the provisions of the fund's governing rules. Any concerns about a fund's compliance with the standards or about the adequacy of existing standards should be brought to the attention of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories advise whether he, as Minister at the time, or his Department, monitored the financial operations of the Ravenshoe sawmill during the course of the $7.6m Commonwealth loans and grants from the time that the moneys were lent until the time it went into receivership.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Boswell would know, when financial assistance was made available to the mill at Ravenshoe, which I think had the support of all parties in the chamber, so that it could retool to enable it to handle the pine resource, the Government set in place conditions which had to be met. I have discovered, in answer to Senator O'Chee's question, that $300,000 was repaid out of the loans. In fact, up until the time the company went into receivership it had met the conditions placed upon it by the Commonwealth. I am advised that there was, therefore, no need to take any action until then and no reason for us to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: The point at which receivers came in was, I think, after I was the Minister. I would have to find out the exact time; I think it might have been April or May.

TALK.START.PARA: —20 April.
—I was not the Minister on 20 April. Nonetheless, my advice is that, until that point, the conditions placed upon the Commonwealth providing money had been met.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to give an answer to a question asked last week by Senator Walters about delays in the child support scheme. I am very pleased to say that delays have, contrary to Senator Walters's assertion, considerably shortened since I became Minister for Social Security. But I will not take sole credit for this, as it was the Government's decision to provide additional resources for the Child Support Agency to remove backlogs in processing. My colleagues the Treasurer and Senator McMullan have also taken a strong interest in the performance of the Agency which, as honourable senators will be aware, is in the Australian Taxation Office and not in my portfolio.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier this year there were problems of delays in the Child Support Agency due to lack of resources. The problem came to light earlier this year and I acknowledged it in the Senate on 29 May. As announced on 31 May, the Government provided major increases in resources for the Agency to clear the backlogs. I am pleased to say that the backlogs have now been cleared. The Agency has advised that 85 per cent of applications are now assessed and registered by the Agency within 28 days. There are particular reasons-generally awaiting information from clients-for cases that go over 28 days.

A separate issue is the structural delay of eight weeks for the first payment to be made. This is due to the arrears method of collection; that is, child support assessed for the first month is not due until the seventh of the next month. The Department of Social Security then deposits the money in the custodial parent's bank account on the first Wednesday of the following month. As Senator Walters appears to be confused about this issue, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an example.
Leave granted.
The example read as follows-
* A child support liability assessed for the month of October is not due from the non-custodial parent until the 7th of November and is paid out on the 5th of December.
* Provided a non-custodial parent pays his or her child support obligations regularly and on time, then this is a `once-off' delay and payments are made regularly after that.

* During this period if a custodial parent is a sole parent pensioner then he or she will receive all the pension to which they are entitled, ie pension is not reduced for child support until the first payment is actually received.

* On the question of interest, payments received by the child support agency are paid into the child support trust account. The trust account, in itself, does not earn interest. The account forms part of the Commonwealth public account. The budget as a whole gets the benefit of interest on cash balances in the Commonwealth public account and other benefits in terms of reduced Government borrowings and subsequent reduced public debt interest.
* This initial delay should be put in context:
-Comparable delays in the court processes which existed before the scheme began could be much longer;

-Custodial parents who have money collected through the agency have a significantly increased prospect of receiving regular and ongoing payments, ie before the scheme began only 30% of custodial parents received payments, whereas now the agency collects 70% of liabilities.
Success of the Scheme

* The legislation itself is fundamentally sound and there have been only 125 appeals in more than 18,000 assessments after one year of operation. Most of these have been about the facts of the case not about the formula assessment.
* There are more than 90,000 sole parent pensioners declaring receipt of maintenance and this number continues to rise by about 1000 a month.
* There have been major increases in the levels of child support:
- The average level of court orders per child per week has risen from $27 in April 1988 to $39 in February 1990
- Under stage 2 the average amount of assessments per child has risen from $46 in 1989/90 to $49 in 1990/91.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to questions without notice asked by Senator O'Chee and the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Boswell) this day relating to the Ravenshoe Sawmill.
Before I remark further, I also seek leave to table certain documents relating to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd which operated the mill. I have copies with me.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in my possession the annual report for the company for the year ended 30 June--

—If I might by indulgence say to Senator O'Chee that, if he sends that material over and it is okay, then we will allow him to incorporate it at a later time. One usually clears it through a member of the front bench first.
—Order! It was to be tabled, not incorporated, is that right?
—That is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The documents I have tabled are as follows: the annual report for the year ended 30 June 1988, together with the director's report and auditor's report, which documents were filed with the Corporate Affairs Commission on 12 September 1989; the balance sheet, profit and loss account, and notes to the accounts for the year ended 30 June 1988, which documents were filed with the Corporate Affairs Commission on 12 September 1989; particulars of charge in favour of Westpac Banking Corporation created on 31 March 1987; memorandum of priority in favour of Westpac Banking Corporation granted on 29 April 1987; particulars of charge in favour of Placer Industries Ltd created on 29 April 1987; particulars of charge in favour of the Commonwealth of Australia created on 29 June 1988; notice of appointment of receiver on 20 April 1990; report as to affairs as at 20 April 1990 sworn by director, Wayne Kenneth Turl; and an assistance agreement and charge between the Commonwealth of Australia and Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, which I understand was previously tabled in Committee of the Whole on 25 May 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: These documents clearly show that prior to the signing of the assistance agreement on 29 June 1988, securities existed in favour of Westpac Banking Corporation and Placer Industries Ltd. Westpac's charge secured the borrowings of other companies in the group, and was additionally cross-collateralised over the assets. In short, the liabilities and assets of the group were as one. The Commonwealth's loan was also secured, but this ranked behind the other two and was not cross-collateralised.

From 29 June 1988 to 20 April 1990, the Government advanced $4.5m in interest free loans to the company as well as making some $3.1m in grants in accordance with clause 2 subclause 1 paragraph (b) of the assistance agreement. The accounts show that as at 30 June 1988, Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd had $6,535,719 in non-current liabilities, of which $2,335,719 was owed to other companies within the group. A further $2,040,001 was owed to secured creditors other than the Commonwealth.

As at 20 April 1990 when the company was put in receivership, $4.2m remained outstanding to the Commonwealth and $2,229,000 to Westpac. Instead of being a borrower from other companies within the group however, Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd was owed $3,024,000 by associated companies, all of which was considered irrecoverable.

This means that there was a net movement of $5,359,719 of loan funds out of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd to associated companies during that 22-month period. In addition, there was an increase in the face value of investments in companies within the group by $400,084 from $2,173,916 to $2,574,000. This latter item may be accounted for by a retention of profits but could equally have been an injection of additional capital and therefore requires further investigation.

The purpose of the assistance agreement was to retool the mill to accept pinewoods, and to provide operational subsidies to protect the jobs of 40 mill workers. In spite of this, however, the mill is in receivership and the retooling is still incomplete. In fact, the Commonwealth has recently made another grant of $500,000 to finish the job.

In the absence of contrary evidence, these facts, combined with the movements in the loan and capital accounts, lead to the distinct possibility that at least $5,359,719 and perhaps as much as $5,759,803 may have been misappropriated out of the company. I say that because large portions of this money should have remained in Ravenshoe instead of going to Sydney-at least that was the intention of the assistance agreement. When the Commonwealth's money is not spent as intended, one must suspect it has been misappropriated, either by negligence or other means.

The Government now accepts that the $4.2m in loan moneys will not be recovered. In addition, there is the $3.1m of grants to be considered too. What the Government cannot say is where that money went. As late as the 18th of last month, Senator Richardson stated before Estimates Committee C that Mrs Kelly had not ascertained what had happened to the Commonwealth's money. How could this happen? How could more than $5m disappear from a company in less than two years, right from under the Government's nose? The answer to these questions lies in the Government's loan documents and the gross ministerial and departmental negligence that accompanied their preparation.

Neither the assistance agreement nor the charge required the company to present in a timely fashion quarterly or half-yearly reports. The only such obligation was under clause 9 of the assistance agreement for the company to provide an annual balance sheet and profit and loss account as soon as they were completed. In fact, for most of the period in question, the company was substantially in default of its obligations under the Companies Code. The 1988 annual accounts were not filed with Corporate Affairs until 12 September 1989-over 14 months after year end. The 1989 annual accounts were not completed at all.

The loan documents also lacked negative covenants to prevent loans being made to associated companies without approval. Moreover, the Commonwealth failed to take securities over the assets of associated companies as other lenders did. Such terms are normal in commercial loans for large sums of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought to sit down, you will look silly tomorrow.

—I would be embarrassed too, Senator Richardson, if I were the Minister responsible. This means that the Commonwealth had no way of preventing the misuse of its $7.6m loan and grant funds, nor did it have any chance of recovering them after the act. In fact, the Government did not apparently have any idea at all what was going on. That is why, according to the company's records, the Commonwealth is owed a further $300,000 in unpaid taxes for the year ended 30 June 1989. That is also why $600,000 is owed to trade creditors.

SPEECH.PARA: I still believe that the mill at Ravenshoe is viable, even if the governmental incompetence in these loan documents does not help. I believe, however, that the time has come for the Government to make good the money owed to unsecured creditors and to come clean on details of this affair. I therefore call on Senator Richardson to explain how so much money disappeared from Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd when the Commonwealth should have been monitoring its operations. I also call for the tabling of all correspondence between the receivers and the Government regarding the mill, which I believe may disclose further irregularities in these transactions. Honourable senators, the people deserve to know the facts regarding this shameful affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with some concern to the matters raised by my colleague Senator O'Chee and would say that it all comes back to a lack of information on this item. Ever since I have been a member of this Parliament--
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Is the honourable senator--
—Senator Macdonald is speaking to the motion moved by Senator O'Chee.

—Ever since I have been elected to this chamber, I have been trying to find out some information on what happened to the $7.6m of taxpayers' money that was granted and lent to this particular mill. I have asked a number of questions, some on notice. I raised the matter with Senator Richardson in Estimates Committee C and it just seems to be impossible to get a reply from the Government as to what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: In Estimates Committee C on 18 September, Senator Richardson indicated, as did senior public servants, that they would know all when a report was received from the receiver-manager and they indicated that they expected that report in a couple of days. On 25 September 1990 in an Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) interview on the 7.30 Report the announcer indicated that he had been advised by the receiver-manager that the report had been sent to the Government some 10 days previously; that is, on 15 September. Subsequent to that, I have asked the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) whether he received the report and, if so, what was in it. If what was in it was not satisfactory to the Government, I then wanted the Minister to indicate whether he would institute a full and complete inquiry into the subject, which he did. He said that he would, in fact, have a complete inquiry if those things did not come out of the report from the receiver-manager.

The Minister indicated in answer to my question last Thursday that he would seek advice from the responsible Minister, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, as to whether that report had been received. The ABC was able to tell me and the whole of Australia on 25 September that the report went 10 days ago, but so far this Minister has not been able to obtain from Mrs Kelly whether or not that report has been received. If it has been received, why can we not be told what is in it?

All of the questions that I, Senator O'Chee and Senator Boswell have raised on this issue may well have a very simple answer. The answer may be in the reports, figures and statements of the receiver-manager, but we are never going to know that unless we find out from the Government whether it has received the report and what is in the report. If what is in the report is not sufficient for its needs, when will it conduct a full, open and frank inquiry into the advances and loans, which the Minister has indicated he will do?

I know that this is annoying Senator Richardson and that he has been fairly helpful in the past, but he could save himself, the Government and this chamber a lot of trouble if he would answer the questions, let us know whether that report has been received, and let us have a look at the report so that we can find out what has happened to $7.6m of taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 September I asked Senator Collins, as Minister responsible for the northern part of Australia, exactly the same question, when we would get the report, as have Senator Macdonald and Senator O'Chee. The advice given then was that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, wrote to the receiver-manager on 19 June. On 27 June the receiver-manager wrote to Mrs Kelly to advise her that he could not meet the requirement at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: On 18 September, both Senator Macdonald and I at Estimates Committee C put Senator Richardson and Dr Andy Turner through a fairly vigorous question time. We were told then that the receiver's report would be due in a matter of days-within a short time. I asked:
What is `shortly'? Is it a week or two weeks?

The doctor told us that it would be a `matter of days'. Last Friday Senator Macdonald again asked for a response on when the report was due. Up till this stage we have not received any response from the Government. I think that the Senate should be indebted to Senator O'Chee for his investigative abilities. He has gone back to the annual accounts, the reports of receivers and to the Corporate Affairs Commission in delving into this matter.

Senator O'Chee makes a very serious allegation. It relates to over $5m. I believe that I can establish the allocation of another $1m by Senator Richardson to the sawmill, and quite rightly so, as the Government's response in providing the 48 mill workers at Ravenshoe with a future and a living. However, that money should have been spent on that mill. Senator O'Chee's investigations point out that that money has not gone to that mill. It may have gone to other mills. It may have gone to the other sawmills owned by that company. It is a very serious allegation that we in the Senate are faced with today. Where has the money that was allocated to ensure that the Ravenshoe mill workers were to have a future and a job gone?

We have been continually seeking that information since 14 September, and even longer. No longer can we be fobbed off as this Government has been doing for four or five months. I urge Senator Richardson to make a statement today, to put the matter clearly on the table and to let the Senate and the people know where the money that was allocated to Ravenshoe has gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give an answer, at least in part, to the concerns that honourable senators have expressed. Following World Heritage listing, the Government decided that the best way to assist the Ravenshoe community was to keep that mill going, rather than close it down. Nothing that has happened subsequently would make us change our mind. Therefore, an assistance grant was negotiated by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Before that took place, there were two independent studies of the viability of a retooled sawmill. They were considered by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd and Price Waterhouse. An interdepartmental committee was established to oversee the implementation of the structural adjustment package. It determined the parameters of negotiations with the Associated Plywoods Sales (APS) sawmill, and negotiations took place. The legal agreement, which was finally signed, was prepared by the Attorney-General's Department.

The agreement contained a series of conditions. They included retooling the sawmill, maintaining a work force of at least 40 people, making good operating losses, meeting taxation and stamp duties levied on assistance, paying plantation timber royalties, using timbers only obtained from outside the World Heritage area, submitting audited balance sheets and annual reports to the Department as soon as they were completed, executing a floating charge over its assets in favour of the Commonwealth and obtaining 20 years guaranteed access to plantation timbers from the Queensland Government.

The Department's monitoring of the sawmill's operation prior to the holding company going into receivership found that all the above conditions were met. Officers of the Department's Cairns office made a number of visits to the sawmill during the period. The sawmill work force remained at over 40 all of the time and in 1990 had grown to over 50. The first loan repayment was made on time and the sawmill apparently made a small profit for the financial year ended 1989.

The holding company's first financial statement in June 1988 was completed in December 1988 and was received by the Department in June 1989, prior to making the first subsidy payment. This statement was audited by the chartered accountants Parkhills BDO, 96 Phillips Street, Parramatta. The next audited financial statement was due to be completed in December 1989 and would have been received by the Department before the second full subsidy became due.

The Department wrote to the holding company on 28 March 1990 before the holding company advised the Government that it was seeking a buyer and before receivers were appointed to the company to initiate an audit of the holding company's expenditure on the APS sawmill by the Department's accounting advisers, Price Waterhouse. However, before that review was completed, the holding company was placed in the hands of the receiver. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) wrote to that receiver-manager on 19 June and 14 September this year, seeking details of how the Commonwealth assistance had been used.

We have now received an interim report from the receiver, who is also using Price Waterhouse. This interim information has been examined by the Minister's department, which considers that the Commonwealth assistance provided to the holding company has not yet satisfactorily been accounted for. The Minister is referring the matter to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to investigate whether the Commonwealth can take legal action with respect to the moneys unaccounted for. It is not possible to release that report now, for two reasons: firstly, it is commercial-in-confidence and, secondly, I am not certain of the Commonwealth's legal actions in seeking redress. So we cannot release the report now, but I hope that we can release it at some later time. I am still not certain when we are likely to get a full report from the receiver. Until we do the Commonwealth can do nothing further.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 15 October, from Senator Coulter:

INTERJECT.PARA: `Today I propose to move that, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
(a) the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into forests;
(b) a discussion paper circulated by the Government on sustainable development; and
(c) the Government's decision to allow extensive and destructive logging in the South East forests of New South Wales,

the preemptory nature of the decision to destroy the ecological integrity of these South East forests and the hollowness of the claim that the Hawke Government has any commitment to ecologically sustainable development'.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
Having regard to:
(a) the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into forests;
(b) a discussion paper circulated by the Government on sustainable development; and
(c) the Government's decision to allow extensive and destructive logging in the South East forests of New South Wales,

The preemptory nature of the decision to destroy the ecological integrity of these South East forests and the hollowness of the claim that the Hawke Government has any commitment to ecologically sustainable development.
The crunch line in the letter to the Senate calling for this urgency debate is the last one:
. . . the hollowness of the claim that the Hawke Government has any commitment to ecologically sustainable development.

I point out that the Federal Government has stated quite clearly a commitment; indeed it has circulated a draft discussion paper on ecologically sustainable development. It has also, I believe, through the environment statement made several months ago by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), recognised that greenhouse warming is, to use the Prime Minister's words, `the most serious environmental problem facing Homo sapiens'. If greenhouse warming is not an example of the fact that our industrial development is not sustainable, surely nothing would convince anybody.

We have also seen Mr Hawke's plan to plant one billion trees. Of course, this bears very much on the other issue which is raised in our urgency motion-that is, the plan to slaughter a large part of the south-east forests of New South Wales. If I could paraphrase the biblical injunction, what does it profit a man if he plants a billion trees and at the same time he removes a billion old trees? Of course, one might be cynical enough to say that in political terms it certainly does not save his political soul.

TALK.START.PARA: —His soul-come on!

—Thank you, Senator Watson. I would have thought the links between the cutting of forests and the problem of greenhouse were absolutely plain to every person in this chamber. As we cut down these old growth forests that are in balance with the ability of the atmosphere to maintain its carbon dioxide levels we turn them-this is predominantly the case in respect of the south-eastern forests-into woodchips and paper. They are on a one-way trip to the junk heap to be burnt and to be put back into the atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide. So, there is a clear link between what the Prime Minister has recognised as the most important environmental problem facing human kind at this time and his decision to get into those forests and remove a substantial portion of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to remove these trees from the south-eastern forests in our view shows a clear lack of understanding or, indeed, any real commitment at all on the part of Mr Hawke to sustainable development. The decision has been made to satisfy very short term economic ends in a way which is quite similar to a number of other decisions which we have seen the Hawke Government make recently.
Mr Hawke, in his discussion paper on ecologically sustainable development, says this:

Resources that are free or underpriced tend to be overused and abused and environmental damage may result. Deficient pricing of natural resources is one factor contributing to Australia's problems. Changing prices is one of the more direct ways of changing patterns of resource use.

Hear, hear! We could agree with that absolutely. Let us look at the situation in relation to the pricing of the resources of the south-eastern forests. First, let us look at the question of employment. It is true that employment in the forest industry is falling. But it is equally true that the employment there is not falling as a consequence of the activities of the conservation movement or moves to protect the forests. It is falling because there has been a significant move towards greater capital intensity and less labour intensive type exploitation of the forests. It is falling also because there has been a substantial move away from sawlogging and towards the exploitation by way of chipping and pulp manufacture-something which is capital intensive and not particularly labour intensive.

Let me say that it is rather surprising at this time to hear both the Federal Government and the New South Wales Government, in this case because it was a joint announcement, expressing concern over employment. If I could pick up what the Opposition has said this weekend in connection with the insipient oil strike, Mr Howard was quite adamant that the loss of a thousand workers' jobs in that industry was part of a process of rationalising the industry, and he did not express a great deal of concern that those workers should lose their jobs in the process of rationalisation.

I also point out that the New South Wales hardwood industry in the Bega Valley in the Bombala region employs only about 6 per cent of the population in that area: 1.1 per cent in sawmills, 1.3 per cent in the chip mill, 2.3 per cent in logging and cartage, and 1.4 per cent by the Forestry Commission. A total of only 600 people are employed in that area in the forestry industry. Employment in the region, moreover, in the timber part of the industry there, remained static throughout the 1980s while overall employment in the region increased by 2.3 per cent between 1981 and 1986, which is approximately three times the rate for New South Wales as a whole. Quite clearly, there are substantial shifts in employment in the timber industry which are quite unrelated to actions to protect the forests.

Let me point out the other losses of employment which are going on in New South Wales at the present time and which are countenanced-indeed, praised, furthered and promoted-by the New South Wales Government and looked on, presumably, favourably by this Labor Government. There have been 3,300 jobs lost in education, 3,500 in the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, Elcom, 4,000 in government supply, 450 in the closure of the Homebush abattoir, 200 in the State brickworks, and another 550 in family and community services. Very significant job losses have occurred throughout New South Wales in the name of rationalising industry and production and yet when so few jobs are concerned in the forestry industry, apparently we must destroy old growth forests to provide that employment.

What other measures are available? If we look at the direct financial circumstances of the forestry industry, we note that gross royalties received by the Forestry Commission to 30 June 1990 amount to-and these figures are very instructive-$15.59 per tonne from pulp wood, with 93 tonnes per hectare being collected, which amounts to $1,449 per hectare, and $30.02 per cubic metre from saw logs, with 11 cubic metres per hectare, a total of $330 per hectare. In other words, that amounts to $1,780 in gross royalties per hectare. If we look at that on a 50-year rotation basis, that is $36 per hectare per year collected in royalties as a consequence of the exploitation of these south east forests. By any stretch of the imagination, that is a paltry sum to weigh against the destruction of these very important areas.

To place the matter in a somewhat different perspective, Mr Sid Walker of the forestry working group has placed a value of 60c per tree. That is his estimate of the value placed on each tree as a consequence of the amount of royalty being paid, and this 60c per tree has not been questioned by the Forestry Commission or by industry.

When Mr Hawke announced that he was going to plant one billion trees he suggested-rather disingenuously, I think, in the light of what happened since-that he could plant and nurture those trees for $1 a tree. The Opposition immediately said that that was a ridiculous figure and its estimate, as reported in the media, for the planting and nurturing of the trees until one could be reasonably assured that they would grow on was $11 a tree.

Let me go back to the Prime Minister's statement in his `ecologically sustainable' draft that `resources that are free or underpriced tend to be overused and abused'. Surely, if any resource is being underpriced, abused and overused, it is the south-eastern forests of New South Wales. If the Opposition is correct in its estimate, and if we are to adhere to market processes for the allocation of resources-and I certainly share with the Government and the Opposition the view that the market system is an efficient way, not always an equitable way, of allocating resources-then surely the value that should be put on a tree is, at the very least, the cost of replacement, which, according to the Opposition, is $11 a tree, and not the 60c which has been placed on these trees by way of the royalties.

Daishowa, the company which is exploiting about 80 per cent of the southern forests, is a totally foreign owned company. That fact needs to be stressed because, very often, the term Harris-Daishowa is used and the names are linked. I believe the company started with those owners, but Mr Harris, an Australian citizen, very quickly sold out and the company is now totally foreign owned. In 1987, 1988 and 1989 it made after-tax profits of 100 per cent, 93 per cent and 93 per cent respectively on investment. Those profits, of course, were immediately and totally repatriated to Japan. The profits as a percentage of before-tax sales range between 21 per cent and 26 per cent through those years, which is several times higher than the national average.

If we were to increase royalties to 50 per cent of before-tax profits, that would raise an extra $5m a year and, in three years, $15m, which is more than enough to establish the industry on a sustainable basis and provide long term security for the work force-an alternative to the very short term solution which this Government has sought.

In the Australian Democrats' alternative budget we suggested that there be a substantially larger increase in the royalties charged on chips, in line with the idea of charging the full value of these trees. We suggested that there be an additional royalty of $20 a tonne. That would raise over the whole of Australia-we are not talking only about the south-east forests here-$110 million a year. That would give a substantial sum of money which could be used to direct this industry away from its present exploitative, non-renewable practices towards those practices which would ensure sustainability in the long term.

Of course, we also need to look at the demand side of this equation, not just the supply side. When we look to see why those forests are being destroyed, we see that the products are being used for a lot of purposes for which there is really no good, substantial reason. I have here the junk mail which I collected from my letterbox in just one evening. It is material which is absolutely useless; it certainly does not advertise a single item that I would wish to buy and it simply goes straight into the waste paper bin. This is the sort of activity which this Hawke Government is defending in the light of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely the recycling bin.
—I thank Senator Baume for raising that. The Senate will notice that quite a lot of that junk mail is on glossy paper which is extremely difficult to recycle.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia imported 36 per cent of our paper and 22 per cent of its pulp in 1986-87, which cost over $1 billion. When we look at what Australia does in the form of recycling, we find that it is only recycling about 28 per cent of its pulp, whereas Japan is recycling 49 per cent and even in the Netherlands the amount is some 45 per cent. There are substantial opportunities for increasing the amount of recycling and, therefore, decreasing the demands on our forests-particularly our old and original forests which contain such a wealth of other values.

If I might return to the principal theme-putting an appropriate value on these trees would make that material, that is, the pulp and other material that we get from those virgin forests, much more expensive. This is precisely the price message that needs to be put into the market system to level the playing field so that there can be an appropriate allocation of resources. The market will do that, provided the right price mechanisms are put in. In short, Australia is currently paying Daishowa and a number of other substantially foreign companies like Daishowa simply to take our resources away. We are not being adequately recompensed for those chips.

Timber is not the only value for which we need to protect forests. The Government has continuously reduced the funding for the Australian Biological Resources Survey. One biologist to whom I spoke just the other night down at the National Science and Technology Centre said that he had made a calculation in relation to the number of species being described in Australia and the task which still lay before us. His estimate was that we would not have a complete inventory of all species, plants and animals, in Australia before the year-wait for it-3000. In other words, it will take more than 1,000 years from now, at the rate we are proceeding, to describe the biological richness that was in this country before European settlement. Of course, if we take that length of time, many of those species will long have disappeared because of the destructive practices we have adopted before we have a chance to even know what is there, and that is certainly true of the south-eastern forests.

I need only reflect briefly on the map showing the areas which the Government is seeking to protect. Any person who knows anything about biology would recognise the uselessness of those narrow strips on the map. One of the southern pieces is shaped like a three-legged spider, with the protected areas being no more than a few hundred metres wide. One leg stretches along the Princes Highway, apparently to make the roadside look attractive for those who drive along there, and the other two legs stretch up river valleys. That is absolutely useless protection in terms of other values-the species and so on-that might reside in, and might need the protection of, an intact ecosystem for their continued survival.

The growth of the old plantation timbers is now exceeding the rate of increased consumption of timber in this country. It is easy to predict that within 10 to 15 years, even with present consumption patterns, the timber needs of Australia could be supplied from those plantation sources and we would not need to go into the forests. Of course, if we were to put in place proper costings and the recycling measures to which I have referred, the apparent need to go into these forests would be seen as being without any foundation whatsoever.
In last Monday's announcement of the south-eastern forests decision the Prime Minister said:
It will provide for a more stable long-term strategy for the management of the South East Forests.
He went on:
This strategy will be finalised in consultation with the New South Wales Government by the end of the year.
The development of this long-term strategy has pre-empted the outcome of the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into forests and timber resources.

It should be remembered that the RAC is supposed to be the centrepiece of the Federal Government's processes for reconciling environmental and developmental objectives, particularly those which are particularly controversial. The forest and timber inquiry is its first, and an interim report is due early next year.

I return to the point that I made at the beginning, which is that the decision to log the south-eastern forests is poorly based, and clearly the words which the Government mouths in relation to sustainable development indicate that either the Government does not understand what it is talking about or that those words are hollow and without foundation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, as Minister responsible for the environment from 1987 to 1990, had to spend quite a deal of my time wrestling with this complex and difficult issue. As a precursor to my remarks, it is worth noting that there has been a clamour from both sides in this debate, not just about the south-eastern forests but about each and every environmental issue, that governments ought to make their decisions based on the best scientific advice available. It is pretty hard for anybody to reject that as a sensible course of action for governments now and in the future. The only problem for governments appears to be that, after they seek the best scientific advice available, whoever is aggrieved by the advice that is produced then wants to disagree with it.
