SPEECH.PARA: When the Government was dealing with Wesley Vale, that notorious mill in Tasmania, there was scientific evidence produced by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and even by the client department, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, which suggested that there were very real risks indeed in proceeding with the mill at the time, particularly if its technology were not to change. The company walked away because the Government took a decision to impose extra conditions on the basis of the scientific evidence which was produced for it. There was an example of industry walking away when it did not want to accept scientific advice. Sadly, when we look at what has happened in the south-eastern forests, we are seeing some people in the conservation movement taking a similar step.

When it comes to the calibre of scientific advice, an examination of those who were put on the committee to look at this area points to a pretty impressive list of scientific brainpower. Contrary to assertions that in some way it is a forestry plot, names such as that of Henry Nix appear on the list. There is not even a minority report from people such as that for the conservation movement to base some sort of counterargument upon. In the absence of any argument of that kind, one wonders how far the scientific argument can be taken.

To go back to the genesis of the committee itself, it came about after discussions between Senator Cook and me as to what were the Commonwealth's obligations in trying to settle the south-eastern forests logging argument. We took the decision to protect 95 per cent or whatever it was-a very high percentage-of the area while we were getting this scientific advice. There was never an undertaking to continue the protection beyond the time when that scientific advice had been produced. When it came down, I have to say, it was an even tougher proposal than that which the Cabinet finally adopted.

I do not believe that people can take all of this advice and tear it up and ignore it when it does not suit them. In the course of the next few years all of us, no matter where we stand in these debates, whether we class ourselves as green or not, will have to believe that, when experts are assembled for the purpose and learned reports are produced, we just will not have the luxury of allowing our bias to reject them when they do not suit our arguments.

It is not good enough for Senator Coulter to say that we should wait for the Resource Assessment Commission. I suppose that there is always a reason to wait-one can wait forever- but eventually governments have to make decisions. That is the task we are given by those who elect us. It is not as if there has been some tiny area reserved for future generations in the south-eastern forests. The reserve system for the south-east will conserve some 55,000 hectares through new national parks, nature reserves and flora reserves. The proposed boundaries take account of both conservation and heritage values and the needs of the timber industry. One has to look at the Commonwealth's obligation for protection of the National Estate to discover why it is that those values had to be taken into account.

I think that we should dispel the myth that in some way National Estate status means no development of any kind. Not even when that legislation had its beginnings during the Whitlam era was it ever suggested that the National Estate was untouchable, as were national parks. It was always the case, even for those who were drafting this legislation, that the Commonwealth's responsibility was to see whether there were prudent and feasible alternatives to going into the National Estate. It was never the case that the National Estate could not be touched under any circumstances.

What we have seen in the past few years is an attempt to equate National Estate with national parks. Sadly, they are just not the same. Obviously we have an absolute duty to do our best to protect the National Estate, but one wonders, having looked at all the circumstances of this debate, what more we could have done.

Further to that, we should compare what went on in the south-eastern forests here with those old growth forests of Tasmania. When it came to settling that argument there was scientific evidence about 400-year-old trees and about areas of world significance. That can be settled, if the Commonwealth has the will to do it, by listing for World Heritage. So in Tasmania there was a clamour from the environment movement for a World Heritage listing. The Commonwealth, having examined that, agreed; we went ahead. There were arguments with industry, arguments with the State government of the day in Tasmania, but we went ahead because there was sufficient evidence and the adoption by the World Heritage Committee of those boundaries suggested that the evidence was indeed there. But one does not hear the clamour from environmentalists about listing these forests for World Heritage so that the argument can be settled. The reason is that so many of these forests have been logged before. It is pretty hard to establish wilderness values, apart from a few small areas. In the case of Tasmania there were some very large areas that had not been touched. It is also always necessary to take in some areas that have been touched to provide proper buffer zones around those areas that have never been touched. The opposite applies in the south-eastern forests because logging has been going on in them for so long and most, as I have said, have been logged in the past.

Again, in looking at Senator Coulter's motion, there is at least the suggestion that in some way the concept of sustainable development has been infringed by the Government's decision. I have to reject that suggestion as well. This decision is all about sustainable development. It is all about making sure that the forests can regenerate themselves, that we will be able to see logging done again after the proper cycle has gone through.

That becomes the crux of the question. I was very critical a couple of months ago, when I was launching a book which listed some of the great areas of Australia, of those in industry-not just the timber industry; on that occasion in particular the mining industry-who were seeking to hijack the sustainable development debate, seeking to suggest that it meant an open slather for a whole raft of areas which the Government and, I think, a majority of Australians want to see protected.

On this occasion I hope that those in the environment movement, or indeed Senator Coulter, do not get to the stage of believing that some argument about sustainable development can be used for the opposite purpose; that is, to protect everyone. It has to be, by its very nature, somewhere in the middle. It has to be the case that sustainable development implies development occurring. By establishing such an extensive system of reserves in the case of the south-eastern forests, I do not think anyone can suggest that what we are about here will not be anything but sustainable development.

We are told in this motion that the fact that the Resource Assessment Commission has not yet decided is some reason for delay. But the reality is that that Commission is looking at a long term assessment. It will look at the future over the next few centuries. There is no pretence that the Resources Assessment Commission will come up with a forest by forest decision about what we ought to be doing around Australia during the next few years. The fact that there is a long term forest inquiry is a very good thing for the future of the industry and for conservation but it cannot be used as a reason for stopping decision making, either at a State or at a Federal level.

We have come a long way since the beginning of the debate. Here we are, being critical of what we have been able to protect, when only a couple of years ago we had the then State Minister, Ian Causley, absolutely anxious to take the chainsaw to every tree in the south-eastern forests. Because the Commonwealth got involved in this process, because it would not cop that sort of redneck attitude, we now have a situation where the governments can agree on the reserving of a very large section of those forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you reckon Tim Moore is a redneck?

—In answer to Senator Michael Baume-through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, because I know I am not to speak across the chamber-I do not believe that Tim Moore is a redneck; I believe that he has a genuine pro-Green feeling. I also believe that he is completely powerless within the New South Wales Government. I would like to see a bit more muscle given to his arm. If Senator Michael Baume can help in that process, I think New South Wales will be a lot better off.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing that the Commonwealth has done in the course of this debate should be seen to take away from a look at the future. The future of this industry does not simply lie in the management of old growth forests. The States and the Commonwealth must do all that they can to tease out just what we can do with plantation forestry.

I do not believe that any long term solution to the problems of balancing conservation and development in Australia can be even attempted without an acknowledgment that eucalypt plantations will play a big part in that future. The Australian Conservation Foundation has quite rightly pointed out that eucalypt plantations are an essential component of any strategy to reduce pressure on old growth forests.

I know that some sections of industry want to reject that claim. I know that some sections of industry do not want to accept that sawlogs can ever be got out of plantation forests. But again, it seems clear to me, when looking at research carried out by the CSIRO and even by some companies, especially in Tasmania, that there is a future for the industry in looking at eucalypt plantations. It would do well for everyone in industry, in the conservation movement and in government to spend a bit of time and money on that--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is where the future lies.

—I agree. They should do so so that there will be a future for everyone in the industry. From day one of the debate, at the heart of the Government's undertakings was an undertaking to try to maintain employment in those south-eastern forests. There is a very difficult decision to be made any time one gets to a forest-specific argument. Having been through the Ravenshoe debate and having seen people put out of work when they and their family predecessors have worked at a particular job, sometimes for 100 years, through generation after generation, it is pretty wrenching to say to them, `There's no longer a place for you here. You've got to go somewhere else'. It does not matter how Green one considers oneself; that kind of human concern is pretty hard to dismiss.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that many Green people are very hard on this issue. It is very easy to get up and say, `This area, that area, has to be protected; to hell with the jobs'. But when one is faced, as I was, time and again with people, quite naturally, being very angry about the prospect of their lives and the lives of their families being disrupted by a government decision on conservation, it forces one to start thinking about what really is balance in the argument. There is no balance in the argument that suggests that there is no future for forestry in the south-eastern forests.

We heard mention of Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd. We had the foreign bogy raised again. The south-eastern forests argument has never been about Harris-Daishowa; it is a sawlog driven argument. All of the arguments that we have been having over the last few years are about sawlogs keeping some small mills going; they are not about finding cannon fodder for the machinery at Daishowa's mill, because that can be found in a whole range of areas around the south-east. It has always been about sawlogs.

So let us not raise the foreign bogy. More to the point should be what the long term future of the woodchip industry is in Australia. All of us who have a belief in secondary processing of our raw materials have to understand that there cannot be endless woodchipping here; that there will come a time when we will require companies to do more with the resource than just chip it. Of course, when that time comes, there will be the argument of what kind of pulp mill to have, what kind of waste it will have and what kind of machinery it will use. I would rather face that debate than simply have sterile debates about woodchipping itself. In my view, there is no long term future in that. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, we need to be a bit smarter-the clever country will not just woodchip; it will do a lot more. So I hope that we do not have to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with Wesley Vale.

—Senator Watson says, `What about Wesley Vale?'. I have already said why the company did not get on with Wesley Vale, and that was because science was against it; there was a welter of scientific evidence against it. In the cold light of day, we really ought to acknowledge that evidence. Senator Watson will never get a Wesley Vale or any other mill built without proper studies being done beforehand. In the end, the fact that the Gray Government never had the guts to ask North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd and Noranda Forests Inc. to actually go out and do some baseline studies was the largest contributor to bringing them undone. The fact that Senator Watson would go along with it is even more appalling. Mind you, it is not surprising-we have listened to him here before.

SPEECH.PARA: But to get back to the matter-I do not want to respond to interjections all the time-it will never be possible to get decisions that satisfy everyone in this debate. As one who sat around God knows how many negotiating tables during the course of the last few years trying to get that agreement, I know that it is hard enough getting it within any political party let alone getting it with industry, conservation groups and State governments.

However, here we have made a very real attempt. By and large it has been successful. I hope that conservationists note that the industry did not just race out and say, `What a terrific agreement. You've saved all our jobs'. Far from it. It came out and said, `You've reserved too much. In reserving 11 1/2 per cent of resource, you've reserved too much'. It was angry that the Government would take such a decision. It believed that even what we did placed jobs at risk. So no-one has come out here and said, `It's a great decision'. If both the conservationists and the industry are saying that it is not such a red hot decision, maybe we have got pretty close to the right balance.

While it is not being said too much during the discussions of the last week or two, we should also note that no logging will occur anywhere in the Tantawangalo catchment area for the next four years while we get some more science, while proper hydrological studies are done. That is something that I was calling for a couple of years ago. So, there has been tremendous concessions made on the New South Wales side. The agreement that we have got here is nothing like what Minister Causley was calling for two years ago. He was removed from his portfolio and his ambit claim has been destroyed by this agreement. The truth is that the Greiner Government did move back. I do not want to criticise Mr Greiner for doing it. I want to congratulate him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell me Moore won; you are telling me that Moore won?

—What happened was that while Murray and Ian Causley cost the Opposition an election, I think that Premier Greiner did not want him to cost him one so he just had to get Causley out of the portfolio. That will not be enough to save him but at least it shows that he is not completely stupid. Anyway, I seek to defend this agreement not just because it is signed between the two governments but because it is a genuine attempt to recognise that science must play the overriding role. All of the forest types that need protection-the plant varieties-have been protected and that cannot be done unless one looks properly at the science, and we have done so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition finds this urgency motion curious but not unexpected. It seems that the odd boys out in this debate at the moment are very much the Australian Democrats. This is not because they are the only people who are genuinely concerned with the environment in this chamber but, on the contrary, they are the only people who are prepared to beat their breasts in an unrealistic and nonsensical way, pretending that trees are things that do not grow, that they are something static and that once harvested can never be replaced.

SPEECH.PARA: There was not one mention in Senator Coulter's speech of the Report of the Joint Scientific Committee entitled Biological Conservation of the South-East Forests. The facts would have interfered with Senator Coulter's speech. On the question of Senator Coulter's speech, it is worth noting that there is not one other member of the Australian Democrats supporting him by being in the Chamber listening to his speech, and listening to this allegedly important matter of urgency that the Democrats have brought before this chamber today.

I am not surprised by that because, quite frankly, the Democrats in this area have been demonstrated to be phonies and this debate is another example of that total phoneyness. For heaven's sake, here at last we have a situation where there is a prospect of that wonderful term `sustainable development' being recognised as the most important and practical response to our environmental problems. What we have in this chamber is a grandstanding act by the Australian Democrats refusing to recognise that if there can be a degree of political unanimity on this matter, we will have gone a long way to solving some very serious problems that do exist in Australia about the environment, and which for far too long have been political footballs.

Now at a time when the New South Wales coalition Government under the Liberal leader, Mr Greiner, can come to an agreement with a Labor Federal Government about sustainable development in the south-eastern forests, when in fact at last politics between the major parties are removed from that kind of issue, what do we naturally see? We naturally see the Australian Democrats like dogs sniffing around a garbage bin picking up the leftovers, and quite frankly, I suppose they have nothing else to chew on. Not that there are many of them chewing on it, because as I said, one member of the Australian Democrats is in the chamber to sustain this alleged--

TALK.START.PARA: —Two.

—At last we have another one who has come in. The honourable senator must have been listening on the radio in the comfort of her office when I made this point. But let us see what really is happening in this debate, because as the Australian noted in its editorial of 10 October:

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the motive, the coming together of Mr Hawke and Mr Greiner on the forests-
that is the south-eastern forests-

is welcomed. Now is the time for moderate greens to join them, to bring to life the ideal of sustainable development, to suggest how projects can proceed in an environmentally acceptable way-to be positive about Australia's development. That would be a green revolution.
That, of course, is the position of the Opposition. There is no doubt that as the Australian said:
A calmer environmental movement would accept the need for growth to maintain living standards and throw its efforts into ensuring projects went ahead with first-rate environmental safeguards.

That surely is what we all should be about. Let us concede that for far too long there have not been adequate environmental safeguards, and because that pendulum was so far one way, naturally it swung back too far the other way to a situation where we have people like Senator Coulter taking the view that no development is acceptable; that there should be minus population growth; and that in fact every tree apparently must remain extant-static. I think Senator Coulter might have forgotten the fact that trees actually grow. I know this is a terrible thing to intrude into this debate and it may be that it takes 50 to 100 years for some trees to grow to the sorts of sizes that may even be commercially necessary for logging purposes.

I know it is uncomfortable for Senator Coulter but I have here a scientific report which says quite clearly what the realities are about these forests. Senator Coulter says, `old-growth'. In other words, nothing could be worse than chopping down these wonderful old-growth forests for short term vulgar, commercial gain; or in fact simply to sustain living standards or to sustain any kind of economic growth in Australia. Let us read what the Joint Scientific Committee, which reported to both the State and the Federal Ministers for resources, reported so recently:
The National Estate forests in the Eden region have been described as old-growth forests, an emotive term which has considerable public appeal.

Let us recognise that obviously Senator Coulter would prefer to call them that, because he is depending in this issue on emotion and on a public appeal, because the Democrats are running out of issues. The report continues:
The forests are in fact-
contrary to what Senator Coulter was suggesting to us-

multi-aged, consisting of a main canopy of old trees infilled at intervals by other trees representing many age classes, each class having regenerated after a fire or as a result of early selective logging.

Senator Coulter apparently has forgotten about the fact that Australia is subject to bushfires. I do not know whether he is going to pass a law against bushfires or against lightning, but unless he does that, he is going to find it very difficult to sustain every `old-growth' forest area in its pristine present state. The report continues:

On a wet . . . site examined, groups of trees originated at about 40 year intervals, coinciding with roughly every second fire event. In dry . . . forest, trees originated at a average recruitment interval of 18 years, about twice the frequency of recruitment to a wet . . . site. The oldest tree recorded on the former site was estimated to have been 400 years old when cut, 210 years on the latter. We acknowledge that these very old trees are to be found within the forests but not all of the forests are made up of such trees, nor will the forests contain these same trees forever. The forest is not a static entity but a dynamic one. At any one time parts of it represent stages in the successional gradient, regenerating, developing, ageing, senescing and dying.

Trees actually die. Under the best of all possible Coulter worlds, trees would remain in their static beautiful state forever. It is simply not so. There is no doubt that chopping them down hastens that process, but the question is this: Can we come to a sustainable level of development? The answer is yes. We must not overcut our forests, but there is no merit in pretending that they should not be cut at all. What disturbs me about this debate is that anyone who takes a view contrary to the extremist position of Senator Coulter is seen and presented as someone who is running around the forests of New South Wales with a chainsaw, chopping down everything without consideration for or recognition of any other factor. That is simply nonsense.
We also hear how forestry practices that will follow will be the slaughter-that is the word Senator Coulter used-of large parts of the south-eastern forest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been to the area, Senator?

—Yes, I have been there. I have had a good look. That is why I am talking with some knowledge of the area and some knowledge of the facts. It is a pity that Senator Coulter did not address himself to the scientific material that is available and which he studiously avoided in presenting this debate. I would have thought that something that regenerates was not being slaughtered; it was being farmed. I wonder whether every time Senator Coulter sees a harvester cutting through a wheat field he describes it as the slaughter of the wheat. It is the same kind of emotional claptrap which we expect from the Democrats and which we get consistently. As for this stuff about how it will destroy the fauna as well, I will read out some more of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible to harvest the forest and maintain an appropriate age series and canopy structure so that conservation values of the forest will not be impaired.
That is the rational, sensible, middle course. It is a course which Senator Coulter could not recognise if he bumped into it. The report continues:

At each successive harvesting the conservation values of the harvested area will be altered: some organisms will be disadvantaged for varying periods of time, some will be benefited, but none will be lost.
As the report says elsewhere, forests are continually changing. It continues:

There is no scientific evidence to support a contention that the sequence of management practices now being employed in the area will result in the extinction of any organism, either plant or animal. Many will be reduced in numbers, but none will be rendered extinct at either the local, regional or national level as a result of carefully controlled forest harvesting operations where conservation is one of the objectives of forest management.

Here is a rational approach to the irrational statements that have been coming from the Australian Democrats. What we have to recognise is that in effect in many of the older growth forests there are relatively small volumes of sawlogs available due to the high proportion of mature and overmature or senescent trees, the relatively few merchantable stems and the low level of utilisation relative to total wood yield. The Eden native forest management area is no exception. So we are not going to see a massive destruction of those areas. There is no doubt that a reasonable reading of this report shows that it is quite possible to have rational, coherent and relevant conservation policies while at the same time allowing for a reasonable level of farming of trees.

It is not just me, the Government or Mr Greiner in New South Wales making those points. In fact, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) has looked at the matter in some detail. Earlier this month at a luncheon at the National Press Club, I think, Dr Stocker of the CSIRO announced details of a forest management plan which could boost Australia's timber exports while preserving more native trees. He said that it was commercially practical to gently thin out young trees at different stages of growth from eucalypt forests. This technique would increase production by up to 60 per cent, according to a five-year young eucalypt program of research by the CSIRO in collaboration with industry and the Victorian and Tasmanian governments. Thinning provides a third way of forest management which could help break the impasse between environmentalists and industry.

Dr Stocker said that trees could be produced in 50 years which would normally have taken 80 years to grow in a natural regrowth forest. As an added bonus, the young trees older than about 18 years would be an excellent source of pulp wood. Research has estimated that there would be about 300,000 hectares of regrowth forest in Australia suitable for thinning. 'If we could identify 800,000 hectares of regrowth forest, we estimate we could meet the projected needs of Australia's pulp and paper industries by 2030', said Dr Stocker. Let us see what the Australian Democrats' view really is. It is an anti-growth view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am one of the few senators, I believe, who have actually visited the Tantawangalo and Coolangubra forests, although Senator Michael Baume has just said that he has been there too. I know that several Australian Democrats have also been there. There is no doubt in my mind that the areas we are debating today hold enormous significance in environmental terms. These forests are strikingly beautiful places. They include substantial areas of largely undisturbed old growth forest and habitats for many rare and endangered plants and animals, including the long-footed potoroo, which is one of Australia's rarest mammals.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the significance of the south-east is also connected to the wide variety of virtually intact ecosystems found over areas that will now no longer be viable. This decision will mean their effective destruction. We are not talking about the possibility of extinction here; we are talking about a definite outcome. This decision will mean the extinction of some species.

It is interesting to note that in their 1988 survey of the Bega district, for instance, ecologists Lunney and Leary found that the numbers of large and medium sized mammal species dropped sharply after 1910 due to land clearing in the Bega Valley. Six species of native mammals are already in danger of extinction while many others have become dangerously rare. Some of the wildlife, such as koalas, were almost eliminated in the Bega Valley by the removal of nutrient rich species of eucalypt.

These forests were not originally the prime possum and glider habitats in New South Wales, but they now form a major refuge for this animal group. Increased logging of these forests will reduce their habitat further. We must understand that the issue of wildlife conservation is integral to the areas of habitats which are now threatened by this logging decision. These areas of unlogged forest are essential for ensuring that viable populations of wildlife are maintained in the region.

In 1987, the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service, in a report it prepared for the New South Wales State Government, estimated that, even then, the areas of high nature conservation value left in the State had been hugely diminished due to logging. That report cited that of 27 rare or threatened plant species in the south-east, only eight have been adequately conserved on a national scale. Already at that stage-and this was three years ago-nine of those species were endangered. The report also commented on the impact of woodchip operations on the wildlife. I quote from the report:

The extensive study of mammal fauna undertaken by the National Parks and Wildlife Service in 1979-84 reached the conclusion that logging operations are having a significant impact on the forest fauna. For those species dependent on mature unlogged forest there will be only a small and fragmented area of suitable habitat after logging. At this point there will be an increased likelihood of local extinction of these vulnerable species.

Two hundred years ago forests covered more than a quarter of Australia's land surface. Eighty per cent of that forest has now been destroyed. In the last couple of years, however, I have been encouraged to believe that we in this chamber seem to be starting to get the same feeling for the land that Aboriginal Australians have had for thousands of years. But we are now faced with a decision which means that about half these National Estate forests will be logged.

Both the Federal and New South Wales governments have chosen to ignore a strong body of independent scientific evidence which suggests that logging these areas will cause irreparable damage. Both the Federal and New South Wales governments have chosen to ignore a strong body of community feeling that National Estate forests should be protected. This recommendation of the Federal and New South Wales governments was based almost exclusively on the report produced by the Joint Scientific Committee. The findings and recommendations of this report really do not deserve the prominence and reverence that they have been given by this Government and the New South Wales Government.

To begin with, five of the six members of the Committee were foresters, and three were employed by the New South Wales Forestry Commission. No-one disputes that the Committee should have had foresters in its membership, but it should be obvious what bias was built into the policy making process even before the recommendations had been drawn up. It is not just the Australian Democrats who believe that any committee which is top heavy with foresters is obviously going to produce a report in favour of logging.
The Federal Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, when commenting on the Joint Scientific Committee report in December last year, stated:

It is highly unlikely that the findings of the final report can arrive at a conclusion other than that which supports the claim that forestry operations and conservation are compatible-a finding at odds with most of the literature on the subject.

Many scientists and academics have found grave flaws in the report. Dr Hugh Possingham, a prominent and well-respected scientific academic at the Research School of Biological Sciences at the Australian National University, directly contradicted the Joint Scientific Committee conclusion that there was no evidence to suggest that species extinctions would occur because of forestry practices. A recent report by the Department of Ecosystem Management at the University of New England warned that logging in the south-eastern forests would increase the probability of extinction of some species.

The number of mammal species which have become extinct over the last 200 years in this country is more than in any other continent in the world. The decision to log almost half of this National Estate area is obviously an appalling act of environmental vandalism. To protect our critically endangered species, we should be preserving as much as possible of our remaining natural ecosystems, not destroying them.

The claim that logging can be carried out in a manner which maintains biological diversity has not been independently tested. Logging has an immediate effect on all the surrounding flora and fauna. Some species will almost certainly become extinct, and the range and abundance of some species, particularly tree dwellers, will be severely affected.

The Australian Democrats, and groups such as the Australian Conservation Foundation, have been arguing for years that it is possible to have a viable and responsible forest industry strategy involving the establishment of, for instance, sufficient eucalypt plantations on previously cleared land to supply all expected local hard wood needs with no logging of native forests except for small volumes of very high quality saw and specialty logs for some high value added manufacturing.

This could have been the strategy taken with the south-eastern forests. All three National Estate areas could have been declared national parks and at the same time sufficient plantations could have been established to produce an equal amount of timber from new plantations. There are already significant areas of existing cleared land with suitable soil, adequate rainfall and topography where the development of plantations that will produce pulp wood is technically feasible and likely to be economically viable. Seven hundred hectares planted each year for 20 years and managed on a 20 year rotation would yield 280,000 cubic metres of pulp wood per annum which is more than sufficient to replace the volumes that would be preserved in the south-eastern forests.

I am offering these proposals because the Democrats and other responsible conservation groups in our society genuinely believe that there is a way to preserve our National Estate and ensure that the forest industries, which are so important to the country, will continue. I am well aware of the argument that if we halt logging in the National Estate now, where will our timber requirements come from in the interim? To begin with, I believe that most of Australia's bulk hard wood timber needs can be met, as I have already said, by establishing eucalypt plantations on currently cleared land. While plantations are maturing, timber needs can be met from existing but lower conservation value forests. We cannot dismiss this lightly.

It is now well established that plantations in Australia are of increasing importance to the forest industry. After the plantations mature in 20 to 30 years, clear-felling can be phased out of the lower conservation value native forests and replaced with long rotation selective logging for high value saw logs as required. Meanwhile the forest industries have admitted that there is much that they could do to improve the efficiency of their operations.

Recent reports, for instance, estimate that improved utilisation of logging waste could produce an additional 2.24 million tonnes alone and create additional jobs in the industry at the same time. Such an approach carries an enormous number of benefits and very few costs. By using plantations, the timber industry will benefit from higher growth rates and lower logging costs. Environmental benefits would include reduced native forest logging, improved land productivity and water quality, and reduced soil erosion.

Another factor which tilts the economic balance in favour of plantations is the higher value which is given to pulp wood obtained from plantations over native forest supplies. Hard wood plantations based on forestry would benefit timber production economics in a number of other ways as well. Growth rates are up to three times those of the native forests, logging and transportation costs are reduced, and processing costs are reduced because of the greater uniformity of quality obtained from plantations. The capacity to breed and select the most appropriate timbers also has the potential to increase growth rates-a factor which is understandably important to the industry.

Obviously the environmental benefits of using plantations are enormous and include things such as a reduction in erosion and salinity problems, as well as improved water quality, wildlife conservation and land values, to mention just a few. I am trying to show that it is not very difficult to map out a strategy which would not only help to preserve a significant and rapidly dwindling wilderness of Australia's native forests, but which also makes good economic sense.

There is enormous community opposition to logging in our National Estate forests. Even the leader of the Labor Party Opposition in New South Wales, Mr Bob Carr, is publicly on record as supporting the Democrats' position not to log the National Estate forests. His statement last Tuesday probably summed up the feelings of most conservationists when he said:

To think of this area being logged, as this decision allows, is tragic. Here was a decision to make a really bold, visionary conservation decision-there's no vision in what has been decided. I really think politicians in 1990 ought to be thinking not just of the next election . . .

Many New South Welshmen will remember that it was under the previous Labor Government in New South Wales, of which Mr Carr was the Minister for Planning and Environment, that a promise was made to declare these forests as national parks.

The Democrats believe that these three areas of National Estate forests are some of the most significant parts of the natural heritage in my own State of New South Wales. I believe their preservation is a matter of urgency and I urge the Senate to vote in favour of the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No constellation of issues results in a greater series of dilemmas for governments in Australia at a State and Federal level and internationally than those that are grouped under the broad heading of `environment'. I think that is appropriate, given the significance of the decisions that are being taken and that need to be taken for current and future generations and the ramifications of those decisions not only on a national scale, but also on a global scale.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a greater understanding of interrelationships, though that understanding does not necessarily seem to have taken hold in all parts of the political process. In broad terms there is a far greater understanding of the interrelationship between economic growth and environmental protection than there was just a few years ago. That is evident in the contributions that are being made to debates on environmental issues, such as the sensitive issue of the south-eastern forests of New South Wales.

Looking directly at the proposition before the Senate this afternoon, as moved by Senator Coulter, it apparently seeks to cry `hold' to the decision-making process while further attacking the Labor Government for the determinations that were announced just recently by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premier of New South Wales.

Unfortunately, the proposition lacks clarity. I am obliged to say that it apparently seeks to cry, `Hold'. The proposition also offers no alternative. Beyond that, the proposition is flawed. It is flawed because it is simply assertive, rather than analytical in the terms in which it approaches the issue. If I am being unfair, I suggest that it is the language that suggests that, if not the intent. To date, the Senate has heard from those who support the proposition no alternative strategy. None has been advanced. No realistic alternative approach has been outlined and no practical solution to the dilemmas about the south-eastern forests of New South Wales has been defined or held up on offer. All we have, by way of the alternative proposition, is a deferral.

As everyone in the chamber knows, there are economic consequences to decisions taken on environmental protection and conservation generally. Often, there is the tragedy of unemployment, some of which is long term. That hits hard the people who very often have the least capacity to resist change in that they possess the fewest skills. Decisions can also result in the dislocation of families, the disruption of communities and the destabilisation of entire regions. We need to be very careful in weighing up the decisions well before they are taken. That has certainly been the case here. The process has been exhaustive. The economic consequences of decisions such as those on the south-eastern forests cannot be ignored by the Senate in debating the proposition this afternoon, and they have not been ignored by the Government in taking the decision that has been announced in cooperation with the New South Wales Government.

There are political as well as economic consequences. The consequences of making the wrong political decisions on the environment are perhaps best demonstrated by the defeat of Senator Chris Puplick at the last general election held on 24 March 1990. To his credit, Senator Puplick had endeavoured to bring an environmental conscience to bear upon the Liberal Party of Australia. For his pains, he was punished by his internal adversaries, relegated and defeated, rejected by the Liberal Party, which sought in turn to return to irrelevance in the environmental debate.

Another political consequence of this decision, however, is something that is of immediate relevance-that is, to confirm that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Ros Kelly, has been both accomplished and capable in her portfolio. There can be no doubt of that for the future, given the magnitude of the decision taken. There is no doubt about the quality of the decision making of this Government, the quality of debate in the Cabinet and beyond, not only as seen in the decision on the south-eastern forests but also taken in the context of its being a week or so away from the greenhouse gases decision. To achieve a decision with the conservative government of New South Wales on this issue is no mean feat, particularly given the history of environmental decisions in New South Wales since March 1988 and the defeat of the Labor Government there.

The decision also took a degree of courage that has not been acknowledged, as seen in the context of the reaction and the responses from some industry groups, to a lesser extent from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and from some of the conservative groups. This decision required courage and resolution and it has required a degree of resilience in the political process subsequently.

Earlier this afternoon Senator Richardson said that Federal pressure from the Labor Government has caused the Greiner-Murray Government to change course on this issue and to change course dramatically. The philosophy of `rip it out and tear it down', on which the Greiner-Murray Government was elected in New South Wales, could not be sustained. While we are talking about environmentally sustainable decisions, environmentally sustainable process, it is interesting to note that that philosophy of `reduce it to rubble or to chips' has not proved politically sustainable either in the State context or nationally. Things have changed to an extent in Macquarie Street. A chill wind of electoral as well as economic reality has registered.

I think Senator Michael Baume referred to the Democrats in this debate as being the odd man out. Given Senator Bourne's original contribution and her analysis of the election of Democrat senators, I thought that was singularly inappropriate and inaccurate. I prefer to think of the Democrats as seeking to carve out for themselves a position in Australian politics as being a fourth faction of the Australian Labor Party, some group off to the left of the Labor Government.

At the moment the debate is about the environmental agenda, about relations with the green constituency, which has developed an affinity with this Government and has been and remains close to the Labor Party in a primary sense in decision making. It is about political support. Political support, votes, polls and relationships are insufficient elements in Australian government. There is a bipartisanship here that is important in what has been reached with the New South Wales Government. It has been a bipartisan decision and in many respects that is the way it ought to be.

A few points need to be made about the Government's approach in the broad on this decision and related environmental decisions. It is undeniable that this Government has taken decisions on merit and has made decisions accordingly. There has been balance overall and the right decisions have been made. The decisions on Kakadu, the Franklin, Wesley Vale, the Tasmanian forests, the wet tropics, the ozone and the Antarctic, in my view-and I think in the view of a broad majority of Australians-are all sensible, realistic and sound decisions. When Senator Richardson was Minister for the Environment, decisions were not considered easy; they are not easy now. The only way to gain environmental protection was to fight a battle. The battle is being fought and has been fought by this Government. A lot of nonsense has been talked about how the Labor Government has become less green.

The decision on the south-eastern forests was always going to be difficult. It is understandable why some people in the green movement did not applaud the determination. Some wanted more of the forests to be saved. If any proof was needed that the Labor Government deals with issue according to merit, it was given last week when it looked at the determination of the south-eastern forests and the greenhouse effects in the same week: one decision was considered a soft green decision; the other a deep green decision. As the Prime Minister said a few days ago, `We make decisions on their merits. We have done this and we will continue to'. It is obvious from watching the debate taking place throughout the community that the official Opposition has simply staked out a claim of irrelevance, of playing no part, of vacillating and procrastinating.

The details of the Government's decision are worthy of a brief outline to the Senate. A system of new reserves is to be established in the south-eastern region, containing about 55,000 hectares. The boundaries have been drawn taking into account both conservation and resource considerations. It will conserve about 60 per cent of the three national estate places involved in the recent dispute. It will draw about 11 1/2 per cent of the timber resource currently available to the industry.

The Commonwealth has made it clear that it will cooperate with all bodies involved to achieve measures, such as resource supplementation through plantations, industry development through improved resource utilisation and value adding, further biological research, and management of the new parks and reserves. Overall it might be said without fear of contradiction that these measures and the reservation system will provide a more stable long term strategy for the management of the south-eastern forests. All of this is to be finalised by the end of the year. That is no mean achievement at all.

A brief word must also be said about the reactions to the decision, both for and against. The New South Wales Forest Products Association Ltd can be numbered amongst those who have welcomed the decision. That Association notes that it will be an opportunity for the forest industry and the environment movement to settle differences over the south-eastern forests.

It notes also that there was a necessity for compromise and balance. It notes also that a cooperative approach has been achieved at long last-with Ian Causley thankfully rendered inoperative-between the relevant Ministers. Most importantly, the decision will end the resource uncertainty for industry in the region.

Of course, that is not the view taken by Dr Robert Bain, on behalf of the National Association of Forest Industries, who was very critical of the Government, in some respects representing the alternative poll of opinion to that which has been advanced in Senator Coulter's proposition this afternoon. Dr Bain argued, for example, that far more was given to the conservationists than to the forest industry in terms of the decision, claiming that it would halt timber production in 75 per cent of the National Estate in the area, with a resultant loss of jobs and the like, and arguing also that the agreement would not help industry to process its resources.

There is simply not one side of an argument here; there is another side to the coin. There was enormous pressure on the Government in terms of the decision that had to be taken. The decision on the south-eastern forests, taken with the Government of New South Wales, was based on a thorough scientific study of the biological values of the forests involved. It does mean that about 60 per cent of the National Estate forests will be protected.

The decision is also part of a very detailed industry restructuring package which will be based on such things as sustainability and value-adding. I might say on that score, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that is one thing that many conservationists have rightly been saying is necessary if we are to properly use our resources overall as Australians. Many people in the broad community and the conservation movement and beyond recognise and acknowledge that this Labor Government has an environmental record second to none.

In terms of the national interest, this was a balanced and fair decision. It sent a signal about Government priorities. It sets the basis for a policy of environmentally sustainable growth, and that is the policy being pursued effectively by this Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our colleague in the Senate from the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, has put forward as a matter of urgency-which I do not believe, in light of the debate we have heard today, that he can really sustain-the peremptory nature of the decision to destroy the ecological integrity of the south-eastern forests and the hollowness of the claim that the Hawke Government has any commitment to ecologically sustainable development. Again, we are seeing a situation where the conservation movement is complaining because its leaders did not get everything that they actually wanted, despite the loss of over 100 jobs a sawmill and an agreement which goes well beyond the recommendations of the Joint Scientific Committee report.

SPEECH.PARA: In politics, timing is important. I believe that, in addition to all the significant problems that are facing Australia today-which include an oil strike, a wool crisis, balance of payments problems, high interest rates, business failures, bankruptcy, and declining standards of living-the Democrats wish to perpetuate this debate in relation to forestry. Secondly, if I may, I take issue with Senator Coulter on the relativities. I think it is well known that the growing of young trees tends to solve this problem much more satisfactorily than the preservation of older ones.

I would like to put things into perspective with regard to the Government's decision-in Senator Coulter's words-`to allow extensive and destructive logging in the south-east forests of New South Wales'. Over more recent times the focus of the forestry debate has moved from the Tasmanian forests to the south-eastern forests of New South Wales. Whilst the concentration was on Tasmanian forests, I remind the Senate, the Commonwealth Government was responsible for adding a further 600,000 acres of Tasmania to the World Heritage Register. This additional amount, together with other forest areas and forest reserves, et cetera, takes to 25 per cent the amount of land which is locked up in World Heritage, national parks and other Crown reserves and is thus unavailable for commercial use. Now the attention has swung to the south-eastern forests and pressure is being applied by members of the conservation movement for the locking up of National Estate areas, in particular, within that area.

The Government made a decision last week to allow logging to continue in certain parts of the south-eastern forests while other parts were conserved or, if you like, preserved. The decision, on the one hand, allows logging in 40 per cent of the three most contentious areas of the National Estate in the south-eastern forests-Coolangubra, Tantawangalo and Yowaka. On the other hand, a larger proportion of the three national estate areas-60 per cent-is to be conserved.

I trust that my colleague Senator Coulter is not of the mistaken belief, as are many conservationists, that in locking up an area from logging it will remain unchanged forever. A forest can never be preserved. A forest is extremely dynamic and ever-changing, and that is why it is such a tremendously renewable resource.

For example, a myrtle-dominated forest which is preserved through its inclusion in the World Heritage, national estate or other listing will revert to a eucalyptus forest should a wildfire raze it. Even without wildfire, over time the forest will die and will be replaced by eucalypt species as the forest canopy opens to allow the sunlight into the forest floor.

That a forest should be conserved because it is registered as National Estate is also of questionable logic. One of Tasmania's National Estate areas which received national press in recent times was Jackeys Marsh. A handful or so of residents in Jackeys Marsh did not want the State forest around the logging area. Even after the State's forestry service, the Forestry Commission, had spent many hours with the residents altering the road access to divert it from housing and changing the logging coupes so that they were not visible from residents' homes, the objection still stood. The area was nominated for National Estate and placed very promptly on the National Estate interim list. There were numerous species listed as rare and endangered in an attempt to justify the Jackeys Marsh nomination-all of which, it has since proven, are neither rare nor endangered. In fact, for one species there was strong evidence of its succession and proliferation being assured by the logging and regenerative processes.

The other thing about Jackeys Marsh is that the forest, a eucalypt forest, has been cut over for sawlogs for many years and, I might add, is still being cut over by the locals for fence posts. All that remains are gnarled, twisted old eucalypt trees-a pure pulpwood forest which would only be used commercially as woodchip. The forest is not a particularly good example of a forest type and thus begs the question as to why it was consigned for National Estate nomination in the first place and subsequently registered.

While I admit that I am not as familiar as some of my other colleagues with the south-eastern forest areas, I will not pass comment on their worthiness or otherwise for inclusion in the National Estate and whether their National Estate values would be threatened by logging in the area. But the point that I am leading to is that I wish to inform the Senate that the Resource Assessment Commission was told in its public hearing in Hobart on 5= October 1990 by Mr Geoff Law, a spokesman of the Tasmanian Conservation Trust, that the use of National Estate listing by the conservation movement has been a calculated ploy to further its cause to cease logging in native forests.

This must throw doubt on the validity of the whole National Estate processes, including the Australian Heritage Commission, which, as the Australian editorial put it, plays a game of claiming to be merely advisory when it suits it and of being avowedly conservationist when it suits.

No doubt Senator Coulter is quite hyped up at the moment on his topic of forest conservation, having entertained tribal leaders from Sarawak who spoke about the devastation of their rainforest. And from my personal on-site inspection in both of those countries, I must say that I share his concern about Thailand and Malaysia because they lack proper logging and regeneration practices. But unlike Sarawak, what Senator Coulter and others of like mind need to understand is that here in Australia the majority of those who plan logging coupes, supervise those logging coupes and regenerate those coupes after logging, have undergone four years of tertiary education. They have an educated and scientific basis to every decision that they make. Theirs is not the rape and pillage mentality which I regret is rife in some other parts of the world. The standards overseas are not the same as the standards here at home.

This is borne out by the comments made by the World Bank when the Wesley Vale mill did not eventuate. In fact, the World Bank expressed its regret at the cancellation of the Wesley Vale project on the basis that if the supply of bleached kraft pulp was not met from Wesley Vale, it meant that the mill would be built somewhere else in the world, probably a developing country-a country in which the environmental control standards do not come anywhere near those in Australia.

So the forests of the south-east are not about to be invaded by a bunch of gung-ho cowboy equivalents with their Cats and D9s. Australia's forests which are utilised by the timber industry are managed by professionals. This is the point that I want to make. In many instances it is these professionals and the research departments attached to the forest companies which make the scientific advancements in the industry-for example, the introduction of machinery to minimise soil erosion and the best methods of regenerating the logged coupes.

Australia's forest industry companies do not go in and rape, pillage and run. They take a long term view in planning their operations. The time frame forestry employees think of is between 20 to 80 years. Those working in research today certainly do not expect to see the results of their research in their working lifetime.

Tasmania has been fighting the forest resource utilisation-forest conservation battle for almost a decade now. In that time there have been something like 10 inquiries, all of which have handed down decisions in favour of the industry. The latest in the long line of reports and inquiries has been the Salamanca agreement, which led to the forest and the forest industries strategy. The difference with regards to this strategy from any other inquiry was that all the players in the forestry industry in Tasmania, along with their adversaries, came together over a 12-month period to put that strategy together. The sawloggers, the woodchip companies, the environmental groups and the Government agreed to sit down and, with the Federal Government's financial support for the process, to try and work out a strategy.

The idea was that each would put the particular issues on the table and work out where the compromises needed to be made to try to develop an industry that had some certainty about it for investment purposes and also gave relevant value to conservation issues. So at the end of the day we got the magic phrase that so many of us like to use, `sustainable development'-developing such things as private forestry, utilising properly State forests, and looking at all the different methods of logging and so on. All the parties which have been involved in this process over the 12 months signed the strategy, except the combined environmental groups which represented the Australian Wilderness Society, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Tasmanian Conservation Trust.

The strategy sets out certain areas to be locked up and certain areas to be made available on a long term basis to the forest industries for commercial use. When it came to the crunch the environmental groups were unable to sign the strategy. Their reason for not signing was foremost that the strategy included the logging of some National Estate areas.

I wish to make two points from the Tasmanian forest and forest industry strategy. Firstly, the process which arose out of the Salamanca agreement was the first attempt at bringing all the parties to the table and undertaking a process of discussion, information sharing and compromise. This process had the financial backing of the Federal Government. While it may seem like a good idea for the Federal Government to finally get the forestry issue sorted out in Tasmania, let me tell the Senate that the people of Tasmania have viewed the Federal Government as enemy No. 1 on forestry issues over recent years.

People have lost count of the number of times that the State Government has made a decision with regard to the forestry industry only to have that decision overturned by the Federal Government. Even today in this chamber, despite the signing of an agreement by the industry and the various unions and endorsed by the Tasmanian Government, we could not get a clear undertaking from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, that the Federal Government would not intervene.

For a change, we do have a Federal Government that is showing signs of cooperating with State governments in these matters. Likewise, on the matter of the south-east forests of New South Wales, the decision as to the areas to be conserved and the areas to be made available to the logging industry was made in conjunction with the State Government. I believe that this State-Federal government cooperation on forestry matters is to be applauded. It augurs well for the creating of a secure environment for investment in the forest industry over the coming years. Such investment, particularly in the pulp and paper manufacturing sector, is necessary if we are to reverse our current economic trends.

The second point is that the move to a Salamanca-type approach to forests can be viewed as a very serious move by the Federal Government to take the forests out of the political arena and put them back into the realm of scientific and rational debate. We welcome that. However, as with Tasmania's forest and forest industry strategy, where a combined environmental group could not sign the final strategy because it went against the basic philosophies of the groups it represented-no logging in National Estate and no logging in native forest-I will be highly surprised if agreement can be reached on the definition of `sustainable development'. To the groups at different ends of the spectrum, sustainable development does mean different things. Unfortunately we cannot support this urgency motion today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past few weeks we have seen a spate of newspaper articles saying that the greens are over the hill and that now Australia must give priority to economic realities. These are the people who are trying to distance themselves from the result of the Federal election in March. I would define it as a polite way of saying that the Government is giving in to the demands of industry and mining interests. This contrasts curiously with the findings of Simon Balderstone whose report, not fully published yet, indicates that green preferences indisputably helped Labor get across the line in 10 key seats in the March election.

SPEECH.PARA: With the Australian Labor Party holding a parliamentary majority of eight, that could have meant the difference between government and opposition. Three of those 10 seats were in my home State of Western Australia. If honourable senators had asked any of the House of Representatives members of the Labor Party on election night how they felt about green preferences, I am sure there would have been a ringing endorsement of the fact that most green preferences were going in their direction and they certainly made the difference.

What this Government has to realise is that those people who voted green and then gave their preferences to Labor, did not do so in order to see the kind of policies put into place that we are talking about here this afternoon. Nor do we look forward to a mining go-ahead in Kakadu to satisfy the economic rationalists. There are a whole lot of other issues that could be included in this debate, where the Government made promises during the election which seem now to be fading fast.

I am glad to see that the decision made last week on the greenhouse limits went some way to meeting the demands of the environment movement. Although it was disappointing that it was not 20 per cent of carbon dioxide gases alone, it included the other greenhouse gases as well. However, it was some return to sense on the part of the Government that it did not turn totally away from the hard decisions that have to be made in favour of the environment.

A classic example of this rush away from sustainable development pertains to the south-eastern forests of New South Wales, although I would add that it also applies to the forests of East Gippsland and to Western Australia-a situation I intend to refer to in a few minutes.

The decision that is being made about the future of the south-eastern forests of New South Wales is a long term decision. The Government did not need to make it now. The timber industry had between six months and two years timber in reserves outside of essentially undisturbed forest, that is, most of the National Estate and all of the high conservation value areas. The conservation movement and even parts of the Federal Government have tried to find out from the Forestry Commission where the timber reserves are, but it refuses to divulge the information. Apparently we just have to take the Forestry Commission's word for it. It is this kind of secrecy and evasion which is so frustrating in terms of trying to reach an agreement for a long term strategy for the forests.

It is criminally irresponsible to make these kinds of long term decisions about the forests when we are denied important information that will allow us to dialogue effectively and offer an informed critique of the arguments put forward by the Government of New South Wales and the big timber interests. This Government has made a decision to circumvent the Resource Assessment Commission and to give in to the timber industry in advance of any long term strategy that may come out of the RAC. As Senator Coulter has said, it is a peremptory decision and it did not need to be made now. Essentially, therefore, the Government has given in to the logging protests, and I presume that any future waivering will result in another blockade until Cabinet backs down again. The loggers talk about resource security, but I want to question their definition. After all, loggers have had resource security for many years and what we have seen is a winding down of jobs, some 20,000 or so jobs in the last 20 years. At the present rate of forest destruction, the Nimmitabel sawmill, for example, will not be around in 10 years unless there is a long term strategy drawn up for the region. The Greens did not cause this; it was the timber industry and the nature of the timber trade. Targeting the Greens is going way off course and blaming the wrong people for the loss of jobs in the timber industry.

Harris Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd, a totally foreign owned company despite the name, is well known for greedily taking out profits as fast as it can. We have already been given the relevant figures by Senator Coulter, so there is no need for me to repeat them. What the Government should have done before giving Harris Daishowa undertakings on future resource allocations is to have demanded a proper strategy for renewable resources for the future.

As for the concern of the Government of New South Wales where jobs are concerned, its hypocrisy is breathtaking. This is the Government which is trying to cut back on 30,000 jobs in the State, mostly in the Public Service, many of them in rural areas, providing vital community services such as schools, health care and infrastructure. Why should it show so much concern for around 600 jobs when there are only 10 years of forest left anyway? As the Wilderness Society has asked: How does the Government reconcile job losses elsewhere in the economy, which are explained as the product of industry rationalisation, when it is not prepared to address such rationalisation in an industry which, of its own accord, admits that it is not sustainable?

As for the timber industry, it cannot have it both ways. On the one hand it wants free markets but on the other hand it wants, in effect, a sheltered workshop where it can knock down all the trees as fast as it wants. In fact, the conservation movement has repeatedly spoken out in favour of a long term strategy for the forests which guarantees job security. There have been repeated proposals for the creation of tree plantations which would guarantee supplies into the long term future.

Where, though, is the security for national parks? They are not going to be managed properly. They do not have ecological integrity. They do not have long term security. We have now missed the chance to have one great escarpment forest stretching down to the Victorian border and beyond. Coolangubra is in effect being demolished. I am seriously led to question this Government's commitment to ecologically sustainable development. I quote from a document put out by Australia's leading environment groups, the Australian Conservation Foundation, Greenpeace Australia, the Wilderness Society and the World Wide Fund for Nature:

Ecologically sustainable development has, as its foundation, the limits set by the earth's biological process. An appreciation of the overall imperative of ecological sustainability can only be gained through an understanding of the state of the global environment.
The overall picture of the global and Australian environments is one of continuing decline. Loss of biological diversity and the degradation of natural systems are accelerating.

This particular section goes on to point out that Australia is classified as one of the seven most important mega-diverse areas on earth. Yet the rate of species loss in Australia over the past 200 years has been extraordinary, as Senator Bourne pointed out earlier on in this debate. Here in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales we have a situation where a choice could be made for the future, and the Government has chosen to follow its old discredited path. A recent good example of what I am talking about is the destruction of Devils Creek koala habitat, where the Forestry Commission has failed to honour a promise to carry out further koala habitat survey work in conjunction with the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Instead, it has begun roading activities which pose a major threat to this most significant koala habitat.

The koala faces regional extinction in the very near future. In this context, it might be useful to remember a little of the extermination process which this animal has experienced. Koalas were once so numerous in the Bega Valley that one resident could write, `When I was a boy in Bega...almost every tree had its bear'. Today, the only surviving wild koalas reside in the State forests of the area. It is highly likely that the logging and roading activities of the Forestry Commission in the Devils Creek catchment area are a significant contribution to the final chapter of the extinction of the animal in this region, despite what Senator Michael Baume has said this afternoon about no species being threatened with local or national extinction.

Over the past 20 years, there have been koala sightings in this area and the regional and district foresters of Eden must be aware that the major threat to the koala is the destruction and fragmentation of habitat. The failure of the Forestry Commission to honour its promise to carry out further survey work is just one more example of the secrecy, deceit and destructive arrogance which has characterised its management of our forests. It is this failure even to carry out an adequate survey of koala habitation which is one of the reasons that conservationists have urged the Government not to make these crucial long term decisions so soon, despite what Senator Richardson has said about not really needing any more time for making these decisions.

Obviously, more time is needed. We need that time for the surveys that the industry says are not needed, but I do not believe that the industry needs an immediate decision despite its claims at the moment. It is also a savage irony that it is a Japanese company which is so heavily involved in this destruction of forest habitat when the Japanese people are so enamoured of this animal. The other question, of course, we must ask is to what use Harris Daishowa puts Australian woodchips in Japan. It is a highly consumer oriented society, and I imagine that our valuable timbers are being wasted hand over fist by Japanese consumers, who are not very concerned about recycling or reusing.

I return to the more overall issue of ecologically sustainable development. A move away from a resource driven economy is imperative if Australia is to avoid economic and ecological decline in the long term. Although it is understood that decisions that have to be made now will seem to be tough, they must be made. As the conservation movement has argued, ecological sustainability imposes a new discipline upon the Australian economy. Guiding principles for ecologically sustainable development include intergenerational equity, the conservation of biodiversity, constant natural capital and sustainable income, an anticipatory and precautionary approach and the pricing of environmental values and natural resources. At the moment they are not priced in any way at all and yet they have almost priceless value once they are removed. By then, of course, it is too late.

The Government's discussion paper fails to acknowledge the underlying imperative of ecological sustainability or environment as the basis for continued human existence, not just as a facet of it. It is the underlying principle, and I think the Government has failed to grasp that basic concept. The emphasis on the maintenance of economic growth ignores the need for major changes in structure and major distribution in resource and energy use. It has to address demand, not just look for continuously expanding supply. That is why we question this Government's lip service to sustainable development when it makes the kind of decisions that we are talking about in respect of New South Wales.

The situation is not very different in Western Australia. Again, we have a situation where commitments are made to continuing forestry operations before all assessment information is made available and before putting in place a strategy which is ecologically sustainable. I know that Western Australia does not figure very much in terms of the debate on the fate of our forests, as I have noticed this afternoon, but I want to put on record the Western Australian row over the Four Corners program entitled `The Wood for the Trees', which examined the economic basis of the timber industry in Western Australia.

It was a program which raised questions about the price received by the State Government for the timber resources it administers and focused on the role of the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management. It was an interesting program which triggered off a lot of protests from vested interests-objections which were considered by the ABC and covered in a report dated 18 July this year. I have not got time to deal with the report in this debate, despite its relevance to the critique that has been presented by Senator Coulter and Senator Bourne this afternoon, so I ask permission to table it.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that other speakers from the coalition and the Labor Party have shown that they still do not understand what ecologically sustainable development is about, but I believe that, given time and pushed by the voters, they will come to understand. I hope it will not be too late for the old growth forests of south-eastern New South Wales and the rest of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the other speakers in this debate because it has revealed a great deal about their approach to this matter. Senator Watson has talked about the Australian expert foresters coming from Tasmania. He would know that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission ran up a debt of over $400m to the extent that it could not even afford to pay the interest on the debt. That shows how well it was managing the forests in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Several senators have commented on environmentally sustainable growth-the term that was used by Senator Loosley-which indicates just how little this Government really understands about sustainability. Let me say absolutely and unequivocally that growth, as measured by economists-that is, growth of gross national product-is not consistent with environmental sustainability. There is an absolute irreconcilability and unless the definition of 'growth' is modified we cannot have sustainability. That assertion is absolutely provable-it is not an arguable point at all. To hear members of the Opposition and the Government still talking about balancing environmental ecological sustainability and economic growth is to talk in absolutely absurd terms.
