A number of points were mentioned. Senator Richardson began by pointing out that he was relying on a scientifically reliable report. He was referring simply to the joint scientific study. As Senator Bourne mentioned, five of the six people on the committee of the joint scientific study were foresters. There are a number of other studies which indicate that a great deal of circumspection should be used in approaching this whole matter. We should not be going in, as we are, logging these forests.
I will quote a few other experts. Liz Dovey, a specialist potoroo biologist from the National Parks and Wildlife Service in New South Wales, said:
. . . if the current management regime continues in the way that's been advocated . . . the long-foot potoroo will almost certainly become extinct in New South Wales.
Professor Harry Recher from the Department of Ecosystem Management in the University of New England said:
A balanced membership--
he is referring to the joint scientific study--
might have avoided some of the inconsistencies in the Committee's report and its apparent support of logging interests.
I will quote Dr Hal Cogger of the Australian Museum, who said:
When we undertake the kinds of operations that are proposed for the south east forests there is . . . a high risk of some organisms becoming extinct.
Dr Hugh Possingham-who has already been quoted-from the Research School of Biological Sciences at the Australian National University said:
Their use--
he is referring to the Committee--
of ecological theory is poor. If a graduate student wrote this . . . I'd think that I'd done a poor job in educating them.
Professor Gordon Orians, the eminent Professor of Zoology from the University of Washington, said:
The confident assertion of the committee that continued logging of the South East Forests will not threaten . . . species in the region is not supported by the scientific evidence.

So much for the basis on which we approach this matter of urgency which was brought into question by Senator Richardson. We believe there is abundant scientific evidence to support the stand we have taken, and the Government quite clearly accepted the evidence that suited its particular purpose.

Several of the speakers in this debate have suggested that we need to compromise, and suggested that we know enough about the forests to maintain the biological values. Let me say again, unequivocally, that an incredible arrogance runs through the arguments of the Government and the Opposition in the assumption that we know everything about these forests and that we can, indeed, maintain their biological integrity.

The evidence is that we are supremely ignorant, and the reason for protecting these forests in their undamaged state is not to hold them-as Senator Watson and Senator Baume tried facetiously to suggest-in an unchanged state, but to hold them in a way which will preserve the range of species in them. Certainly, they will turn over and they will die and new animals and plants will grow, but we want to maintain them so that the evolutionary processes which are going on in those forests will continue in perpetuity without the disruptive intrusion of human intervention. They will be areas to which we can go to discover more about the natural environment.

I will give one example, which is happening globally. Honourable Senators may have read about this. It appears that throughout the world not only are frogs disappearing in terms of numbers of species, but also the numbers in each species are in rapid decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is due to the warming.

—I was speaking to Dr Mike Tyler just the other night. He said that he has been in virgin rainforest in north Queensland and in virgin rain- forest in Costa Rica quite recently and, in both situations, the number of frog species and the number of frogs were in rapid decline. We do not know why that is occurring. I hear Senator Watson saying, `That is the warming'. I wish we jolly well knew why it is occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: Years ago we sent canaries down into mines and when they died we said, `Ah ha, there is something wrong, we should not go in there.' We now have frog species-not just one but frog species generally throughout the world-declining in numbers and we do not know why, but there is a strong suspicion that it is because of the intrusions which humans have made into the global environment.

The assertion was repeated by Senator Richardson that the reason for coming to the agreement in relation to the southeastern forests was to protect the jobs of the sawmillers. My evidence is that 80 per cent of the timber that comes out of these south-eastern forests goes to the chippers. I can only assume, therefore, that the practices which this Government is about are to protect the interests of Daishowa, not the interests of the loggers.

I go back to the statement I made earlier: where it becomes a matter of protecting the assumed model of the economy, neither Mr Hawke nor Mr Greiner in New South Wales cares a hoot about jobs. I listed the large number of jobs that are being lost to protect their model of the economy-to protect what they see as a desirable shape to the economy. If it becomes a matter of protecting the environment and losing two or three jobs, they say, `To hell with the environment! We are not going to make ourselves unpopular to that limited extent'. I thank Senator Vallentine for pointing out that at the last election the Labor Federal Government was returned substantially on the preferences which flowed from the green parties and from the Democrats. I do not wish to draw any distinction between greens and Democrats, because we are supporting the same environmental ends.

I hear that the membership of the Labor and coalition parties is very much in decline. I can put it on record that our membership is substantially increasing-and I am not surprised, because every poll of public opinion one looks at indicates that the public are right behind the sorts of measures that we have raised in this urgency motion this afternoon.

Sustainability has become a term which is bandied around. Indeed, one author cynically suggested in the Adelaide Advertiser the other day in a letter that it will not be very long before we hear the term `sustainable nuclear war'. It is a term which it is very important to get right. I point out that sustainability must become the basis for industrial development from now on into the indefinite future. It is not understood by the Government or by the Opposition, and it is absolutely important to get it right. The logging of the south-east forests is an important reminder that the Government has still not got its economic house in order.

STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

The Bill amends the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act 1977 and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Collection Act 1977 to give statutory effect to the Government's waterfront reform strategy. It is introduced in conjunction with the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1990.
Mr President, I will now outline the background to these Bills.

Australia has been poorly served by its waterfront industry, with major costs for the rest of the economy. This key point in the export trading chain has been characterised by gross inefficiencies and high costs due to an absence of competition and competitiveness.

The Government determined that the true potential of our waterfront industry should be unlocked by a coherent strategy for reform. This is a task on which we are embarking vigorously. It is a major element of the Government's program of microeconomic reform.

On 1 June 1989, following consultations on the conclusions of the Inter-State Commission's waterfront investigation, the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Ralph Willis, announced a far-reaching reform strategy for the waterfront industry. The strategy is designed to improve waterfront efficiency, reliability and productivity which will, in turn, assist our exporting sectors.

Since then, the waterfront reform strategy has been consolidated. In October last year, a three year ``in-principle agreement'' for waterfront reform was entered into with Stevedoring employers, relevant unions and the ACTU. The agreement resulted from negotiations with waterfront parties conducted under the auspices of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, which oversights the reform process.

Fundamental to the reforms outlined in the agreement is the shift from the present industry-wide employment practice to enterprise-based employment, and other new employment arrangements where appropriate. Under the new arrangements, employment responsibilities which have rested with the industry will be assumed by individual employers, an arrangement more in line with the practice in other industries. These changed arrangements will contribute to achieving a competitive and productive waterfront industry with improved services to clients.

This initiative is to be assisted by a workforce rejuvenation program involving a one-off early retirement and redundancy scheme. In addition there will be a progressive phasing out of statute based arrangements for cross subsidies between ports.
The Bills, as a package, underpin the waterfront reform strategy:
Firstly, by facilitating through the existing special statutory levy, the collection of employer contributions to the new retirement and redundancy scheme

Secondly, by providing for the phasing out over the reform period of cross-subsidy arrangements for smaller Australian ports which are currently financed by revenue raised under the general statutory levy.

These smaller ports, sometimes referred to as non-permanent ports, are those which employ Division B waterside workers, that is, ``waterside workers'' who are employed by the industry and are available for engagement by Stevedores on an ``as required'' basis, rather than under the weekly hire arrangements which apply to the majority of the waterfront workforce.

The phasing out arrangement will involve payment of the general levy by a small port being discontinued when all employers in that port have moved to new employment arrangements, and a complementary phasing out of cross subsidy payments. This will ensure that these ports are exposed to the competitive pressures necessary to improve their efficiency.
As this Bill contains a number of amendments of a minor nature which are explained in the explanatory memorandum, I will confine my comments to the more noteworthy amendments.
Amendments to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act 1977

The Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee is established by this Act to administer statutory levies imposed under the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act 1977. It comprises a government appointed chairperson, three representatives of the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour, and a representative each of the Australian National Line, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company and the Waterside Workers Federation.

It is proposed that the membership of the Committee be expanded to include an officer of the Department of Industrial Relations (which has administrative responsibility for the legislation and is involved in the collection and administration of the statutory levies) and a nominee of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority.

The functions of the Committee are to be expanded to enable it to make recommendations to the Minister as to when the general levy should cease to apply to employers in smaller ports which have moved to enterprise-based employment or other new employment arrangements.

Under provisions contained in the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1990 the Minister for Industrial Relations will be able to discontinue the levy for the smaller ports to which I have referred.

An amendment is proposed to enable the Committee to make payments directly to an employer for reimbursement of expenditure incurred in satisfying relevant award obligations. Current arrangements require that these payments be made only to the Association and therefore do not cover the situation where an employer decides to withdraw its membership from the Association.

Under the new arrangements, these payments will continue to be made to individual employers or the Association in respect of employees in the smaller ports until such time as the Minister notifies, by gazettal, a finishing date for a port indicating that all employers in that port have moved to new employment arrangements.

Clause 9 of the Bill provides the vehicle by which revenue collected through the special levy is to be applied to the provision of prescribed benefits to eligible employees. The ``in-principle agreement'' defines eligibility for the early retirement and redundancy payments in terms of, amongst other things, employment by a member company of the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour.

However should a Stevedoring company withdraw its membership from the Association, its employees may no longer be eligible for early retirement and redundancy payments. A prescription power is therefore proposed in clause 9 to provide for this and other exigencies. Monies raised to meet redundancy obligations will be paid to the Committee, to the Association or to individual employers.
Amendments to the Stevedoring Industry Levy Collection Act 1977
The Bill involves a change to the definition of ``local cargo'' contained in this Act.

Under current arrangements, cargoes shipped to oil rigs and other associated structures or vessels located above the continental shelf in Australia are levied at the higher special levy rate applied in respect of overseas cargoes. As these cargoes are not destined for overseas locations, it is clearly illogical and inequitable that they continue to be levied in this way. Amendments included in the Bill seek to rectify this small anomaly by including these cargoes in the definition of ``local cargo''.
Penalties prescribed for offences against these acts and regulations are to be increased for the first time since the Act came into effect in 1977.
Financial Impact Statement
The Bill does not involve a financial cost to the Commonwealth.

Amendments to the definition of ``local cargo'' will not affect the amount ultimately collected through the special levy to meet employer contributions to the early retirement and redundancy scheme. The levies will be in place no longer than is required to meet outgoings.

Any financial impact will be positive as, due to amendments contained in clause 10, the Commonwealth will be able to recover expenses (including salaries and audit costs) incurred in its administration of the scheme.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990
This Bill amends the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act 1977. It is introduced in conjunction with the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990.

The main purpose of this Bill is to facilitate the phasing out of the general statutory levy imposed in respect of Division B waterside workers which is, in part, used to finance cross-subsidy arrangements for the smaller Australian ports, that is those ports where Division B waterside workers are employed.

This levy is applied to meet attendance money, guaranteed wages and retainers and annual leave for employees in smaller, non-permanent ports. It also finances, for all ports, employers' retirement fund contributions, administration and port conciliator costs.

The `in-principle agreement' entered into with stevedoring employers and unions and the ACTU (in October 1989) provides for the general levy to be discontinued in the smaller ports on a port-by-port basis once new employment arrangements are effected.

New section 9A is introduced into the Act to facilitate the phasing out. This section provides for the Minister to notify, by gazettal, a date in respect of each small, non-permanent port after which the general levy will cease to apply to employers in those ports.
A date will only be notified in respect of a port when the Minister is satisfied that all employers at the port have revised their employment arrangements in line with the `in-principle agreement'.

Under a new provision contained in the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee will be empowered to make recommendations to the Minister as to when the general levy should cease to apply.

The Act is to be amended so that all levy rates, both general and special, will be prescribed by regulation and will no longer be set out in the Act. As the general levy in respect of Division B waterside workers is to be phased out, it is likely that levy rates will need to be adjusted on a regular basis to take account of the reduced cross-subsidy financing requirement.
Financial Impact Statement
There is no financial impact associated with this Bill, for the reasons outlined in relation to the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Government has decided to restructure home ownership assistance arrangements to better reflect the changing pattern of home ownership assistance requirements in recent years and to ensure that Commonwealth funding is better targeted to the needs of home buyers on lower incomes.

The main purpose of the Bill is to preclude payment of assistance under the First Home Owners Act 1983 to sole or joint applicants who contract to purchase or build, or commence construction of, a dwelling on or after 22 August 1990.

The Bill also fixes 30 June 1991 as the cut off date by which applications for assistance under the First Home Owners Act must be received by the Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health.

The Bill additionally deals with two minor amendments. Firstly, it amends section 38 of the First Home Owners Act, to create an offence related to the recklessly making of false or misleading statements in connection with applications under the act, in addition to the existing offence of knowingly making such statements. Further, it deletes certain references which are unnecessary duplications of provisions which can be found in the Crimes Act 1914. Secondly, the Bill corrects some anomalies which occurred when references to migration law in the First Home Owners Act were amended by the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989.

The second minor amendment corrects drafting oversights affecting applications since last December. These oversights have resulted in inequitable treatment of certain migrants, generally from New Zealand and some of whom are long term residents here, in the application of the scheme's income test. The proposed amendment will enable the Department to review such applications.

The First Home Owners Scheme (FHOS) was introduced on 1 October 1983, to assist low to moderate income first home buyers into home ownership, to stimulate construction of new dwellings and to create new jobs.

When FHOS was announced, housing activity was at a 20 year low-only 105,000 dwellings were commenced in 1982/83. Housing finance was in short supply and it was rationed. This often resulted in `cocktail' arrangements whereby home buyers had to take out a second mortgage at a higher interest rate-thus driving up the overall cost of finance.

In its first year of operation, FHOS assisted over 54,000 households into home ownership and was a key element in a remarkable recovery in the housing industry-housing commencements increased by almost one third, to about 137,000 in 1983/84 and some 40,000 new jobs were created. Since inception FHOS has helped over 360,000 households into home ownership at a cost of around $1.53 billion.

As foreshadowed earlier, the nature of home ownership assistance has changed over the last few years and so has the economic environment. Housing activity has fallen to a more sustainable level following the record level of 175,000 commencements reached in 1988/89. The Australian financial system has been progressively deregulated which has ensured an adequate supply of housing finance and enabled lenders to develop loan products which are more responsive to the needs of lower income borrowers. The overall supply of housing finance has increased from $7.2 billion in 1982/83 to $18.8 billion in 1989/90.

At the same time, greater emphasis has been placed on the efficiency and effectiveness of home ownership schemes under the CSHA. The 1989 CSHA not only represents the most significant reform of public housing funding but also has laid the foundation for a significant increase in funds available for home purchase loans by inclusion of private sector funds. As a result of these reforms and the development of shared home ownership schemes under the CSHA home ownership has been extended to include people on lower incomes.

The success of the close co-operation between the States/Territories and the Commonwealth in the home ownership area has led to a considerable increase in the number of families benefiting: from 16,000 in 1987/88 ($720 million) to over 32,000 in 1989/90 (over $2 billion). The market share of State Housing Authorities has more than doubled: from about 4.5 per cent in 1987/88 to over 11 per cent in 1989/90 (or some 30 per cent of the first home buyer market). Since 1983 some 124,000 households have received home purchase assistance.

However, despite the development of innovative financial arrangements, insufficient savings capacity continues to be a major barrier to home ownership for some lower income people. Lack of savings capacity can in some cases preclude potential home buyers from accessing State HPA Schemes.

To some extent, the First Home Owners Scheme has been used by home purchase assistance recipients to bridge the deposit gap or assist in meeting the entry costs and some home purchase assistance schemes are designed on this basis. However, wide variations in house prices across Australia have made it increasingly difficult to maintain and develop an equitable and efficient national scheme such as FHOS.

Essentially, under the current home ownership arrangements the same target group is benefiting from both FHOS and Home Purchase Assistance but the two programs are administered at two levels of Government. In order to streamline the administration and remove the duplication in this area the Government has decided to cease the First Home Owners Scheme and provide funds to the States to link deposit assistance with existing home lending schemes. The new arrangements will be administered directly by the State and Territory Housing Authorities and will ensure a fairer and more equitable distribution of these funds to lower income earners. The Commonwealth will develop broad guidelines against which States will develop more flexible deposit assistance tailored to family needs and local market conditions. The new arrangements will thus provide State and Territory Housing Authorities with an impetus to further develop their home purchase assistance schemes.

The new deposit assistance arrangements are envisaged to come into effect from 1 January 1991 provided agreements can be reached with State and Territory Governments over the next few months. It will receive total Commonwealth funding of $14 million in 1990/91 which will increase to $30 million in 1991/92. The new arrangements will be incorporated into the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement.

The First Home Owners Scheme ceases from the budget night. Home buyers who are already receiving assistance under the First Home Owners Scheme will, of course, continue to receive the assistance to which they are entitled. People who have entered into a binding contract to buy or build a home, or have commenced construction, before 22 August 1990, and who are otherwise eligible for assistance under the First Home Owners Scheme will have until 30 June 1991 to lodge their applications. FHOS assistance will not be available to those entering into contracts on or after 22 August 1990.
In 1990/91 some 11,000 families who have already acquired a home will receive FHOS assistance for the first time and ongoing assistance will be paid to a further 140,000 families.

The Government's Housing Program is a key part of its Social Justice Strategy. It is Governments policy to maximise access to affordable and appropriate housing. Since coming to office, the Government has delivered effective services in greatly increased numbers to assist thousands of people throughout the community: 360,000 households have been assisted under FHOS; over 124,000 home purchasers received assistance under CSHA; public housing stock increased by 39 per cent and 1,450 services were provided under the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP) for transitional housing support. The Government is also aware of the importance of adequate medium and long term accommodation to the successful movement of homeless young people towards independence. In responding to the needs of these young people, as highlighted in the findings of the Burdekin Report, a $100 million package of assistance, over 4 years, was announced last year. The package included substantial increases in funding for youth housing, in order to provide assistance for an additional 6,000 young people.

The new CSHA agreement was renegotiated in 1989 and as I said earlier, represents the most significant reform of public housing funding since the CSHA was introduced in 1945. The new arrangement will provide an unprecedented level of funding and forward commitment for public housing: $1.028 billion was provided in 1989/90 and at least that amount guaranteed for each of the three years 1990-91 to 1992-93.

The housing area is now high on the Government's list for major reform. Current problems and projected demographic trends will change the pattern of housing demand and we need to come up with imaginative housing solutions. The Government is determined to ensure that all Australians have access to affordable and appropriate housing, in the right locations, and that this continues well into the twenty-first century.

The National Housing Strategy, which the Minister for Community Services and Health recently established, will examine innovative ways of providing secure, affordable and appropriate housing, within a broad economic, social and demographic framework. It will also examine longer term proposals for remedying fundamental structural problems in the housing market. The Strategy creates a major opportunity to evaluate trends in home ownership and provide a framework to examine the effectiveness of the current range of assistance schemes and policies.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

upon which Senator Alston had moved by way of amendment in respect of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate deplores the Government's hasty and ill-conceived attempt to bestow a vast new range of unpredictable and unnecessary powers on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in a desperate attempt to divert attention from its total failure to introduce any meaningful reforms of broadcasting regulations despite the Prime Minister's unequivocal 1987 election promise to `urgently reform this nightmarish legislation'' '.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we adjourned on Thursday evening we were discussing the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990 and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. I notice that in the intervening period there have been press reports in the Sydney Morning Herald of Saturday, 13 October, about an uproar over plans to deregulate radio and television. At this stage, I want to note my concern that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, is talking about Government plans to deregulate the broadcasting system and to replace the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with a new regulatory authority. I am concerned because this is coming at a time when this Senate is looking at passing an efficiency package and, in fact, allocating more powers to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. It seems that we have things in the wrong order. I am pleased to see that Mr Beazley has moved to distance himself from the plan, indicating that the proposals represented only departmental thinking and had not yet been conclusively considered by him or the Cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: I place on record my concern. I wonder who really sets the agenda when we are in the middle of debating these important Bills and comments are reported in the media which cause us to question the value of this entire debate.

When we adjourned on Thursday I was making some comments about the extra remedies provisions of this Bill. The Broadcasting Amendment Bill inserts in the legislation certain suitability requirements for the holders of radio and television licences. Further, the Bill provides the Broadcasting Tribunal with a number of options where it finds a radio or television licensee not to be a fit and proper person to hold a commercial licence or where it finds that person to be unable to provide an adequate and comprehensive service.

For fairly obvious reasons, these amendments have come to be known as the Bond amendments. Although the issue of whether Alan Bond was a fit and proper person to hold a broadcasting licence may not yet be fully resolved, this example clearly highlighted the glaring deficiencies in the Act with respect to the Tribunal's powers in such a case. As is seen in the Bond case, it may be that a company is operating well within the prescribed boundaries but that one of the interest holders in the company is the party in question. The only option previously available to the Tribunal was to impose conditions on the licensee company itself.

This Bill will grant additional powers to the Tribunal, enabling it to give specific directions to relevant parties or to impose appropriate conditions on a licence where it finds a licensee fails to meet suitability requirements. Further to this, the Bill provides that where these directions or conditions do not sufficiently address the situation, the Tribunal can direct relevant parties to divest their interests. As I have indicated, the Australian Democrats welcome these additional powers.

This Bill also makes provision for aspirant public broadcasters to transmit sponsorship announcements. The Democrats have always been strong supporters of public broadcasting as we recognise the value of diversity in our media. It is vital that potential public broadcasters have the ability to test whether a market exists for their particular broadcast format. As such, we support these clauses.

The Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) before us today is the so-called `efficiency package' designed to, among other things, streamline the Tribunal's share transaction approval process. The Bill will change the share transaction process to require Tribunal inquiry into only those transactions which involve the acquisition of a prescribed interest, those which result in a party coming into a position to exercise actual control or those which may breach foreign ownership provisions.

Further, the Bill will raise the levels of general meeting votes or shareholding interests which constitute a prescribed interest in a television licence from 5 per cent to 15 per cent. The Democrats accept that these measures are desirable. We will be supporting these clauses.

The Bill will, however, also remove the requirement for prior notification of share transactions to be given to the Tribunal. To the Democrats, it is an untenable situation that the Broadcasting Tribunal is not empowered to issue or withhold approval of share and financial transactions that affect the ownership of licences prior to those transactions taking place. After all, the Federal Communications Commission in the United States of America has this power; the Canadian radio-television Telecommunications Commission also has the power of approval, and the British regulatory commission had it up until its removal by Margaret Thatcher.

To illustrate the absurdity of the existing Australian regulations, we have the situation where the original purchase of the Nine Network by the Bond group and the question of whether Alan Bond was a fit and proper person to hold a broadcast licence was not fully resolved before the Bond group had sold the network. In the public interest, we believe the Tribunal must be provided with greater legislative power with respect to the takeovers of broadcasting stations. In particular, all share and financial transactions affecting licence ownership should be subject to prior approval by the Broadcasting Tribunal, and the Tribunal should also be empowered to step in and freeze any share sales or purchases.

Of course before the Murdoch amendments of 1981, introduced by the Government of the day, the Tribunal had this prior approval power. I would like to remind some of the present Government Ministers of what they had to say when the approval requirement was removed back in 1981. Senator Gareth Evans said at the time that there were many things wrong with the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill including:
. . . allowing the unconditional takeovers without prior approval and with later approvals by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which is necessarily reduced to an empty cypher.
Senator Button also said:
The provision that the prior approval of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is required has not been a terrible inhibition to Australian companies and those who seek to take over media companies.

Let me say that I agree whole-heartedly with both of these statements. Requiring Broadcasting Tribunal prior approval power is not an inhibition to Australian companies and the removal of it has reduced the Tribunal to an empty cipher. This situation, we believe, should not be allowed to continue.

As the Saunderson Committee noted, without prior approval it becomes a case of the Tribunal attempting to `unscramble the eggs'. Rather than seek to strengthen the Tribunal's hand with respect to the approval process, this Bill actually weakens the Tribunal by removing the obligation for parties to transactions to give the Tribunal prior notification of the transaction. For the Tribunal to at least be given the chance to function efficiently, an absolute minimum requirement is that it has as much information available to it as possible. To deny the Tribunal access to the very information it relies on to perform its duties is almost culpable. The Australian Democrats will be opposing the removal of prior notification.

Another clause of this Bill provides that where the Tribunal has failed to approve or decline a commercial licence share transaction within six months of the transfer inquiry beginning, then it is deemed to have given approval to the transaction. The Bill also allows the Tribunal to extend the inquiry period where it feels this is appropriate but it must provide written reasons for doing this. My concern with this clause is that if a situation is serious enough to warrant an inquiry in the first place, then it is inappropriate to simply deem approval because six months has elapsed. One of the primary reasons that some tribunal inquiries go beyond the six months is again because the Tribunal is grossly underfunded. Such a clause provides no incentive to the licensees to assist in the speedy resolution of the inquiries; it does just the opposite, and it may be more appropriate to deem rejection where an inquiry is incomplete after a prescribed period.

Some of the more controversial clauses of this Bill relate to the networking agreements between the regional stations and the networks. The Bill will provide exemptions from ownership and control limits for parties to such networking agreements. The granting of these exemptions results from a ruling by the Attorney-General that networking agreements may breach the 60 per cent audience reach limit.

As the aggregation of our regional stations relies heavily on these agreements, action is clearly needed to be taken. It is already on the record that the Australian Democrats opposed aggregation, as we believed it would be detrimental to the quality of service provided by the regional stations, particularly in terms of local content. We accept, however, that regional viewers deserve to have the same choice of programs that their city counterparts have.

To date, the regional stations have been in a reasonably strong position with respect to purchasing programs from the networks. They have been able to `cherry-pick' from the networks the best programs at relatively cheap prices. As these monopolies are to be broken down under aggregation, the pressure is now on for closer affiliation agreements and, because of the small number of networks, regionals are virtually compelled to line up one for one with networks. Also, because of the emerging economic pressures towards maintaining affiliation agreements, the regionals will be keen not to upset their network partners, and this potentially allows the networks to exert significant influence over the regionals.

The Democrats recognise that there are economies of scale and viewer benefits to be gained from these networking agreements, and while we do have serious reservations with respect to the aggregation of our regional television markets, we also realise that to dismantle networking agreements at this stage would be most destructive. As a consequence, we do not support the coalition's opposition to the networking clauses in these Bills.

The Democrats recognise the potential that these agreements provide for the networks to exert control over regionals and are concerned to ensure that this potentiality does not eventuate. As such, I indicate that I will be moving an amendment to this legislation in the committee stages to ensure that the autonomy of the regional stations involved in networking agreements is protected. This Bill will increase the maximum licence renewal period from three years to five years. It also allows the Tribunal to specify a shorter licence period where it is satisfied that the circumstances justify this. Clearly, part of the motivation behind this Government amendment is to reduce some of the workload of the Tribunal.

The Australian Democrats believe that the Government has approached this issue from the wrong direction. The solution to the Tribunal's backlog of work is not simply to remove some of the very important work that the Tribunal does. Instead, the Tribunal needs to be provided with sufficient resources to enable it to undertake all of its tasks successfully. When the areas of inquiry that warranted Tribunal attention were originally identified, the issue of three-year licence renewals was seen as sufficiently important. To my knowledge, nothing has occurred since that time to make three-year licence inquiries any less important. Indeed, I would have said that these have become considerably more important.

What has happened, of course, is that the Tribunal has become snowed under in work which is directly due to underfunding by this Government. To simply turn around and say that the solution to this underfunding is to reduce the issues into which the Tribunal need inquire is clearly unacceptable to us. We believe that this is a highly inappropriate time to be extending licence periods. Licensees are facing financial turmoil, the uncertain affects of aggregation and the new requirements for Australian content. With these conditions prevailing, I believe that more, rather than less, tribunal oversight is required. With the five-year licence, a licensee's service may be inadequate for two years but not attract any Tribunal sanctions because of an improvement in the last two years before renewal. After all, we do not trust our politicians for anywhere near five years.

The last clause that I wish to discuss is the one that will delete the financial interest test from the existing legislation, which effectively means that loan interests will no longer be considered when determining whether a person holds a prescribed interest in a licence. With two of the networks currently in receivership, it seems reasonable to expect that in fulfilling their fiduciary duties, the banks will now take some interest in programming.

One aspect of the existing scheme that must be retained is the requirement for Tribunal notification of any change in a loan interest. In line with this concern, I will be looking at an amendment to this clause in the committee stage. Senator Alston in his remarks referred to the `old days'. Well, some basic things do not change and one of those things is that television licences bring with them power and influence-the power to shape social and cultural opinion. We, as a parliament, have a huge responsibility to scrutinise sufficiently potential candidates for such power and influence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it two Bills, both of which seek to amend the Broadcasting Act. There is, in the opinion of the Australian Democrats, more amendment needed to the Broadcasting Act beyond that which the Government is putting forward in these two Bills. Senator Kernot has outlined our response to the amendments put forward by the Government and further amendments which we will be putting forward. I will outline an area in which we believe the Broadcasting Act is grossly deficient and put forward reasons why we will move further amendments beyond those mentioned by Senator Kernot. Those amendments will be to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) which presents the Parliament-in the first instance the Senate-with a marvellous opportunity to remedy what we see as a major deficiency in the Broadcasting Act and, at the same time, to contribute to the improved health of the Australian community and continue initiatives of this Parliament in its passage of my private member's Bill last December-the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Act Bill which prohibited the advertising of tobacco products in the print media.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments which I will introduce relate to the deficiency in the Act which we believe the loophole allowing incidental advertising on broadcast media of tobacco products represents. We wish to close that loophole. Therefore, at the committee stage I will move amendments to stop the high level of advertising coverage which has been obtained on television in particular by tobacco companies which sponsor sporting and, to a lesser degree, cultural events.

Honourable senators will be aware-if they are not, I will make them aware-that the so-called direct advertising of tobacco products was phased out of the Act between September 1973 and September 1976, but that advertising, which was defined as `accidental or incidental' to broadcasting remained permissible. I understand that this innocuous-sounding caveat was an eleventh hour amendment successfully lobbied for by the tobacco industry. That was before the Australian Democrats either existed or had representation in this Parliament.

I also believe that few parliamentarians at the time could really have known just how effectively that loophole in the Act would be exploited. Following the passage of that legislation in the 1970s, the tobacco companies set about buying out Australian sport and, by 1980, the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria tells us, the tobacco industry owned every sporting event worth having-high profile televised events such as tennis, cricket, Rugby League, Australian Rules, horse racing, golf, soccer, ballet and opera: the list is almost endless.

In 1989, the tobacco industry spent an estimated $20m on sporting sponsorship, of which $12m went to sporting bodies and $8m to promotion, through this loophole in the Act which is before us today for amendment. This is no act of sporting philanthropy on behalf of tobacco companies. It has been a deliberate and highly successful effort to gain access to the broadcast media, access facilitated by the loophole which was retained at the time of the amendment in 1973.

A number of studies have shown just how much television coverage cigarettes have received since the so-called ban in 1976. The Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria estimated that the televising of test cricket over the summer of 1980-81 gave the sponsors Benson and Hedges at least 72 hours of coverage. This included 40,000 exposures of the name Benson and Hedges on a single channel. Things have not improved. A recent report has shown that during one day's play of a Benson and Hedges-sponsored cricket match televised from Sydney in 1988, the television spectator would have seen the Benson and Hedges name or logo clearly for a full 88 minutes of that one day's coverage.

Equally concerning are the Grand Prix events which feature vehicles predominantly sponsored by tobacco companies. An analysis of television coverage received by Marlboro's Formula One racing car in the Adelaide 1989 Grand Prix show that the Marlboro name gained prominent exposure for up to 36 per cent of broadcasting time. There are other statistics of this nature which have been circulated to all senators and members. I also commend to the attention of all honourable senators a report-a very well documented study-by Donald Martin circulated by the Australian Medical Association.

There is no question that the tobacco industry has deliberately sought to circumvent the intention of the Act as it stands. This has been revealed in a number of court cases. An example is the contract between Rothmans' Winfield and the New South Wales Rugby League which was revealed during the Federal High Court case in 1985. A number of clauses in the contract ensured maximum exposure and assistance from the League in gaining high quality exposure, and that exposure was specifically for Winfield cigarettes. Interestingly, there was also an escape clause. The company had the right to terminate the contract if the kinds of advertising and promotion it sought through its sponsorship were restricted or banned by government or any other authority. Not surprisingly, the judges in that case in 1985 agreed that `the sponsorship arrangement was intended as an advertising opportunity rather than an act of sporting philanthropy'.

The same court case examined the contract struck between Benson and Hedges and the Australian Ballet. In this contract an incredible 75 per cent of sponsorship money was earmarked for advertising and promotional purposes, leaving the remaining 25 per cent of the funds to be used at the recipient's discretion. In another High Court case decided only in February this year, United Telecasters-Channel 10-was convicted for broadcasting a cigarette advertisement in the form of a Winfield spectacular, a dance extravaganza featuring the Winfield name and logo that took place just before the beginning of the 1984 New South Wales Rugby League Grand Final. Yet more evidence was stacked up in that case against Rothmans.

Further, in the much publicised Mr Fix-it trial, also earlier this year, in which a former Rothmans executive was tried for fraud, in his summing up of the evidence the judge stated, and I think it is worth quoting:

The company's main concern in all this ... would seem to have been to circumvent the ban placed upon the advertising of tobacco products on television not only by having events assume the company's brand name but also by ensuring that the advertising signs were transmitted on television. No one seems to have questioned the legality of all this, a question which perhaps would now have to be reconsidered in the light of the High Court's decision, the Department of Public Prosecutions v United Telecasters Sydney Limited (which was decided only on 15 February last).

I could continue to lay before the Senate other examples of a multitude of breaches of the Broadcasting Act, which we are considering today. In short, the legislation-if it is intended, as it says, to ban the advertising of tobacco products-is not working. It has been found before the High Court to have been breached on a number of occasions. It is clearly time for the Parliament to act in this area.

An amendment which I will move at the committee stage seeks simply to remove the so-called incidental advertising provision. Material which is genuinely accidental to broadcast would continue to be permitted. It comes as no surprise to the Democrats that our proposal has met with strong tobacco industry opposition. The tobacco industry's arguments in defence of its actions and position and of continued advertising through sponsorship are fatuous in the extreme. I am reluctant to bring its arguments before the Senate as I do not want to give the industry any particular credibility. But as we will be hearing them in the future, as we have in the past, until, I imagine, it believes the Democrats' resolve has crumbled-which probably will not be until hell freezes over-I suppose I should take the opportunity briefly to refute at least some of the arguments.

The tobacco companies ask us to believe that their advertising has no effect on children and that it is merely to encourage brand loyalty, or to persuade existing smokers to swap brands. They claim that restriction of their access to electronic media via sports sponsorship is an incursion on their right to free speech. The industry also threatens the demise of sport as we now know it in this country should we amend the Broadcasting Act in this way.

I will take each of those particular claims in turn. With total smoking prevalence declining in Australia by about one per cent a year bringing about an estimated annual reduction of smokers of about 120,000, for the tobacco industry to remain viable, clearly it must recruit new smokers. We have very good evidence which shows that children are influenced by tobacco sponsorships. The Australian Cancer Society conducted a national survey in 1984 to measure the smoking habits of Australian schoolchildren. In an interview last week on a radio station in another State, when I sought to quote this survey I was accused of quoting surveys from vested interests. In this debate I would much prefer to quote surveys from the Cancer Society whose vested interests, I would suggest, are positive, than to quote surveys from anyone connected with the tobacco industry whose vested interests are material at the very least, and damaging at the very worst.

This survey was conducted in 1984 to measure the smoking habits of Australian schoolchildren. As well as finding alarmingly high smoking rates among schoolchildren the study also identified different brand preferences in different States. It is interesting to look at them. In New South Wales and Queensland, far more children smoked Winfield where Winfield received high exposure through sponsoring the major winter sport, rugby league. Escort was favoured among South Australian children where it sponsored the Australian Rules Escort Cup. Escort was not one of the leading brands anywhere else in Australia.

In Victoria, Peter Jackson was the most popular brand, followed by Winfield. Both of these brands are heavily advertised, or were at the time, through the Victorian Football League in a number of forums and, in particular, on television.

The freedom of speech argument is a favourite of the tobacco industry. In this context, freedom of speech means the freedom to advertise a highly dangerous and addictive product that killed in excess of 18,000 Australians in 1987. Frankly, I believe that a more important freedom is that of children to be free of advertising pressure to adopt smoking.

Recent media reports of a British study state that over 90 per cent of teenagers who smoke three to four cigarettes a day are trapped into a career of regular smoking which typically lasts for some 30 to 40 years. The report from the Australian Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare on drug problems in Australia, chaired by Senator Peter Baume in 1977; the Better Health Commission, established by Dr Neal Blewett in 1985; and, only last year, the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, have all endorsed the view that there is no place for tobacco advertising in the Australian community. At the end of last year, through the all party support for my private member's Bill, which placed a ban on the print advertising area, we saw that even the Parliament as a whole had finally come to the view that it was time for us to act again federally for the first time since the mid-1970s.

If tobacco advertising has been a blight on the print media, then it is equally a blight on the electronic media in spite of the Act as it stands which nominally places a ban on that advertising. It is naive to regard the forms of advertising as different entities. Tobacco sponsorship is tobacco advertising.

Let us have a look at the tobacco industry's threats about the certain decline and fall of Australian sport as we know it in the absence of tobacco sponsorship. I make it very clear that the amendments I will move do not prevent tobacco sponsorship of anything. In Canada, the Canadian Government has simply banned tobacco sponsorship of sporting events. If the tobacco companies wish to respond by withdrawing their funding of certain sporting bodies, I suppose that will show us that the arguments we have put about sponsorship being advertising are very clear, but I do not believe that should hinder the passage of these amendments in any way.

I hope that honourable senators will be aware of the very successful health promotion foundations that have been established in Victoria and South Australia, funded by purpose-built levy mechanisms on wholesale sales of tobacco products and providing considerable support and replacement sponsorship to sport and other health-related activities.
A mere one per cent of revenue from the Federal excise on tobacco would provide $12.5m, sufficient to replace current tobacco company expenditure on sport sponsorship.

I believe that the Federal excise on tobacco products is currently under review. I also believe that submissions are being made to Cabinet at the time that we engage in this debate and I commend those submissions to the Government.

As I have said, under the terms of the amendments which we will be moving, sporting and other organisations would be free to continue to accept sponsorship from tobacco companies if they wished, subject to legislation enacted at State level. Tobacco companies would be permitted-as they are in the United Kingdom and West Germany-to use their colours, they simply would not be allowed to display trademarks, brand names or logos. As I said, that happens in Europe. In those countries tobacco companies have demonstrated that they are quite able to comply with that level of regulation, and it is the utmost in hypocrisy for them to say in Australia that the livelihood of Australian sport would be threatened. If we allow ourselves to fall for that argument, I suggest that we are succumbing to precisely the blackmail that the tobacco industry always intended, and the tobacco industry will not only have bought sport, but government or the Parliament as well, with the exception of the Australian Democrats who are putting forward these proposals.

Honourable senators may be aware that one recent parliamentary report does not recommend the ban of tobacco sponsorships for sport-that is, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, in its second report on an inquiry into sports funding and administration. This report does not favour a ban on tobacco sponsorship which, as I have already said, is not the purpose of what we are proposing to do with the legislation before us.

The report went on to conclude that a complete ban on the accidental and incidental televising of cigarette products is not realistic on the grounds that it would be an impossible piece of legislation to enforce. I agree with that. That is precisely why in the amendments I am putting forward I am proposing to continue to allow accidental broadcasting of tobacco advertisements. `Accidental' means just that-accidental. If an event is being filmed and somebody wanders past with a Marlboro tee-shirt on, that is not the fault of the organisation involved. It is not my intention to devise troublesome legislation that would be open to vexatious litigation; indeed, I think I have already demonstrated that litigation is exactly what is happening with the legislation as it currently stands.

I remind honourable senators of the level and strength of support among the general public for action in this area; indeed, support specifically for the amendments which the Australian Democrats will be moving. As I said, there was all party support for a move in the print media a few months ago. It would be inconsistent in the extreme of both the coalition and the Government to fall away at this stage from a public health move of major significance and to close what is a dramatically damaging loophole in some legislation which is clearly the Federal Government's responsibility. There can be no claims that this is not within the responsibility of the Federal Parliament. Quite clearly it is. The amendments that we propose go forward with the strongest endorsement from medical and health groups, as well as from a range of wider community groups. State governments are increasingly taking what action is open to them within their jurisdiction with, I regret to say, the notable exception of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague from Queensland expresses some concern that the brave pre-election promises of the Goss Government in this area, as in too many others, seem to be falling by the wayside. SPEECH.PARA: Tobacco related illness, death and disease are costing our community dearly. The Democrats will be putting forward a very sensible rationalist move in the committee stage of this legislation. There is no economic and, certainly, no moral argument for not taking this step. I tell the Senate that as I move amongst young people, and I do that as it is of the highest priority when I am not in this place-I visit their schools and talk to them in every other environment in which I can-I find that it is a matter of very great concern to young people that there is such a close link between sport and drugs and even an apparent or accepted dependence of sport on drugs.

We make a lot of song and dance-indeed there are some people in this chamber and in the other place with whom it seems to be an absolute obsession-about drugs in sport. Tobacco is a drug. I might be corrected, but I think that of the legal drugs, it is the only one of which we could say that there is no safe dose. I do not know about all the illegal drugs, but we could probably say the same thing, based on our present knowledge. Tobacco is certainly a grossly damaging substance. The very fact that it is legal is irrelevant in this debate. As for those people who say, `Why don't you just ban tobacco smoking?', we know that that would not work; we know that all that would create is a black market and quite probably even more peer pressure on young people. We have a responsibility to take the pressure off whoever it is and not allow the promotion of a product which we know costs our community so dearly-over $2 1/2 billion a year at least.

The health bodies, such as the Australian Medical Association Ltd, the Heart Foundation, the Asthma Association, the anti-cancer councils and a whole range of other groups, are putting their voices so strongly behind this move because they are the ones who have to cope with the damage that is created in our community. Amongst us in the Parliament are people from the medical fraternity who know very well the gross damage which tobacco causes. I make a plea to them, in particular, for leadership within their various parties on this particular issue.

I have heard that the Opposition has set its course against the Democrats' amendments-although there seems to be some uncertainty, as contact with the office of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has given us to understand that there is some uncertainty about its position. I hope that is the case. There is still some time for consideration by both the Opposition and the Government on these amendments. I could not commend anything more strongly to both sides of the chamber. We owe it to our young people and to their future. If we cannot bring ourselves to take this action for them, at least we should take it on the basis that we need not be spending $2 1/2 billion, largely out of the health budget, which we could put better into the other activities by way of government expenditure. I will be moving these amendments to correct what we believe is a gross deficiency in the Broadcasting Amendment Bill, which is before us today for amendment. I commend that action to both sides of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time and time again taxpayers' money is wasted by this Labor Government. Tonight we have a prime example of such waste. As a result of ill-considered sales tax legislation which passed this Senate, we are now considering a Bill to further amend that legislation because of the unintended consequences. Of course, I am referring to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), which will amend Sales Tax Acts (Nos 1 to 9), which received royal assent on 16 June, only four months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sales Tax Acts (Nos 1 to 9) increase from 30 to 50 per cent the rate of sales tax payable on motor cars and station sedans, including four-wheel drive vehicles, with a wholesale value exceeding $28,793. The anticipated revenue- I emphasise `anticipated revenue'-from this gain was in excess of $100m per annum.

These nine Acts were flawed from the day that they were announced. They were announced in a manner familiar to the Treasurer, Mr Keating, that is, legislation by press release, which, as a matter of principle to all democrats, is wrong. Furthermore, it was the retrospective nature of the legislation which was reconsidered once these Bills reached the Senate.

The application date for the new sales tax was altered from 1 April to 1 May, causing copious complications and chaos for car salesmen, as well as for purchasers. In fact, their fate is now changed by the introduction of Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). Luxury car sales surged during the period from Mr Keating's tax increase announcement in February-an election gimmick-until its implementation in May. Sales during this period pulled forward an estimated $54m in duty and sales tax. A threat of an increased sales tax was the impetus that many buyers actually needed to get into that new luxury car sooner rather than later, and as a consequence pay 20 percentage points less tax.

When sales tax Acts were being debated in the Senate in May, the coalition said that it did not believe that the increase in luxury car sales tax would raise anywhere near the amount of money claimed by this Government at the time. We also argued that it would have a negative impact on employment and business viability. The fact that the Government is now introducing amending legislation to these Acts vindicates the arguments which were put forward at the time by the coalition.

The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) will amend the Sales Tax Acts (Nos 1 to 9) in accordance with the changes announced in the Budget. The overall effect of the Bill is to reduce the rate of tax applicable to lower priced luxury motor vehicles by applying a progressively increasing rate, commencing at 30 per cent. The amended tax system commences at 30 per cent for vehicles priced at $30,234 and increases up to a maximum of 50 per cent for vehicles with a wholesale price equal to or greater than $54,419. This will mean that the higher priced luxury vehicles will remain subject to the existing 50 per cent rate of tax.

The effect of the luxury car tax, as admitted to by the Government, was to encourage wholesalers to adopt a number of undesirable practices which artificially reduced the wholesale prices below the threshold level, in some cases by removing safety options from the vehicles. For example, advanced safety features, such as anti-skid brakes, were removed in some cases. While this may have saved the purchaser a substantial amount in sales tax in the short run, they could well find themselves paying a higher price in the long run. What price do we put on a life?

Many within the car industry have referred to the increased sales tax as a tax on safety, not only because it has led to the practice of removing safety options from vehicles to bring the price down, but also because it prevents the safety items filtering down to the less expensive models as they would push the price of those cars over the threshold and thereby make them uncompetitive.

The Government also cites as reason for the amendment the plight of primary producers living in remote parts of Australia where the terrain necessitates the use of a four-wheel drive vehicle, the price of such vehicles placing them in the luxury category. I remember that my colleague Senator Panizza, from Western Australia, drew the Government's attention to the absolute necessity for four-wheel drive vehicles to have air-conditioning in remote parts of Western Australia. My colleague Bruce Lloyd also pointed out in the House of Representatives that it is bad enough that the farmers cannot obtain an ordinary sales tax exemption for four-wheel drive vehicles with a back seat. It is going over the top to classify these farm workhorses as luxury vehicles.

What the Government is not admitting to in making these amendments is the fact that the increase in luxury car sales tax has resulted in a negative impact on tax revenue. In fact, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, when announcing the hike in luxury car sales tax from 30 to 50 per cent, said that he expected the measure to raise an extra $100m dollars a year. This would increase the total revenue raised from this source from $450m to $550m per year.

Car company figures showed that the Government was unlikely to even maintain its previous revenue base, falling short of the $550m figure by as much as $260m, or almost 50 per cent. When the Government was doing its sums on this sales tax increase, it did not realise that the high interest rates had caused a slowdown in demand for luxury cars. From the information available to the Government, it should have known that annual average sales from September 1989 to February 1990 were just 10,900 units. If this level was maintained for a full year it would have cut the Government's sales tax and duty revenue on these cars by $130m in 1989-90, even without the tax increase.

For Mr Keating to get his bloated figure-perhaps we should say `boasted' figure-for an additional $100m in sales tax revenue, Australians would have to be buying almost 13,600 luxury cars a year. The absolute maximum likely to be sold over the next 12 months is only 8,000 units. So, the luxury car market is driven by price. The more expensive the cars become, the more the consumer finds alternative ways of spending money. The warning signs were there. The Government just failed to heed them.

The Government has also failed to mention the impact that the increased sales tax has had on the sales of Australia's two home-grown vehicles which fell into the luxury car category: Ford's LTD and General Motors-Holden Ltd's Caprice. At the 50 per cent tax level, a Ford LTD retails at $58,490, $16,335 of which is paid to the Federal Government in sales tax. Holden's Caprice has a price tag of $61,860, including $17,276 worth of sales tax. In both these instances, the amount of sales tax paid represents 28 per cent of the price tag.

Catching these two Australian-made cars in the higher tax net and jeopardising their sales prospects was described by Mike Kable of the Australian as `nothing short of absurd'-and we agree with that-`given the Government's commitment to the Buy Australia campaign'. The changes which will be implemented as a result of this amending legislation will particularly benefit those vehicles in the lower end of the luxury car market. LTD and Caprice both fall into this bracket and will now sell for $5,554 and $4,966 less respectively than under the 50 per cent tax regime. While this will make Ford and Holden happier, it has certainly not impressed the luxury car importers whose vehicles fall into the upper end of the market.

I do not wish to delve into what role the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries played in having the sales tax altered or the matter of export credits, other than to make a general observation to the effect that the Button car plan has not been adhered to. It will be very interesting to see what the current Industry Commission's inquiry into the automotive industry recommends.

Mr Keating's estimation of the cost to revenue of phasing in this new progressive rate of luxury car sales tax is $8m in 1990-91 and $10m in a full year. I presume that these amounts are to be deducted from the $550m which Mr Keating's 50 per cent tax was expected to earn. My guess is that, given present sale volumes, this tax change will add between $8m and $10m to the $280m which the car industry expects the Government will earn in view of the current sales volumes. Thus, the overall impact will be a negative revenue return and poor work on the part of the Federal Treasurer. Such a mess indicates the urgent need to review sales tax.

When the matter of a luxury car tax was being debated in May, I said that the sales tax needed a complete revision because of its arbitrary classifications, its ad hoc composition and the difficulties of finding a proper wholesale value in an age when wholesale merchants are so few in number compared with, say, 20 years ago. We note from the Budget Papers that the Government is undertaking a review aimed at simplifying the wholesale sales tax system. This review is, as other senators would appreciate, a direct response to pressure by the coalition for a broad-based consumption tax to replace wholesale taxes.

If we look at some of the aspects that the Government is reviewing-for example, classifications and sale value-we see that the possibility is there for the Government to introduce a turnover tax by the back door. Perhaps this would be the back door response of the Government to the coalition's suggested need for a goods and services tax.

I must say that the Australian Taxation Office is making good progress. It has 18 months in which to complete that review and I commend it for the professional way in which it is going about that simplification. I only hope that there is the same commitment to simplification of income tax. Although the Government has promised in the Budget to deliver a Green Paper on the simplification of income tax-the good honourable Senator McMullan said that it would be out by the end of September-it is now October and we have had no word. There is no enthusiasm for simplification despite the fact that it was suggested in 1985. In other words, other matters took greater priority. Simplification was a No. 1 priority in 1985 but look at what has happened to income tax in the intervening time.

Surely the need for simplification cannot be greater than at the present time. Yet for some reason the Government is taking its time. It is taking much too long, and people-professionals and ordinary men and women-are crying out about the need to simplify income tax because we cannot have a proper system of self-assessment until there is certainty before the law. I commend the sales tax section of the Australian Taxation Office on the speed at which it is moving to simplify the sales tax law. I call for that same sort of commitment in income tax law.

Until the review of sales tax takes place, it is likely that we will be faced with similar situations to the one we presently find ourselves in-that is, debating amendment Bills on amendment Bills. Let us just be grateful that we are not the ones out in the marketplace trying to run a business and cope with these taxation alterations which have been as changeable as Melbourne's weather.

I will just give some brief information about another likely change. The Income Tax Amendment Bill, which will debated later on tonight, has some thin capitalisation rules. But before it hits this place we have been promised that by December there will be changes to the thin capitalisation rules. This is how absurd the situation is with amendment on amendment.

I turn now to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1990 and schedule 2 of Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) 1990. The purpose of these Bills is to overcome what the Tax Office considers an anomaly in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935. Under the present arrangements, printed matter which is inserted into a tax exempt publication, such as a newspaper, has also been exempt from the 20 per cent wholesale sales tax. If this same article had been distributed separately, the 20 per cent sales tax would have been applied.

So the sales tax treatment of news supplements and inserts has been a contentious issue for many years with the Australian Taxation Office seeking to tax such material as advertising matter. Many taxpayers have been challenging this approach. In general, the courts have agreed with the taxpayers. The courts held that the inserts and the supplements are exempt from sales tax on the ground that they were merely part of the newspapers.

The Sales Tax Amendment Bill and schedule 2 of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill amend items 51 and 54 of the Sales Tax Act 1935. The amendment provides that the following will not be included in exemptions provided under items 51 and 54 where the following conditions exist: the material is printed on a different sheet size from the rest of the publication; the material is printed by a different process from the rest of the publication; the material is printed on different paper; the material is inserted into the exempt product after the latter has been made; and the exempt publication is a magazine in which the insert is detachable or the publication is a newspaper in which the insert is not related to news, sport, entertainment, travel, leisure or similar sections. I believe that, even with this legislation, the ingenuity of the newspaper proprietors will probably get around even this amendment.

These amendments are expected to raise $20m in additional revenue in 1990-91 because inserts are a popular way of advertising. It is supposed to be the `in thing' nowadays. The coalition does not object to these amendments and, thus, will not be moving any further amendments when the Bill reaches the committee stage. In this instance, however, I wish to add that I trust that the Government has done its homework correctly on the impact of this tax alteration and that we do not find ourselves back here next session or even before amending the amendment, as we have with the luxury car sales tax legislation.

Just before the dinner break, the Australian Democrats gave us a few moments notice of their intention to proceed with a series of amendments. All these amendments have particular personal appeal and they also appeal to particular interest groups because they provide benefits in relation to the recycling of certain products and they provide relief, for example, to the disabled, which is very attractive. The problem that worries me is that they provide opportunities for an upper House virtually to take over a legislative program on issues which would not otherwise be before the House as a result of the contents or scope of that legislation.

I believe we have to act with a degree of responsibility, as an upper House with certain limited financial powers, in opting for knee-jerk type reactions no matter how desirable an amendment might be. After all, it can affect the Government's Budget integrity and Budget strategy, certainly if taken too far.On the other hand, it might well be said that it is a minimal cost to the Government but I do not think it is up to an upper House to pick and choose what it believes to be politically attractive taxation measures and to provide exemptions or benefits to certain categories, particularly when the items chosen are not normally within the scope of particular legislation. Therefore, I believe we on this side of the Senate will have difficulty under those circumstances unless we can be persuaded during the debate to change our minds.
