—It was not the uplift factor. Senator Watson received a sheet of paper listing all nine Democratic amendments to all the taxation Bills which are now coming before the Senate. I must say that I was somewhat disappointed that the Opposition parties did not find time to give due consideration to the amendments that we are proposing and I trust that during this debate I will be able to convince Senator Watson sufficiently for him to take the message to his colleagues so that they in turn may approve what I believe to be quite important amendments in a number of areas.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are in the area of sustainable development, the matter we have heard so much about this afternoon. Here is a practical opportunity for both parties, Government as well as Opposition, actually to put their actions where their mouths were this afternoon. I refer to the proposition to make tax exempt products that are manufactured out of 100 per cent recycled plastic material. I also refer to another amendment which proposes to exempt from sales tax that part of a product which is constituted by 100 per cent recycled paper. That is one omission in the legislation that previously exempted recycled paper. It is an omission that I believe should be corrected, and the Democrats are offering that opportunity to both the other parties to consider that what we are here for is to put into effect what we are talking about and that is the sustainable economy. We should not keep putting it off. The Government has indicated to me that, while not entirely opposed to the propositions that the Democrats are putting forward, it is not ready at this stage to consider those propositions. I regret that. How long do senators have to wait to pass a simple amendment that deals with urgent matters such as this when we are paying lip service to developing a sustainable economy?

I should return to the substance of the Bills before I deal in more detail at a later stage with our proposed amendments but the Senate must agree that I was provoked by Senator Watson, unlikely as that may seem. Today the Senate is debating two Bills: the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1990 and the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. The Bills seek to enact two sales tax measures announced in the Budget. These measures are, firstly, to phase in the 50 per cent luxury car sales tax by introducing an alternative method of calculation to apply in a certain price range only; and, secondly, to ensure that printed matters inserted into tax exempt printed matter, for instance, in newspapers, are taxable as if they were distributed separately.

Currently these inserts are generally taxed at 20 per cent if distributed separately, for instance, as junk mail. However, a recent court decision has exempted from sales tax inserts placed inside exempt printed matter, for example, newspapers. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) also seeks to define what an insert is, and that raises some concern. It appears that some publishers may be able to defeat the tax by simply ensuring that the item is not a separate insert, for instance, if the insert is physically attached to the publication by perforation, stapling, gluing, sewing, et cetera. Whether or not such an exemption could be practically exploited is open to some doubt. I simply mention it to draw the Minister's attention to it and suggest to him that this is a matter that the Government should pay some attention to.

Another aspect is the phasing in of the tax on luxury motor vehicles. Currently there are two rates for taxing luxury motor vehicles: a 20 per cent rate and a 50 per cent rate. Because there is such a big difference in the tax payable, many dealers and possibly manufacturers seek to qualify for the lower rate by taking out the optional extra components from the car and there are fears that this may spread to safety equipment as well as items that we would normally consider to be standard equipment, such as stereos, et cetera.

Consequently, the Government is proposing to lessen the severe impact of the 50 per cent rate by allowing a lower rate to apply to vehicles with a wholesale cost in excess of $30,233 but less than $54,419. Above that level, the current 50 per cent rate will continue to apply. The effect will be to reduce the cost of so-called lower priced luxury motor vehicles by taxing those vehicles at 30 per cent plus 75 per cent of the excess of the vehicle's price over the $30,233 threshold. This will lessen, on a per vehicle basis, the Government's tax take somewhat. For example, for a car which sold for $53,318, $1,000 below the higher limit, formerly the tax would have been, in round figures, $26,650. In round figures again, the new tax will be approximately $26,400. So there is a slight drop in the tax take.

However, basically we accept the argument that there will be a better compliance ratio in collecting this tax. While we intend to monitor results, the Australian Democrats do not propose to oppose this measure or amend it. Therefore, both Bills will be supported by the us; however, not without amendments that have been foreshadowed.

In the first instance we will move an amendment to seek an exemption from sales tax for products made of 100 per cent recycled plastic, as well as that part of a product that is constituted by 100 per cent recycled plastic. For example, if the door trim of a car is made of recycled plastic, its price will be deducted from the total price of the car and no sales tax will be charged on it.

An example of the products that are currently reaching the market in a somewhat halting flow-because they are competing against other products some of which, like timber, are not subject to the 20 per cent sales tax-is Syntal, which is manufactured by Smorgon Consolidated Industries and is still subject to the 20 per cent sales tax. I understand there has been continuing contact between Smorgon and the Government on these matters-and, I believe, with other manufacturers as well. I have before me some correspondence from Smorgon Consolidated Industries addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Ros Kelly. That correspondence states:
Smorgon Consolidated Industries believe that the recent discussions between industry and government indicated the urgent need for national strategies on waste minimisation and recycling--

It also makes suggestions as to which measures should be taken, apart from the exemption from sales tax of the actual products. It suggests that all equipment that is imported for the purpose of recycling plastic waste should be exempt from duty and any other taxes, and further that capital expenditure on plastic recycling equipment be subject to accelerated depreciation for taxation purposes. Finally, it suggests that research and development grants be substantially increased in respect of the Australian development of new technologies.

We support all of these suggestions, and the Minister might be pleased that, at this stage, we have not fashioned them into amendments. But we will, unless the Government means what it says about sustainable development and beats us to the punch-I wish it would-and introduces some of these measures which are so badly needed. Alas, at the moment, that is not to be.
A little further on, that letter from Smorgon Industries states:

We cannot understand government policy in regard to the imposition of sales tax when on one hand, government supports recycling initiatives, yet on the other hand there is a penalty for those consumers who want to support recycling by``closing the loop'' through purchasing products made from recycled materials.

I trust that these arguments will find their target with Senator Watson and his colleagues, because he stated earlier that he is still open to persuasion and I am doing my darnedest. I trust he will appreciate that.

I have another letter, from Hardeman and Rolls Packaging, a firm in Melbourne which specialises in producing plastic shopping bags from recycled plastic material. We all know how many plastic bags we are inundated with-sometimes they are of practical use-in department stores. Clearly, if some firm takes the initiative and innovatively produces plastic bags from recycled plastic, that firm should have the support of the Australian Parliament, which says that we must support not only innovation but also home-grown industries-once again, let me use the words-to build up a sustainable economy.

I move on to my second amendment, which refers to recycled paper. I have briefly mentioned it before. The amendment seeks to enact a new sub-item (1a) to item 60 in the First Schedule, which will exempt from tax that part of the value of the finished goods which relates to the value of the recycled paper which is part of those finished goods. That simply is closing an omission in the initial legislation, which exempted 100 per cent recycled paper from the sales tax. Currently, it applies only when an item is simply that-totally recycled paper. When dealing with a book which includes added value, such as printing and bookbinding, the item is not currently exempt from sales tax. Clearly, the occasions on which an item is purely composed of 100 per cent recycled paper are rare. To be realistic in our commercial world we must attempt to ensure that this legislation is, in fact, effective and meets the objectives that it sets out to fulfil.

At this stage I will not again run through the arguments as to why that is necessary. It should be obvious to everyone. We have had a debate this afternoon on why it is necessary, but in our view it is totally reprehensible, destructive and, in fact, idiotic to cut down National Estate forests so that we can make paper. Of course, we do not make most of the paper; we cut up the trees into chips, ship them to Japan and then import the finished product.

I now turn to a group of other amendments which will be moved by the Democrats. They concern mainly aids for disabled people. To a large extent they are based on recommendations made by the report of the Industry Commission on aids for disabled people which was delivered in July this year. To some extent I believe the Minister might well take that fact as an excuse-but I think it is a very threadbare one-for saying the Government must continue to consider that report before it can decide whether or not the amendments that we propose are acceptable to it.

I wonder how long the Minister has been in the Senate and whether or not he is aware of the speeches made by Senator Macklin in 1989, by Senator Macklin and Senator Janine Haines in 1988 and by them and other Democrat senators in previous years seeking exemption from sales tax for equipment that is used by disabled people-deaf people, blind people and otherwise handicapped people-who need these aids to enable them to lead as normal lives as they possibly can. All of these appeals in one form or another and, in substance, the amendments that we have sought are very similar indeed, yet those pleas have fallen on deaf ears.

It is not as if these matters would result in a large loss to the Government's tax revenue. In fact, these measures involve single million dollar figures. I remind the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) of the fact-and would appeal to Senator Watson and his colleagues-that a nation is judged by the way in which it treats its most disadvantaged citizens. It is a well known principle ascribed generally to Mr John Rolls as the Rollsian principle of social justice, but I would have thought that the principle is so obvious that it does not need an academic reference.

I turn now briefly to describe the three amendments that we intend to move. The first is to extend the exemption from sales tax to vehicles used by disabled people-for those disabled people who do not use a vehicle simply to go to and from work but who also need a car to enable them to be generally mobile. We believe that it is a question of mobility, not a question of employment for disabled people. Currently the exemption that applies benefits 750 people-that is all-at a cost of $2.3m. If we extend the provision to disabled people who can afford to buy a car-and I assure the Minister that there will not be hundreds and thousands of them-so that they can visit relatives, attend adult education classes, and go to places of entertainment, sporting fixtures and so on, I can assure him that it will not affect revenue by much more than $2m or $3m. Yet I understand that the Government intends to say no to this amendment. How do members of the Government reconcile that with their consciences? I wonder whether Opposition members will step into the breach to teach the Government a lesson.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong. There are some factually incorrect statements about sales tax.
—Currently the cost to the Government on this particular item is $2.3m and it benefits 750 people.
—That is not what you said. You were talking about cars.

—I was talking about cars. Does the honourable senator wish me to repeat it yet again? Let me continue. The next item refers to a matter that has been suggested by the Industry Commission in the wording of the general provision exempting aids and other goods which are used by disabled people. In line with that recommendation, the amendment seeks to modify the current test whereby exemption from sales tax is granted only on goods which are not ordinarily used by people who are not disabled, diseased or ill. It would turn it into a positive formulation so that the exemption would apply to goods which are predominantly used by people who are disabled, diseased or ill. That recommendation is contained in an Industry Commission report of July 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the third amendment concerns section 123a of the first schedule of the exemptions and classifications Act, which deals with aids that assist deaf people to communicate. Some existing examples are interactive and broadcast videotex systems and broadcast teletext decoding devices. The Industry Commission has recommended adding computer equipment used as, or in conjunction with, electronic communications equipment to the list of exemptions under the provision.

All three items are concerned with an attempt to ensure that our most disadvantaged disabled people in the community are allowed to live as normal a life as we can make possible. I believe that it is up to us to do our utmost to ensure that this is possible. It is not as if the Treasurer (Mr Keating) can say, `This will cost $100m or $500m and will demolish my surplus' or anything of the kind. It is a mere pittance and it should be one of our priorities to put the matter right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are tonight debating the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. The legislation seeks to alter the sales tax on certain classes of vehicle and certain types of printed material. However, I wish to confine my brief remarks to the legislation as it affects vehicles.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill comes to us barely six months after we in this place debated the provisions as they related to vehicles, and indeed on the previous occasion when the matter was before us we spent many hours on this matter. The Opposition then told the Government what the effect of the legislation would be, and we are already discussing amending provisions. I remember at the time terming the legislation the `jealousy tax' Bill, and I think that that name still holds good.

The original legislation was a reaction by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the high number of accidents that had occurred in this country, mainly on the eastern seaboard. A number of semitrailers and passenger buses had crashed, and this legislation was probably introduced by the Prime Minister in recognition of the fact that the neglect of the roads by his Government over a period of some six years, added to the neglect of the New South Wales roads by that State's Labor Government, had finally come to fruition. Over the weekend I made a personal inspection of a number of New South Wales roads and my visit bore out what I have always felt, namely, that those roads are unsafe. The legislation sought to raise $100m and an extra $100m was to go back into road funding. However, that is certainly not enough to fix the problem which was in existence six months ago, and following the floods in New South Wales and Queensland such a sum would not be enough to fix the problems in those States.

There are other ways in which to bring down accident figures, especially accidents involving heavier vehicles. I believe that alternative ways were not addressed by the Government. Mr Acting Deputy President, I promise that I will return to the Bill in a moment. I refer to action being taken in respect of driver fatigue, speed, lack of control, drivers' habits and so on. I believe in uniform laws throughout Australia when one is dealing with the heavy vehicles that are on our roads. I believe that heavy vehicles and buses should be governed by the same licensing and driving laws. I would even favour an alcohol limit involving no detectable alcohol in the case of drivers of buses and heavy vehicles. The area involving the driving of private cars could then be left to the States.

Although the Prime Minister did say that the measure would raise an extra $100m, I thought at the time it was another jealousy tax and a measure aimed at picking up some extra votes. Senator McMullan may tell us in his reply just how much extra in revenue the last piece of legislation brought in. I understand that the Bill created a certain reaction and that fewer of the vehicles in question were purchased. Certainly manufacturers carried out measures to get the figure below the threshold. I thought that, because bringing in the present Bill so soon after the previous measure can be seen as a back-down in face of the arguments we have advanced, there would have been a costing of the whole exercise so that we would have some idea as to the funds that may be raised by the present Bill.

The other day I heard Senator McMullan on the national media calling for many amendments to taxation measures. Last weekend or the week before he said that it costs 11 times more in Australia to file or substantiate tax returns than it costs in our trading partner countries. I look forward to seeing some of the amendments that may come through. This measure changes the sales tax level on the wholesale price of a vehicle costing over $30,234 by applying 75 per cent to the amount over that figure. When the value of $54,419 is reached, the overall tax reverts to 50 per cent.

During the last debate, about six months ago, I spoke of four-wheel drive vehicles used in remote areas. These vehicles are subject to this measure. I have never believed that a four-wheel drive in a remote area is a luxury. Rather, it is a necessity. That point has been borne out by the fact-I do not know how long this has applied-that members of parliament from the electorates of Kalgoorlie, Maranoa, Kennedy and Grey are issued with four-wheel drive vehicles as their parliamentary cars at a cost of $6,000 per annum, whereas some people in State parliaments get these vehicles for about $400 or $600 a year. Members of parliament are allowed to purchase these vehicles because they are obviously necessary for them to do their work in their electorates. They need four-wheel drives because of the state of the roads, some of which are not sealed, so I certainly agree that they should be given four-wheel drives to use in those areas.

However, I believe that the people who live in those areas and, of necessity, have to buy four-wheel drives should be given the same consideration. Under this Bill, a four-wheel drive costing over $30,000 certainly fits the bill when it is a goods carrier. In other words, a goods carrying vehicle is not subject to sales tax. This Bill does help those people who purchase a vehicle in the $30,000 to $35,000 bracket. Unfortunately, a vehicle used in remote areas also has to double up as a passenger vehicle. It is all very well for a work vehicle such as a Toyota Land Cruiser tray top to double up as a passenger vehicle, but it is impossible for it to carry more than two people.

Also, very few four-wheel drives cost around $30,000. People have to go to much higher priced vehicles to fit the bill. Then, of course, one pays much more; a Toyota Land Cruiser station sedan type vehicle costs near $50,000 and the Range Rover costs much more. These vehicles can be used in remote areas as well as doubling up as passenger vehicles to take the family into town or carry men to work. But these vehicles are still carrying the burdens of a sales tax and a luxury tax.

Can honourable senators tell me what is luxurious about a Land Cruiser station sedan that carries seven or eight people? I suppose they are considered luxury vehicles because there has been a propensity for the more affluent to buy them. These vehicles are used as RVs-if I can use an American term I picked up which means `recreation vehicle'-to run around on weekends even though they are used on bitumen roads. But the sales tax is applied to those vehicles that are used in remote areas.

I do not see why those two categories of use should be treated identically, especially when one vehicle is used for recreation and the other as a necessity. I know that certain imported four-wheel drives cost around the threshold mark. These are generally utilities which cannot carry too many passengers. Just below the Toyota Land Cruiser is the Toyota Hi-Lux dual cab which can carry a driver and four passengers. Of course, that vehicle attracts sales tax as well as this extra tax, as has been pointed out.

As I have said, the Government has a lot of thinking to do on this. People who use four-wheel drives in remote areas of necessity should not be treated the same as those who use their vehicles elsewhere. The Government picked this up too hastily because of the serious accidents on the roads. The immediate reaction was, `How can we fix it? We need more money to be spent on roads. We'll try out a luxury vehicle tax'. I am afraid it has thrown things out of kilter.

Levies on road fuel have been continually rising. They are now rising at a far greater rate because of the Gulf crisis. The Government is having quite a windfall. I have called for the Government to pass on to the motorists some of the windfall that it receives now that the price is above the Budget forecast of $US23 a barrel. If it does not want to pass any back to the consumer, it should at least provide extra road funding.

I quickly take up a point made by Senator Spindler who argued that there should be no sales tax on fully recycled plastic. That is the trouble with vehicles these days-there is too much plastic in them. This is unsafe. When these vehicles are involved in accidents they seem to fold up. I suppose I could support his argument because recapped tyres-correct me if I am wrong-do not carry sales tax. I do not know whether I have missed any changes on that. But I believe that that sort of thing is nitpicking. We have a total overall problem. If the Government wants to spend more money on roads, it should get it from the money it is already raising.

From seeing this Bill and other Bills I believe that the Government is using a piecemeal approach in order to get money for roads or to do something like that. It is time that the Government looked totally at the sales tax system. We on this side of politics have an agenda for that the next time around, and I believe it is time that the whole sales tax system disappeared as it has been getting worse and worse and more and more out of kilter. I think the way to go is the goods and services tax, by which everything will be treated the same right across the board, so that we will not be here every six months passing a new piece of legislation to pothole this and to pothole that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wouldn't bet on that.

—Even Senator Foreman will fully admit that this has not been a great exercise by the Government this time. It is not prepared to attack the sales tax system. Perhaps it will admit that we have a much better system with the goods and services tax, which will iron out these problems and will not use potholing measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill are a damning indictment of this Government's indirect tax system, of its car industry policy, and of its attempt to rouse the politics of envy in support of a discriminatory and completely unjustified tax. Despite strong opposition from the coalition, legislation was passed in May of this year to give effect to the March Federal election campaign announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he would increase the rate of sales tax on what he called luxury cars-that is, those with a then wholesale value of more than $30,234 representing a retail price of more than $42,910, now adjusted with inflation to $45,056-from an already discriminatory 30 per cent to a massive 50 per cent. Let us not forget that cars below that value are taxed at only 20 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the complete absence of any economic rationale or any other justification for these changes, this Government through that legislation also increased the complexity of our tax system which, contrary to needing increased complexity, in fact needs drastic simplification. Barely three months later, the Treasurer, on Budget night, announced further changes which increased this unwanted complexity. Tonight's legislation in part, as well as dealing with other matters, gives effect to those changes. The changes mean that instead of a 50 per cent sales tax applying to the whole price of vehicles with a retail value above $45,056, cars above that value will be taxed at 30 per cent on the first $45,056 and then 75 per cent on every dollar above $45,056 up to $97,429. Cars above $97,429 will be taxed under the same provisions as introduced in May; that is, at the rate of 50 per cent on the total value. If that sounds confusing, it is.

When I spoke on the original legislation in May, apart from condemning its arbitrary nature, I said that the Government had to be able to answer three questions in the affirmative to justify this increased tax. Those questions were: Firstly, was an increase in an already discriminatory tax justified? Secondly, was it consistent with the Button car plan? Thirdly, were the revenue assumptions of the Treasurer correct? The clear answer to each of those questions was no.

So the legislation had absolutely no justification. All the consequences of that legislation have confirmed that the negative answers to those three questions were fully justified. But instead of cancelling it, this out of touch Hawke Australian Labor Party Government has introduced the legislation which we are debating tonight which compounds the problems rather than corrects them.

The Treasurer's revenue assumptions have been clearly proved wrong. I predicted this would be the case when I spoke in this chamber in May and that prediction has been proven correct. The Government's objective of incremental revenue is not based on the realities of the marketplace. It has based its calculations on the selling rates of these vehicles for the 1988-89 financial year.

To give a single example: in the first half of 1989, one vehicle importer was selling on average 272 units per month of vehicles priced above the threshold. In June and July of this year the running rate was 43 vehicles per month; a massive collapse, and of course all of those were still selling at the lower price, because their wholesale sales tax had been paid before the legislation came into effect.

The Government claims that the net effect of the change it is introducing through this legislation tonight will be a loss of only some $8m in revenue off its previous target of an additional $100m, but that $100m has already been proven unattainable. In the financial year 1988-89, which was the basis used for the targeted increase, the annual selling rate of imported vehicles above the threshold price was 15,400 units, which resulted in a total estimated government revenue of $446.6m. However, what the Government did not take into account was the effect of the downturn that hit this market segment from September 1989. The annualised running rate in the period September 1989 to February 1990 was 10,950 units on vehicles above the threshold price. This equates to a total annual government revenue of some $317.6m on the 30 per cent tax base.

In June and July of 1990 the annualised running rate was some 6,050 units and that would provide only $242m in government revenue based on the 50 per cent tax base. However, it is unlikely that many would have been sold at the new tax levels. Most would have been pre-sold in the period prior to the increase in the sales tax rate at the old rate of 30 per cent. On this basis, the revenue could be as low as $175.5m on an annualised basis. I seek leave, and I have already spoken to Senator McMullan, to have incorporated in Hansard two graphs.

Despite the fact that the predictions of this graph have thus far been fulfilled and that, as I have said, the graphs are probably optimistic in terms of the likely sales of cars and the consequential revenue that will be gained, the Government continues to ignore the fact that it has killed this segment of the market through excessive taxation. That in itself is a disturbing development. As can be seen, currently the annualised rate is a little more than 5,000 vehicles and that, it is expected, will continue for the foreseeable future. At best, it is expected that the annualised rate will not recover to much more than 8,500 vehicles whose price is over the tax threshold. That will realise revenue of some $340m based on a 50 per cent sales tax rate on all vehicles over the threshold.

The Government has claimed, in introducing this legislation, that it will lose only $8m in revenue. One presumes that is off its original estimate of $546.6m. With that relatively minor adjustment in tax, the incremental volume effect is likely to offset the lost tax due to the reduction. That leaves the Government with an annualised revenue of $340m from these cars-well below its new target of $538.6m. So much for the promised source of $100m of extra revenue that was to be devoted to improving Australia's roads.

Current projections indicate that annual revenue from these cars will be at least $150m below the level required by the Government for this tax year. The Treasurer, in his Budget press release, stated that the additional revenue from the higher tax will still provide increased road funding. But when one clearly examines the actual market information, it soon becomes evident that without a price reduction of over 80 per cent in this sector of the car market, there will in fact be no revenue generated and the $100m which was promised for extra road funding is a pie in the sky promise.

If the Treasurer thinks that the new policy will be only a small cost to revenue of $8m in 1990-91, as he claimed in his Budget press release, and thereby implies that $92m rather than $100m additional revenue will be obtained, it simply reinforces the point that this Government has ignored the fact that over $150m has already been lost in the 1990-91 tax year in terms of revenue against the Government's original estimates.

It would seem that the Treasurer in particular and the Government in general simply do not understand that this discriminatory, iniquitous 50 per cent car tax has totally crippled this segment of the car market and that without sales tax and duty the revenue cannot be forthcoming. That sales tax and duty have simply been forgone as a result of the combination of this iniquitous tax impost and the impact of high interest rates on the car market.

An assessment of the market for cars between the retail value of $45,057 and $97,429 clearly demonstrates also the protectionist nature of the changes we are debating. It simply reinforces the point I made in May that this car tax is directly contrary to the intent of the Button car plan. In general terms, this segment of the car market is highly polarised, with the locally produced Ford LTD and Holden Caprice accounting for the bulk of sales at the lower end of the price bracket under $65,000.

The major beneficiaries of the revised tax structure which this legislation introduces are the vehicles priced in the $50,000 to $65,000 price segment. However, this represents only 18.7 per cent of the market segment over the threshold and 10.8 per cent of that, which is more than half, are those two locally produced vehicles. These locally manufactured vehicles will benefit from a price reduction of between 8 and 12 per cent under the changes brought about by the legislation.

The balance of the market, which is those cars priced between $65,000 and $95,000, which represent more than 80 per cent of the market between the $45,000 threshold and $95,000, will benefit, at most, by a price reduction of less than 6 per cent. Indeed, two-thirds of that group will benefit by a price reduction of no more than 3.6 per cent. Needless to say, all vehicles in the more than $65,000 price category are imported vehicles.

The massive price increases imposed on these vehicles by the increase in sales tax to a discriminatory 50 per cent in May therefore, to all and intents and purposes, will remain. On the other hand, the amendments introduced by this legislation mean that the Australian manufactured vehicles previously also caught by this rapacious tax impost will now be affected only to the tune of 2 to 3 1/2 per cent compared with their pre-May prices. So, in practical terms, the new policy alleviates pricing pressure on the locally built Holden Caprice and Ford LTD, almost returning them to their previous 30 per cent sales tax levels.

But for the majority of vehicles over the tax threshold, the retail price reduction will be minimal or nil. In effect, through these changes the Treasurer has, yet again, raised the protection levels of locally built cars, even more than the original tax increases did in May. How dare this failed Treasurer criticise Senator Button for dragging the chain in reducing protection when he is introducing this blatantly protectionist measure?

To quantify this, the theoretical retail pricing effect on a $58,490 Ford LTD would be a reduction in the vicinity of $5,500, equal to nearly 15 per cent reduction in sales tax; whereas vehicles which are priced at above $85,000 would benefit by a reduction of as little as $1,400, or a mere 1.6 per cent. Add to that the normal optional extra fitting ratio of about $4,500, which is now taxed at 75 per cent, and the net price reduction potential is less than $500, or 0.5 per cent on that $85,000 motor vehicle.

The new tax structure will create total chaos in the pricing of optional extras with vehicles between $45,056 and $97,429 having to be priced individually. As a result of this legislation there will be three different option prices: category A, based on 20 per cent tax for vehicles under $45,056; category B, based on 75 per cent tax on vehicles between $45,057 and $97,429; and category C, based on 50 per cent tax on vehicles over $97,429.

In addition to this confusion, there will be the added turmoil, firstly, that a vehicle in category A with options added which take it over the threshold will be subject to an incremental 10 per cent on the whole vehicle price and the option price will increase due to a tax change from 20 per cent to a massive 75 per cent; secondly, if options added to a vehicle in category B take it over the price of $97,429, the tax on options fitted reduces from 75 per cent to 50 per cent-some logic in that; and, thirdly, options on vehicles priced at more than $97,429 will be cheaper than on vehicles whose prices are some $50,000 less than that, an example being that a sun roof on a BMW 525i will be 14 per cent more expensive than the same sun roof on a BMW 535i or BMW 7 series.

So the 30 per cent and 75 per cent sales tax mixture will be applicable under this legislation to vehicles between $45,056 and $97,429 at retail price. That makes a complete mockery of the pricing of optional extras. How ridiculous to have the option of an electric sun roof on one model being taxed at 75 per cent, whereas the identical option on another model will be taxed at 50 per cent, or indeed at 20 per cent. The practical problems associated with explaining these price differences and anomalies to customers is a communications problem seemingly ignored by the Treasurer and his advisers closeted in Canberra away from the real world.

This legislation completely ignores the three basic principles of tax legislation that it should be fair, efficient and simple. It should have come as no surprise to the Treasurer, as he claimed in his press release on Budget night, that the 50 per cent tax introduced in May had led to the deletion of safety items in some cases to reduce the vehicle price below the higher sales tax threshold. The Treasurer ascribed these deletions to the so-called discontinuity caused by his initial changes whereby the 50 per cent tax rate applying, instead of 20 per cent, once the threshold price was reached, caused an immediate price increase of $9,070.

This legislation does not remove that so-called discontinuity as far as optional extras are concerned and so will not eliminate the practice of deleting safety items. In fact, the chaos now introduced in pricing optional extras will worsen the situation with regard to safety items. Under this Bill, at the threshold, the tax on the whole vehicle increases from 20 per cent to 30 per cent, while the tax on the option increases from 20 per cent to 75 per cent. This is hardly an incentive to change the option fitting policy of a vehicle marketer.

For example, let us take a car priced at the threshold at $45,055 and add an option such as anti-lock brakes at a cost of $2,320. The cost of fitting anti-lock brakes which should cost $2,320 will, in fact, be an enormous $6,199. So it will cost substantially more to fit a safety feature such as this to a car just below the threshold. In addition, it will cost more to fit it on a vehicle under the $97,500 retail price than it will on one above that price. There is, therefore, still no incentive to fit additional items, including very important safety items, to lower priced vehicles.

Even if this Government continues with its manic determination to tax quality, this should not as well become a tax on safety. Safety related items such as anti-lock brakes, air bags and seat belts should be allowed to be brought in free of duty and free of sales tax. These inequities again point to the artificial and anachronistic depreciation limit, from which this additional tax rate is levied, to which I referred in my remarks on the May legislation. I will not repeat those comments. It is certainly timely that I again reinforce the demand that this anachronistic limit be scrapped if Australia is serious about bringing about a productive local manufacturing industry, capable of exporting vehicles to other countries, with vehicles competitive in terms of cost and quality.

To summarise, the fact that this new policy does bring the retail price of some vehicles down and brings an element of progressiveness to bear, thereby eliminating to some extent the large no-man's- land which the May legislation introduced, by no means offsets the many disadvantages of this legislation, which I have outlined in my remarks. In essence, the policy is flawed because it relies on a Clayton's revenue projection-a revenue projection which will simply not be achieved; it further discriminates against imported vehicles; it will cause confusion in the marketplace; and, most importantly, as I have just explained, it still discriminates against the fitting of optional extras and, in particular, safety related items. The Treasurer is either being devilishly clever or he completely misunderstands the nature of the car industry in introducing these changes to the legislation and, indeed, in persisting with the discriminatory sales tax announced in March and which began operation with the legislation which was passed in May.

This legislation simply reinforces the need for a complete overhaul of the indirect taxation system, which has applied in Australia for many years, and it simply reinforces the justification which the coalition has for announcing that when it forms government, which will now be a certainty after the next election, it will introduce a goods and services tax, a form of indirect taxation, which will replace this motley range of indirect wholesale sales taxes which we currently have, and will also allow substantial reductions in income tax, as well as offsetting compensation.

That simply is the highlight of this legislation-the need for the substitution of that goods and services tax for this unholy mess which we have in the form of a wholesale sales tax. As I said, the way in which it is being applied in the car industry is discriminatory, it is totally unjustified, it is contrary to the directions which the Button car plan sought to set for the Australian car industry and, above all, the revenue projections, which were the reason which the Treasurer introduced this legislation to get an extra $100m for road funds, will not be realised. There is no way in which this legislation can be justified and it simply should not be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, the Senate has before it this evening in a Budget session a Bill to adjust the sales tax. Whether or not these adjustments have been mechanical or contentious, they have provided an annual ritual that has led many of us to question the efficiency of a tax that continually creates anomalies.

SPEECH.PARA: A great continuing evil of sales tax is its manipulation by this Government, either to increase revenue by stealth or to score points through cheap symbolism. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 before us tonight adjusts one such move made earlier this year when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) felt the political need to reinvent his populist credentials by throwing a punitive tax on the sorts of cars that only more affluent Australians can supposedly afford to buy. The politics of envy by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats are obviously alive and very much well. The fact that this Bill is now necessary to introduce a phasing-in period for the 50 per cent luxury rate of tax only reminds us that the original legislation was a hasty and cynical political move, as is so much of the tax legislation that is introduced into this Parliament.

Throughout its term of office the approach of the Hawke Labor Government towards indirect taxation has been a saga of opportunism, cowardice and hypocrisy. What was to be an essential plank of taxation reform in 1985 is now damned by the Treasurer and the Government because the coalition is moving towards a more logical, equitable and honest form of indirect tax. It was after all the Treasurer who, on 3 July 1985, told the National Taxation Summit that `by cutting out the broad-based consumption tax we cut the heart out of the package'. They were the Treasurer's words, not my words, and now because his political masters-the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-have told him to back down he is retreating at a rate of knots. It is a matter of record that the Government beat a political retreat after that pressure from its political masters, the ACTU, but the Treasurer cannot convince anyone that what was logical and right in 1985 is an unjust tax in 1990.

It was the Treasurer who declared himself to have been in favour of an indirect tax from his first days in office and who dismissed criticisms of his 1985 indirect tax proposition as `divided, sectional and too uncompromising in tone'. It was the Treasurer who proclaimed the virtue of a `single rate, exemption-free tax, particularly in the supermarket context'. Such a tax `would create the foundations for a more efficient system to promote stronger economic growth and higher living standards'. They were his words. How different the world is today.

In one important sense the Hawke Labor Government has been consistent in its attitude towards indirect tax. It may have run abjectly from the 1985 proposal for a goods and services tax, but it has deliberately sought to increase its revenue from the existing, underhand, wholesale sales tax.

In reality it has not run away from its proposals of 1985 to introduce a consumption tax; it has simply called it something else. It has simply masqueraded under the wholesale sales tax system. We know that to be true, but unfortunately because of the way in which it is done year after year, little by little-sometimes not so little by little-most Australians do not understand that this form of consumption tax exists. Very few people who go to the supermarket or buy something on a day-to-day basis realise how much consumption tax they are already paying. We have five levels of consumption tax in this country: zero, 10 per cent, 20 per cent, 30 per cent and 50 per cent, all of which have been implemented under this Government. But the Government says, `No, we do not have a consumption tax'.

In 1982-83, the last year of the coalition Government, sales tax comprised 8.5 per cent of total taxation revenue. By 1989-90, it had risen to 11.2 per cent. That equates to $10.1 billion out of $90.5 billion. Under the Hawke Labor Government total tax revenue rose 122 per cent to 1989-90. Sales tax-the Labor Government's form of consumption tax-has risen by a massive 190 per cent. In five Labor Budgets, sales tax receipts increased ahead of total tax revenue, but nobody realises it because it is done quietly and surreptitiously.

We have seen a government that lacks the courage to reform the system but has broadened sales tax by stealth. This Labor Government has extended sales tax to previously exempt items, such as flavoured milk, fruit juices, household disinfectants, skin lotions, sun screens, photographic film and ice-cream. It has doubled sales tax on hand gardening tools and household wrapping material. It is interesting that the Government has put a sales tax on sun screens at a time when taxpayers' money is being spent trying to convince people not to get skin cancers. On the one hand the Government spends taxpayers' money telling people to use good sun screens, while on the other hand it increases sales tax on those products. They used to be exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what you are talking about.

—Is that so? Let Senator McMullan deny that the Government has now put a sales tax on a previously exempt item-sun screens. Let him also deny that the taxpayers have not been spending money over the past umpteen years to convince people to drink less alcohol. Yet, low alcohol beer that previously used to be exempt now attracts a tax of 20 per cent. Senator McMullan cannot deny that; that happens to be fact. That happens to be the Government's form of a consumption tax. The Government promotes a higher use of sun screens, it promotes a greater consumption of low alcohol beer, and then it taxes both of them, which were previously tax exempt. It is just absolute and utter duplicity. These are the facts that expose the hollowness of such grandstanding exercises as the 50 per cent impost on luxury vehicles-luxury vehicles deemed to be luxury by their value, not by their accessories, not by their features, but by their value. The politics of envy again!

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast to this newfound rhetoric, the actions of the Hawke Labor Government show a determination to extend indirect taxes to a range of items routinely purchased by ordinary Australians and those which particularly affect families with children. As I mentioned before just to prove a point, we have items that used to be exempt which the family buys for children: flavoured milk, fruit juices, sun screens and, of course, ice-creams; let us not forget them. Because they are consumed by children in a fairly high quantity, the Government says, `Let's tax them as well'. But then it says, `No, we will not have a consumption tax'.

Sales tax may prove quietly useful to this Hawke Labor Government, but it defies logic and credibility for it to mount a defence of a tax that in 1985 the Treasurer rightly described as anomaly ridden. Nothing has changed. Sales tax is essentially selective in its impact on national economic life, imposing a particular burden on the transport and equipment sectors and hampering exports at a time when Australia's gross foreign debt of $156 billion has reached 39 per cent of gross domestic product.

Then again, this Government does not seem to care that we are uncompetitive internationally while it pursues economic policies that send producers broke. The coalition simply cannot accept what the Government implicitly upholds: that we can afford the $1 billion added to the cost of exports as a result of sales tax. Once again I state: the Government does not care that we are uncompetitive. It does not seem to care that it is sending the primary producers and all the small businesses in this country broke and that those sectors cannot afford to produce products that can be exported viably.

It was a tragedy for me to be talking to people last Friday week who now have to have things produced in Malaysia because they cannot afford to have them produced in Australia and viably exported. It is absurd for any Labor or Democrat senator-both parties, I might add, are hooked on higher taxes-to prattle about any supposed greater equity in sales tax as opposed to a goods and services tax, when the services sector attracting the spending of the more affluent section of the community currently escapes indirect tax. It is essentially dishonest to pretend that ordinary Australians who will pay a goods and services tax do not already meet the end cost of indirect taxes through sales tax.

The Treasurer was more honest in 1985 when he described sales tax as `mostly a tax on Australian household goods' and stated the truth that all necessities must be purchased from income depleted by income tax. Never a truer word was said. The Treasurer is otherwise known as `Bracket creep' because of the bracket creep that has gone on in 7 1/2 years of this Government-7 1/2 years of bracket creep where people's disposable income, the money they have left after paying the enormous taxes put on them by this Government, has diminished.

When Labor now tries to terrify retirees and low income earners regarding a goods and services tax, we might recall that in 1985 the Treasurer promised that such people would be better off as part of the general package centred on a broad based indirect tax. How he has changed his tune again. When the Treasurer actually boasts that sales tax has grown under this Labor Government, the question can only be asked as to why the next logical step is not taken and an Australian goods and services tax introduced in line with 21 of the 24 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries that have a broad based indirect tax in place. Why the Treasurer considers increasing sales taxes by 190 per cent as a good move is beyond comprehension, other than to say that the reason he does it is that most people do not know he is doing it.

As we debate this sales tax legislation we should ask: What specific compensation has been offered to low income earners by this Government, as it has extended sales tax to everyday items? In contrast, it will be an essential feature of a goods and services tax that compensation be given to those adversely affected along with a reduction in personal income tax for all other income earners. The Treasurer can try to fool Australians with the specious claim that all of his supposedly wonderful reforms since 1985 make indirect tax reform unnecessary. Yet the fact remains that income tax now accounts for 72 per cent of tax receipts compared with 66 per cent in 1985-86. That is not what I would call a fairer tax system.

In 1985, the Treasurer accused the tax system of being recognised as unfair and as failing to reward initiative. If he thought that that was what the tax system was in 1985, heaven only knows what he thinks it is now-but he is not game enough to say so. How right he was when on 19 June 1985 he stated:
Unless we find another major base in the tax system, and tax expenditure in some way, then it will be the ordinary working people who will carry the burden.

That was prophetic, was it not, because it is the ordinary person who is carrying the burden today. Ask any taxpayers whether they think they are better off today than they were back in 1985 when the Treasurer said those words. But how he has changed his tune now just to appease his political masters, the ACTU. Not only was that statement logical, but, as I say, it was most prophetic. Australians with incomes 15 per cent above average weekly earnings pay tax at the top marginal rate and revenue under this Labor Government has fed quietly on that well recognised bracket creep.

Of course, the average Australian is told that he lives in the best possible of all taxation worlds, and that he or she must beware of the goods and services tax bogey. At least with goods and services tax the taxpayers would know how much tax they are paying; they would know if it were to be increased, which is certainly not the case today.

I challenge any opponent of the principle of a goods and services tax to say with a straight face what is equitable and logical about the wholesale sales tax that will be abolished by a Liberal government as an essential step towards a goods and services tax. Is it in the long term interests of Australia that Parliament year after year debate the tinkering of a form of indirect tax that affects only some businesses and that was designed as a luxury tax in the 1930s? It is certainly no luxury tax now when it starts taxing things like children's ice-creams. It ignores the contemporary business reality that some wholesalers have become their own retailers and can shift the profit margin beyond the point where tax is applied.

Just what is fair and sensible about a 30 per cent tax on cameras, photographic equipment and household clocks, while exempting antique clocks? Why should a tool box attract 20 per cent sales tax when expensive clothing like Italian suits is exempt; and chocolate biscuits attract 10 per cent sales tax when caviar attracts no tax? How can anyone describe that as a fair taxation system?

I suppose the answer for the Government would simply be, `Okay, we will tax the lot, but we will tax it at a luxury rate, just as we are doing with this luxury car tax-whack it up at 50 per cent'. As I say, it just comes back to the politics of envy of the Labor Party and the Democrats. The only answer is a new honest system of indirect taxation, not open to the special pleading and sleight of hand of this Government. No-one puts the case better than the Treasurer in describing `the current anomaly ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector'.

Today the Treasurer gives unspecified administrative difficulties as to why services cannot be taxed, ignoring the fact that most of our competitors have managed to do so in all but financial services. But he obviously cannot exercise his mind that far. He was able to do so in 1985, but he cannot really do so now because the ACTU will not let him. The coalition is unimpressed by the announced review that will supposedly simplify sales tax and examine relief for business inputs.

A simpler tax system-that is what we were promised in 1983 before this Government even came to office. Yet we have had thousands upon thousands of pages of tax regulations and amendments and additions in 7 1/2 years. Creating more pieces of legislation, to this Government, is a way of making the taxation system more simple. Talk to any accountant or businessman and see whether they think it is more simple. Talk to the individual taxpayer and see whether he can now do his own tax return or whether he has to get an accountant to do it-that is the result of the Treasurer's simplified tax promise in 1983.

All of this simply acknowledges what the Opposition has been saying as to the inefficiency and inequity of sales tax. What we have seen over the last 7 1/2 years of this Labor Government is a Clayton's goods and services tax. A rise in sales tax over that time of 190 per cent is proof positive. This Bill and scores of its predecessors should convince rational observers that what is required is not more tinkering with sales tax but its replacement with a broad-based, equitable and honest indirect tax. Australians simply cannot afford to be hit with more sales taxes at the rate at which this Government is increasing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to start by thanking the speakers on behalf of the coalition and the Australian Democrats, Senators Watson and Spindler, for their support of the Bill at its second reading stage-notwithstanding they may have made other comments about the Bill to which I will respond in a moment. SPEECH.PARA: I want to not delay the chamber for too long but to respond to some of the reasonably important points that were made by some of the speakers. I will not get into some of the political vitriol that dripped a little later in the debate, but I might deal with some of the earlier and substantive points that were made.

I want to say something about four-wheel drive vehicles, which were referred to by Senator Watson and Senator Panizza. It has been argued that there is some unfairness with regard to the way in which the sales tax rate might fall on four-wheel drive vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —For certain types of people.

—I understand that it was for people in remote areas, et cetera, and that there may be some problem with that. So it affected only the very up-market four-wheel drives. SPEECH.PARA: I appreciated the remarks which Senator Watson made about sales tax simplification. I think what he said is correct, and I appreciate it and thank him for it. The whole process of simplification goes on apace; it may not in all circumstances be proceeding at the pace which Senator Watson would prefer, but the process proceeds and will continue to proceed.

Referring to some of the things to which Senator Spindler referred, he did draw attention to-and Senator Watson made some fleeting reference to-possible loopholes in the way in which the newspaper insert section has been drafted. That is a matter, of course, which we will have to look at, but at this stage it is envisaged that it will achieve its purpose and we will keep that under review.

Senator Spindler's amendments we will debate at the committee stage, so I will not duplicate that the Government will not be accepting any of those amendments. They are more appropriately matters that should be dealt with after a wider community consultation and after a priority setting exercise where the Government has reviewed the priorities which it wants to set, consistent with the general view that in many of these matters, though not all of the ones in the amendments, it is usually better to deal with providing assistance to the people to whom the Government tries to target such assistance through revenue matters rather than through tax deductions. Certainly in some of the matters that were raised by Senator Spindler I think that would be more appropriate. I will not say any more now; we will deal with it in the committee stage. I simply indicate that we will not be supporting those amendments.

There was some discussion about the revenue outcome of the previous change and the revenue consequences of this change. It is difficult to make a long term assessment of that because, of course, sometimes purchases are merely deferred. If one looks at a six-month period, one may say that there was a decline in revenue because there were fewer purchases of such vehicles. But it may be that if one looks at figures over one or two years, there is simply a trend of decline. It may be caused by other factors to do with the state of the economy and in the long term there may be a significant revenue enhancement. Even if there were to be a transfer of purchases to lower cost vehicles, those, of course, are not sales tax exempt. They are just taxed at a lower rate. There would be some increased sale tax revenue under the other classifications.

So the hyperbole we hear about revenue is a bit inappropriate. I have to say that I cannot imagine very many Australians shedding tears because we have a situation in which there are fewer imported luxury motor vehicles coming into Australia than there were before. I certainly do not. I do not regard that as a disastrous outcome or as a matter about which we ought to be wringing our hands. I can understand why the Opposition might be concerned that the Ferrari-led recovery is in a bit of trouble, but the rest of us are not.

I was interested in the call by Senator Chapman for safety items to be free of sales tax because he then went on to advocate a broadly based consumption tax. A broadly based consumption tax, apart from its other shortcomings, gives away the capacity of government to discriminate in that way. It consciously abandons the weapon that the Opposition purports to be one of its strengths. Certainly, it does remove the capacity to do that. It may be that Senator Chapman has a good point on the safety issue. That is a matter for another debate. I simply say that the Opposition has to stop trying to have it both ways. It must stop trying to say that we should have this broadly based consumption tax at a uniform rate while raising particular proposals for exemptions. Of course, there is a basic inconsistency in that position and it will be exposed over the years.

The description of this situation applies equally well to debate about issues to do with the environment. It is impossible to argue that there ought to be tax concessions through the sales tax system for environmentally conscious activities and at the same time advocate a broadly based consumption tax. The two are mutually exclusive. I have to say that to hear the impassioned defence of the luxury motor vehicle market in the context of an advocacy of a broadly based consumption tax only reinforces my view that I cannot have much sympathy for a tax proposal that reduces the price of Rolls Royces and puts up the price of a bread roll. I really think that those priorities are wrong.

Senator Knowles's contribution in the main does not warrant a response, but I do want to clarify one thing because she made a factual error that could mislead people. She talked about the tax on sun screens. I interjected but I did not want to pursue the matter in detail at that stage. I simply read into the record a section from the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Act. In respect of preparations, the section states:
. . . that are put up and sold for use as substances to be applied to the skin for the purpose of screening out solar ultra-violet rays, but not including . . .

It goes on to exclude certain cosmetics in respect of which there is a certificate saying that it provides an acceptable level of protection from solar ultraviolet rays. These are exempt from sales tax at the moment. I say to Senator Knowles that I doubt that they would be exempt from a broadly based consumption tax but I understand her concern. It is a pity that she does not understand her own argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —You changed that in 1983 or 1984 and took off a number of cosmetics which had strong sun screen bases.

—It is true that Senator Reid seems to understand the distinction; Senator Knowles did not. I am merely reading it into the record because anybody who had heard or read her speech would have misunderstood the circumstance. I am trying to make the record accurate. That is the situation. I do not want to go on at any great length. Because there is no opposition to the second reading of the Bill it would be inappropriate to do more than say, once again, that we will not be supporting the amendments in the committee stage and thank the speakers for their contribution.
