TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to speak for a while about the visit I have just undertaken in the company of three other senators-Senator Giles, Senator Vallentine and Senator Crowley- together with the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senators Vallentine and Crowley have already explained, we went there as a delegation of Federal female politicians at the invitation of the Soviet Women's Committee. I think the invitation was extended to us for two reasons: first, so that we, in this Parliament, could have a better idea of the problems and the challenges facing the Soviet nation in this time of enormous change; and, secondly, to see what advice we could offer and help we could give as women members of parliament to those who are trying to introduce democracy and a market economy in the Soviet Union.

At the very beginning, I express my appreciation of the members of the Soviet Women's Committee who were our hosts for the entire time we were in the Soviet Union. I especially express my appreciation to Galina Negrustuyeva and Vera Soboleva from the Soviet Women's Committee, who organised the program, and to Ellen Mitriaeva and Tania Anisimova, who were our interpreters. My colleagues have already paid tribute to these women, who really were essential to making this a most successful visit to the Soviet Union.

What did we do in the 10 days that we were there? In those 10 days, we spent almost every waking moment talking with Soviet citizens-men and women in the cities of Moscow and Leningrad- learning about the Soviet Union today. We met deputies at the national, republic, city and district council levels. We met journalists, generals, doctors, housewives, members of the intelligentsia, kindergarten teachers, people in industry and agriculture, communists and former communists, non-communists, human rights activists and veterans. We encountered a wide range of people and a wide range of views.

I do not pretend to speak for my colleagues on the delegation but some lessons that I learnt as the 10 days in the Soviet Union progressed were lessons which I have carried away with me. First and foremost is the clear demonstration of the failure of communism. If any evidence of that was needed, it was the rout of the Communist Party in the votes cast in the assemblies in the last 12 months. Time after time we were given details of how the Communist Party was not supported by the people at the last elections.

Secondly, time and time again clear evidence was given of how central control had failed. That, of course, is a major issue facing the Soviet Government, which I hoped would have been announced today. I have not heard whether Mr Gorbachev has made an announcement about the future of central control, but it was expected today. We saw it in such areas as the failure of the delivery of food to the people in those vast cities of Leningrad and Moscow. I understand that this is the case throughout the country.

We saw it in the inability or the unwillingness of the bureaucracy to ensure that not only the crops are grown but also that they are safely stored and delivered to the consumers. We saw it in visiting a hospital where, until recently, every minor decision had to be referred to Moscow; where there was a question of how many pharmaceuticals would be bought and how much linen would be procured. The decision as to whether the linen was needed was laid down from Moscow, and there were no arguments about it.

We found it also in talking to a young woman of entrepreneurial spirit who, with a group of her colleagues, had set up a travel agency in competition with Intourist. She told us how the only way that the travel agency could deal directly and immediately with the outside world was by telex, because all faxes and all overseas telephone calls had to go through Moscow adding enormously to the delays and the bureaucratic frustrations of people inside and outside the Soviet Union trying to do business. Time and time again central control was demonstrated to have been a failure.

State ownership has failed and that was also very clear in talking to some of the people who were involved in enterprises in the country. There has been a lack of foresight in ploughing back money made by enterprises into the redevelopment; whether it was to provide environmental controls, better equipment or whether it was to go with the new technology into the future. There has been a distinct failure in a state-owned enterprise to put the money aside to make sure that the future is productive.

We found interestingly in those state-owned enterprises that in very recent times they decided that they had to do something about labour and initiative. I was intrigued on three occasions to be told that the labour force now had contracts negotiated-in one case it was one-year contracts-and the wages were reasonably good but that there were incentive schemes built on a base wage. The incentive schemes varied from the hospital I mentioned earlier where doctors and nurses had to be able to give evidence that they had given quality medical care and that their patients had not returned within a short period with the same complaint, to the industrial concern where the workers had to demonstrate that they had had accident free days, that they had turned out a quality product and that they had increased their productivity.

We found in a joint venture a similar scheme for a base rate of salary coupled with incentive payments, and these had been negotiated at the enterprise level with the workers. Until now, of course, when productivity had not been such a vital issue and the state controlled all enterprises, these had not been the way forward. I would think that the Labor Government in Australia could learn something from the direction that these labour contracts are going in the Soviet Union.

Another thing that I found of interest was the failure of affirmative action, and by that I mean the failure of quotas for women. In the Soviet political system, since 1917 when women were given a constitutionally equal place in society, there has been an unofficial quota system whereby women get between 30 and 50 per cent of all deputies positions in the various parliaments in the country. However, with the coming of the democratic elections in the last 12 months, these quotas have now been abolished- disappointingly, of course. For instance on the Leningrad City Council only 26 women out of 400 deputies were elected in the recent election, compared with 300 out of 600 in the previous Leningrad City Council. That story was repeated to us wherever we met deputies in the various soviets or parliaments.

The women in the Soviet Union were very concerned about this, as we are in this country when there are not sufficient women in our parliaments. But, clearly, it is not a remedy to put women there in artificial positions because increasingly, as we got to know what had been happening in the Soviet Union, we found that those women who had been there in substantial numbers had not necessarily effected better conditions of either employment or health for the women they represented. One would have expected that they might be in a position to do more for the health and for the occupational health and safety of the women that we heard about.

Those were some lessons that I found very dramatic: the failure of communism; the failure of central control; the failure of state ownership; and the failure of affirmative action. I also learnt a great lesson on the hunger for information on democracy and small business. The women we met were desperate to know just how they could get more women into Parliament; how women in this country go into Parliament; whether they should opt for a women's party; whether they should go back to quotas; and whether they should have political clubs, as they have already established, to try to help women become-as they say-less naive about the political process and more knowledgeable in working for the political party of their choice.

They also wanted to know about the details of small business, about obtaining finance and about staying out of trouble in a business. They have, after all, had 70 years of no small business. Most of them have had no ability to get out of the country and see small business working in the Western world, and they were very eager to get information from us on that subject.

But there were other issues of importance raised with us while we were in the Soviet Union which I would like to raise tonight briefly. I have mentioned women's health and occupational health and safety, and they were issues which really did worry me very much. We heard how married women in the Soviet Union might expect to have between seven and 14 abortions during the course of their married life because of the lack of contraception. We also heard about the desperate lack of sex education. We heard that few contraceptives were produced in the Soviet Union, and with the lack of foreign currency it was a low priority for buying from overseas. We heard about diaphragms that were made in the Soviet Union but were made of metal and ulcerated women so that they were very badly hurt. We heard about Soviet women being frigid. We also heard about Soviet men being alcoholic. I do not know whether the production of more contraceptives might solve more than one problem in one go, but certainly it seemed as if this is an important subject which has been of extremely low priority in the years where defence has been a very high expenditure and health has been quite low.

We heard about the lack of antenatal care for women. We heard about the crowded and antiquated obstetric hospitals and the difficulties for women in a crowded obstetrics system. We also heard about women working in factories with inadequate protection for their health. We were told that there were 30 million working places designated below satisfactory working conditions and that 700,000 of these places actually break the health and safety laws. We were told that women working in these jobs were unhealthy and that 100 cities in the USSR have been designated as zones of ecological disaster.

We were told of the increasing numbers of children being born with health defects and deformities. We were told that partly this was exacerbated by the lack of antenatal care, but also by the exposure of women in heavy industry to chemicals, and also to the long hours with many of them working 12 hours a day in order to get sufficient income. Because in the Soviet Union a high proportion of the women are working in unskilled positions and therefore on fairly low incomes, in many cases they have opted to work 12-hour days in order to get sufficient money. These are things which are obviously facing the Government and are of great importance. I hope they will be solved.

Senator Vallentine and I met with the Deputy Chief of the General Staff. I also met with the veterans organisation. We heard from these military people about restructuring the Defence Force and I heard about the care of veterans. The openness with which we were given budgetary information-which sometimes in Australia we have to drag out of the defence Estimates committee-was really quite an eye opener to me, at least, and I think also to Senator Vallentine.

There is much I could comment on but I do not wish to take the time of the Senate for long tonight. The General was particularly frank and talked about the problems facing them. One example that he stated quite categorically was that there was currently a problem with morale in the forces, which we believe to be the case, but it was interesting to have him acknowledge it. Also, the Soviet military had not been accustomed to public criticism in the Soviet Union but that was now a growing force, and they had not been accustomed to being subject to public scrutiny of the defence budget in the detail which they now had to face. He wryly told us that his opposite numbers in the United States had sympathised with him on their mutual problems in this area of dealing with politicians who want to scrutinise defence spending.

We were all somewhat surprised at the clear resurgence of religion and particularly that there were a lot of young people taking part in religious services wherever we had the opportunity to see them. We heard about legislation which has changed the censorship laws, but other people told us that senior management in some of the media are exercising covert censorship even if the overt censorship is banned. We heard reports on the human rights situation.

We went to an exhibition of paintings which I found particularly interesting. Two galleries displayed works of dissident artists which had not been displayed in the Soviet Union until this last year. The artists had been imprisoned, executed or exiled in the early years after the revolution in 1917. Although they had made their names in the West and their work had been exhibited and bought and sold in the West, they were not known to the Soviet people. They are now on permanent display. These were the dissidents who showed what it was really like for the peasants to be collectivised, for example. They showed that working in the coal mines, whether under capitalism or communism, was not the most joyous of occupations-unlike the propagandists who were accepted by the state.

We also heard about the shortage of housing, a matter of great concern to many people. We were told of 200,000 Army officers who, with their families, are without homes. The option at the moment is that some may well have to spend time in tents-in a difficult climate, as you would recognise, Mr President. We also heard that for many families there is a wait of three to four years for housing. We also heard, worst of all, that as there are no refuges women who are subject to violent husbands have no alternative but to stay and cope with the situation. For couples who divorce, many will spend two or three years under the same roof with the spouse from whom they have been divorced.

The Senate will probably be interested to know that I was told that one of the most popular programs on Soviet television is the long television coverage when the Supreme Soviet is sitting. Democracy is such a fascinating subject for many people in the Soviet Union that to simply sit and watch the televising of the Supreme Soviet or the Moscow City Council, which is also televised, is to watch the most popular program on television.

One cannot come away from the Soviet Union without thinking how we can possibly help. It is a wealthy country, but it is going through very difficult economic times. I do not believe that gifts of money from the West is the solution to its problems. It must find its own solutions to many of its problems. But there are practical ways that we can help. I understand that in 1987 the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, offered to Prime Minister Ryzhkov an exchange program whereby young Soviet citizens could be brought to Australia for short periods to work in business, the bureaucracy and finance to get an experience that they can take back and in that way contribute to the new market economy in the Soviet Union. I understand that the Soviet Government has not taken up that offer. I do hope that the publicity we have been able to give that offer in our travels in the Soviet Union and since we have returned will help the Soviet Union to make a decision.

I also raised with the military the possibility of military cadets in our country and the Soviet Union having short exchanges to military academies, and also the possibility of junior and middle ranking officers having short exchanges to their units, as we do with defence forces from some other countries. I was told that if an offer was made by the Australian Government and the Australian military, it would be sympathetically received.

We need to make sure that middle level personnel from Australia can go to the Soviet Union to help in the market economy, especially people who have entrepreneurial skills and a background in small business and banking who can go and conduct seminars at the request of the Soviet people. I would like to see, for example, members of the Business and Professional Women's Association being enabled, perhaps by our Government through the provision of fares, to go to the Soviet Union and for the Soviet Women's Committee to sponsor them for a few weeks so they are given the opportunity to learn more about small business. It is particularly important for women because it gives them an opportunity as mothers to have flexibility in their working hours and to have some opportunity for financial independence.

Those women in the Soviet Union crave contact with the West. They have not been able to travel and, because of the foreign currency problems, they will probably not be able to do so for some time. But if they could become members of international women's organisations such as the Business and Professional Women's Association, the Federation of University Women, the International Council of Women, Zonta and so on, they would at least have that fertilisation from the West that they so crave and, I believe, need.

One organisation which is not present in the Soviet Union and which would be valuable is the Girl Guides Association. Women in the Soviet Union are bearing enormous burdens now. They have enormous challenges to face in the future. Something like the Girl Guides Association, which helps girls with leadership training, initiative training and confidence, would be an ideal organisation to be able to contribute to the future of Soviet women. I hope that our guides here might be able in some way to help Soviet girls.

We were also asked while we were there whether a parliamentary delegation from this country would be able to go to Chernobyl. I put that on the record now so that some consideration might be given by the Parliament to see whether this would be possible. They want the world to see what happened at Chernobyl. They want the world to see what is happening now. I put that to my colleagues with a hope that some serious consideration might be given.

I once again state my extreme gratitude to the Soviet Women's Committee for making this visit possible. A 20-minute or so speech could not possibly begin to tell of the enormous value which I personally got from the visit, of the things which I learnt, and of the understanding which I gained of the enormous job which is going to be faced by the citizens of the Soviet Union. We all depend around the world on glasnost and perestroika being successful. The Soviet people stand to gain from it and so do we. Its failure, I believe, would be a dreadful thing for us all. The contribution which glasnost and perestroika will make and can make to the reduction of tension and to peace in the world is just beyond statement. I send the Soviet people my very best wishes in the challenges that this next difficult year, or two or three years, poses for them. I hope that all goes well for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to address the Senate on a meeting that I attended last Saturday at Roma with Senator Macdonald from the Liberal Party, Senator Burns from the Australian Labor Party and Senator Kernot. We represented all sections of the political spectrum. It was a meeting that I walked away from feeling very depressed because the problems that were exposed there seemed to have very difficult solutions. The people who gathered there did a magnificent job. Between 800 and 900 people-perhaps a few more-attended. All sections of the community-from the local machinery agents, the retailers and the livestock hauliers to the farmers and graziers-spoke at that meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: These people expressed a grave concern about their future and the future of their families. This year the Roma district alone will lose some $24m more than last year. There will be a loss of $10m in wheat sales and $14m in wool sales. This is only one small district of the rural community throughout Australia, one small microcosm of the primary industry.

The meeting called for a bipartisan approach from the parliamentary representatives who were there. Senator Burns, representing the Australian Labor Party, acknowledged that there was a rural crisis. He said quite openly that anyone could recognise the problems with wheat down to the lowest rate it had been for 40 years and wool in a crisis situation. Senator Burns was honest enough to admit that there were problems in the rural industry. He said that it was a rural depression.

The problem of interest rates was discussed. The people who attended the meeting pointed out that they could no longer sustain their businesses with interest rates at the current levels. Today I was very glad to see that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have lowered official interest rates by one per cent. I hope that the banks will pass the reductions in interest rates on to the farming community. On the last four occasions when the banks have lowered their interest rates, they have failed to pass the reductions on to the farming community. The farmers were telling us that they are paying up to 20 per cent in interest rates and 3 and 4 per cent in bank charges. They also called for the lowering in the value of the Australian dollar.

I am also glad to see today that the dollar has fallen 3c from Friday-a possible response to the lowering of the interest rates. Every cent the dollar falls, rural Australia benefits $170m. So the farmers have a bit of hope for the future when they see the dollar fall to 79c over a period of 48 hours.

The people at the Roma crisis meeting also expressed a problem with the high cost of fuel. The Government's revenue at the moment is 32c per litre, including excise production levies. That does not cover the State taxes imposed by every State except Queensland.
The people in the rural industry wanted us to bring this problem before the Senate so that the Ministers could understand what was happening.

The Inter-State Commission (ISC) report on road use charges was mentioned. I know that Senator Collins, who represents a large Territory with a very small population, would have to consider this matter. It was said that the ISC report, if implemented, would cost rural Australia another 10 per cent with the increased cost of cartage, which would be felt in bringing the goods from the cities to the rural communities and, in return, taking the products from the rural communities to the markets in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne.

One of the livestock transporters estimated that it would cost an extra 40c a kilo to move beef from the Roma area into the cities. He pointed out that the cost would be passed on in the increased cost of meat. Road trains and trailers will be paying considerably more. In Queensland the registration for a 40 foot trailer weighing 32 tonnes will rise from between $2,000 and $3,000 to $18,600. This will bankrupt many of the road hauliers and the ones who are left will have to pass the increased cost on to their customers.

There are a number of road trains in the community. The proprietors of the livestock transporters pointed out that their registration would increase from $6,000 to around $57,000 per annum. That money would be paid up-front. They pointed out to the meeting that they could not afford these increased charges and many of them would not be around in the future. They particularly wanted the ISC report brought up in the Parliament. I believe the report is causing a great deal of concern in rural Australia, as Senator Collins would be aware.

The farmers also complained about the inspection levies. As from January next year the export inspection levies will be raised by 40 per cent to recover a full 100 per cent on export inspections. We could argue about the user pays principle and whether it was the right or the wrong process. I am saying that there could not be a worse time to increase the cost of primary industry levies than at the moment. In Australia's history I do not believe that we have seen a rural crisis such as this one. Normally one commodity will hit a depth; on the other hand, the remaining commodities will be maintained at a certain level.

Wheat is down to the lowest price in 40 years, and we do not want to talk about wool as it is in such a mess. There could not be a worse time to start increasing costs on primary industry. The farmers do not have the capacity at the moment to withstand any further cost increases. Many farmers acknowledge that they will not make it through the next two or three years. The farmers who are viable will have to go into debt, and the farmers who are in debt now will no longer be viable.

These were the problems faced by the 700 to 1,000 people who wanted to get that message to the Parliament of Australia. The Government must answer the question: What type of a rural community does it want? Does it want a family farm, or does it want the small family farm to go into liquidation and be bought by agricultural corporations? I was disappointed that I did not have the solutions.

One of the solutions that I think the Government should take on board-I ask Senator Collins to take this message back to Cabinet-relates to the family allowance, Austudy and the isolated children's allowance. From 1 January the family allowance assets test will be set at $300,000. Very few properties in rural Australia would be worth less than $300,000. If they were worth less than $300,000 they would not be viable. That family allowance also has an income test of $57,000.

It was pointed out that many children would have to leave school or tertiary education. The families would not be able to send their children to school. It was also pointed out that, whereas a farmer may make a conscious decision to earn his income from rural pursuits, his children should not be discriminated against. There are many farms that will have no income for the next three years and many farms that will have a negative income for the next three years. Those farms may be worth a lot of money but they will not produce any income. Those primary producers will have to tighten their belts; they will have to cut their costs and cut their suit according to the cloth.

The farmers asked us to carry the message back to this place: `Please do not discriminate against our children; please give our children a fair go; please give our children the same rights and privileges as those given to every other child in Australia'. The isolated children's allowance will be asset tested at $200,000 reduced from $400,000 as from 1 January. Again, these people who require isolated children's allowance have no schools nearby to which they can send their children. They are forced into sending their children into hostels in the country towns or to boarding schools. Many children will have to be taken away from boarding school because the assets test limit will now be reduced to $200,000. That is excluding the family home on the farm. I have never been able to work out how to calculate the price of a home on a family farm. Senator Collins might be able to enlighten me. It would seem to me that the value would be only what the home was worth when putting it on a truck and re-establishing it on a block of land elsewhere in the town.

The amount of the assets test for Austudy has been reduced from $400,000 to $200,000. That is a real problem for children and young adults who are away at school, at universities and at tertiary institutions. Many farmers will have no income to pay school fees and expenses. I ask the Government to take into consideration the rural crisis at the moment. Children should not have to suffer and miss out on a basic education. I do not think that anyone in this Parliament would disagree with that. I will ask Senator Richardson-I put him on notice now-that if the opportunity arises and I receive the call during Question Time in the next week whether he will consider delaying the implementation of the assets test until people in rural Australia are in a better position to educate their children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you giving notice of that question?

—I certainly give Senator Richardson notice of the question and I also expect Senator Collins to give him notice of it. I intend to ask Senator Richardson that question within the next day or two. As Senator Burns rightly acknowledged, there is a rural crisis. Surely all of those tests on Austudy, family support and the isolated children's allowance should be based on an income test, not on an assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins represents much of rural Australia. While he is elected by the voters who support the Labor Party, he would have a number of constituents facing similar crises, although Senator Collins is fortunate enough not to have any wheat or wool growers in his electorate. Maybe his constituents have not felt the full brunt of the rural crisis. As I have pointed out a number of times-I do it every time I have the opportunity-it is not just the broadacre farmers who are suffering now. The horticulturalists, the dairy farmers, the peanut farmers and the pineapple growers-every rural sector in Australia, perhaps with the exception of cotton and bananas-are suffering.

In a spirit of cooperation I say to members of the Parliament of Australia that there is a great deal of concern, worry and tension facing rural Australia at the moment. I say to these people that times will change. Hopefully the wheat situation will turn around in the next year and wheat will bring a reasonable price. I bring this message from the Roma crisis meeting held last Saturday and I place it before the Parliament of Australia for us to take on board and hopefully to come up with some sort of solution for rural Australia.
